Consumer complaint narrative: I requested an assumption os next of kin/successor in interest for my father 's home after he passed. I was advised by Shellpoint / NewRez mortgage, who serviced the loan, that the only way to assume the loan was to withhold payment to trigger a loss mitigation and forebearance, after which I could begin the assumption process. I had submitted the will, and all required documents to the servicing company within XXXX  Days of my father 's passing in XXXX. I attempted the assumption process XXXX  times, each time going through every process they requested and submitting every document they requested. XXXX  times they failed to process the assumption. So, I decided to just pay the mortgage off completely. I submitted a formal payoff request XX/XX/XXXX and received it, and wired the funds quoted on that notice XX/XX/XXXX. Funds processed without issue. However, there seems to have been a miscommunication or error on their part where only $ XXXX of the quoted {$60.00} was properly applied, and their claim is that I still owe over {$8800.00} to finally pay off the loan as they just paid property Taxes, which were known to them at time of payoff. This appears to be a misallocation of the funds, as they pulled extra money designated for principal and payoff and applied it to escrow and other misc fees and interest. I would like an investigation into what is going on at NewRez/Shellpoint as there are numerous complaints from other homeowners regarding continued misallocation of funds. Further, based on my conversations with other financial advisors and institutions, the information that a loss mitigation and forebearance are necessities to assume the loan as sucessor in interest appears to be factually incorrect and solely based to keep me from being able to refinance the loan with another institution.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

You are still reporting XXXX XXXX XXXX as an active debt even though it was fully paid off on XX/XX/year>. You already have the payoff, you already have the XXXX balance, and you already have the transaction details. There is nothing for me to authorize. This is your mistake to fix. 

You do not need my permission to stop reporting false information. You just need to correct it. Update the credit bureaus now and send written confirmation as soon as the update is made. Handle this immediately. 

Message to XXXX  I am disputing inaccurate reporting on my credit file. The lender is incorrectly reporting XXXX XXXX XXXX as an active debt even though it was paid in full on XX/XX/year>. The balance is XXXX. 

I am requesting an immediate investigation and correction. The lender has already acknowledged receiving the payoff, yet the account is still reporting incorrectly. 

Please update this account to reflect paid in full and closed. I expect written confirmation once the correction is completed. 

Message to XXXX  I am disputing inaccurate information on my credit file. XXXX XXXX XXXX is still being reported as open and active, even though it was fully paid off on XX/XX/year>. 

The balance is XXXX and the lender has full proof of payment. I am requesting that XXXX  conduct an investigation and correct the reporting immediately. Update the account to paid in full and closed and provide written confirmation once the changes are processed.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I work a job that is not consistent so since the start of my loan with New Rez, I make payments early. I have never had an issue. They provide a box that allows me to allocate my payment and I allocated my payments to future payment. In XXXX, everything was allocated as I asked and my next payment was due XX/XX/XXXX due to making and allocating on their form how I wanted my payments made. 

Suddenly on XX/XX/XXXX without any notice they took my payments and put them towards principal. I do not want the payments towards principal and did not allocate them that way. I intentionally pay early so I make sure my house payment is always made. 

I immediately called and was told it would be fixed, it was not, I called back and was told it would be escalated. I called today and was told you can not pay more than three months ahead. 

That would be find had I been told that and had I not received statements for month and been able to allocate these payments ahead. I am not sure how they can suddenly make a policy change and change my past allocations without notice or warning. 

I am now scared, I will not have funds to make those payments which is why I made them when I did. I did not want them applied towards principal, that does not help me in a couple months when I am out of funds. 

I have requested if they can not apply the payments as they had them in XXXX they refund me as I need the fund if not applied to future payments to make those payments. I feel they are doing this to try and have a reason to destroy my credit or foreclose on me. The reason for the early payments was to protect that in the uncertainty that I have. 

I request that A - they restore everything to what was on last months XXXX statement or B-refund me the extra amount put towards principal ( reducing that misapplied allocation ) and I will put in savings so I can make those payments. I will do that in the future since there has been this policy change. I do not think it is air to retroactively apply it to me. I did not agree to it and each time I made a payment I used the coupon and told them where it was to go. I do not know how they can change those terms. 

I do have this in escalation but the young lady told me she is not sure they will help me. I desperately need help so that I don't have issues with those payments and again, I do not understand how they can make a unilaterally decide to retroactively un-apply the payments as agreed and simply put them where they want. 

I am attaching the statement that shows things when they were allocated as we both agreed and prior to these reversals and mess made of my account.

Consumer complaint narrative:
This complaint concerns various commercial loans that are currently being serviced by Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing. Shellpoint services a total of ( XXXX ) commercial loans consisting of ( XXXX ) scattered site properties that we own across various LLCs. 
There are two issues : our properties are single-family dwellings that are insured under a master insurance policy. Until XX/XX/year>, our insurance broker was XXXX, and our annual policy began on XX/XX/XXXX at XXXX and ended on XX/XX/XXXX at XXXX XXXX  the following year. XXXX was not the best at sending the policies out and I admit there were issues with Shellpoint receiving EOPs and COIs in the past. Knowing that we were changing carriers, I personally oversaw sending of certificates by our new insurance broker/producer, XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) so that Shellpoint received notice on XXXX XXXX that we had changed insurance companies and XXXX  emailed them property ( EOP ) and General Liability ( COI ) certificates for every loan being serviced by Shellpoint. Naturally, Shellpoint did not process many of these certificates and mailed us individual letters for every property, so I spent months resending insurance certificates for approximately XXXX or so loans for the past 10 months. This has been extremely labor intensive and provides insight as to why I have no energy or patience left to deal with this. 

Now, we are receiving various notices that Shellpoint has put Forced Placed Insurance on many of our properties and deducted the cost from our escrow accounts. Some of these cost {$8000.00} per property. This means I know I have to send the insurance certs for the fourth or fifth time and then I have to make sure we receive the correct credit to our escrow account. We do not have the person power for this, and I do not believe it should be this difficult. Shellpoint is completely incompetent, or they are doing this on purpose because they make money on the FPI (? ). I am at my wits end and I don't know what else to do. This could be a full-time position for someone to just deal with uploading and tracking insurance certificates for commercial loan servicers. 

The second issue is that Shellpoint does not list the Borrower correctly so when the insurance certs are sent they list an LLC, but Shellpoint is showing the Guarantor. I sent them a copy of the signed loan documents to review to prove that our version of the certificates are correct. They ignore my email and supporting documents and put FPI in place. This is specifically in reference to Loan XXXX and the property XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, PA XXXX.

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/year>, I requested and received a payoff letter effective through XX/XX/year>. We closed the sale of the home on XX/XX/year>. They received the check on XX/XX/year>. Today, XX/XX/year>, they emailed the title company stating that there is more money due. I talked with a representative of the company and they said there were additional letter generated after XX/XX/year>XXXX  stating the payoff amount had changed. I never received the letters! I emailed ( as there was not a phone number ) the contact who reached out to the title company. The responded to the title company that they are not customer facing but still did not provide the breakdown that was requested only the reduction of interest that I asked for. They will not communicate with me! This is unacceptable. 

First of all, they are stating there are more fees related to the foreclosure. In XXXX, I got the amount to take it out of foreclosure from the company and it was paid by the XX/XX/XXXX (? ) deadline. I am being told that the attorney fees were not paid. If they were not paid then the funds were misappropriated and this caused the entire problem. If they were paid and more fees were generated, I should be given that information. 

This company has been EXTREMELY difficult to get information from. My father passed at the end of XX/XX/year>. I began the process of getting information for his mortgage in XXXX when I had the documents stating I was the personal representative of the estate. It took 2 months to get me on as an authorized contact! This was a process I was told would take 2 weeks! This is exactly where the problems began. Had this been handled in a timely manner, it would not have gotten to the foreclosure process. 

I have been more than patient and understanding in this whole process. However, we are reaching court deadlines that I have to explain all the amounts paid. I spent over an hour and a half on the phone with someone from the company who really didn't have an answer for me when I got off the phone. He admitted there were things happening that shouldn't be but that it had. He stated he and his supervisors need time to do more research. I understand that. However, I have a deadline to pay the amount by tomorrow prior to XXXX or the amount will change. I need to have answers and I am not getting them in a timely manner. 

This is an unprofessional way of handling important information. There are too many hands in the pot and no one seems to know what is going on. I work in a call center. I understand noting the file. However, it seems that NO ONE is making notes or if they are, no one is reading them. I am beyond frustrated as a person who worked in banking. My dad was a veteran. I was the wife of a veteran for over 20 years. I have spent my life supporting our XXXX  and I have never seen such poor handling of a Veteran 's affairs by a company. I was also informed by the title company that this has happened to others in transactions they have handled. DO BETTER! 

I did not have to work to sell this property. I could have turned it back over to them and made it their problem. However, I did the responsible thing and contacted them and maintained contact with them. It is an error on their part that the original payoff letter did not reflect the amount they are saying is different. I should not have to pay for their error. This seems like they are trying to make more money off a Veteran and his remaining family.

Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative: Compliance Department Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing Dear XXXX XXXX, I am writing to formally request that Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing remove the inaccurately reported late payment for XX/XX/XXXX from my credit report in connection with Loan # XXXX for the property located at XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, CA XXXX. As stated in my prior complaint to the CFPB and multiple conversations with Shellpoint agents before XX/XX/XXXX, I contacted Shellpoint early and frequently after a declared natural disaster severely damaged my property on XX/XX/XXXX. XXXX officially designated the region a disaster area shortly thereafter. I initiated calls on XX/XX/XXXX and several more times prior to the XXXX delinquency threshold to ask whether to make the XXXX payment or preserve funds for emergency mitigation and safety repairs. During those calls, I was advised that I could enter a forbearance and would not be penalized for deferring the XXXX payment. This advice formed the basis of my decision not to pay XXXX at that time. Shellpoints own letter, dated XX/XX/XXXX, confirms the start of a forbearance period. I relied on that written communication in good faith. However, the XXXX payment was later reported as 30 days late to the credit bureaus, despite my early and consistent contact and reliance on XXXX assurances. As a result, my XXXX XXXX dropped over XXXX pointsmy first and only derogatory mark in years of timely payments. The Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), XXXX XXXX. XXXX ( a ), mandates that furnishers of credit information report accurately and not in a misleading manner. Courts have ruled that even technically accurate information can be misleading in context. In XXXX XXXX XXXX Banking and XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ), the XXXX XXXX held that a furnisher can be held liable under the FCRA for reporting that is technically accurate but materially misleading. Further, XXXX v. Experian XXXX. XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX ) reaffirmed that a forbearance or deferment should prevent adverse reporting if the borrower was told no payment was due. Additionally, under guidance from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security ( CARES ) Act, if a borrower is in a forbearance due to hardship ( including declared disasters ), servicers should not report the account as delinquent. Although the XXXX Acts specific mandates have sunset, the regulatory precedent and consumer expectation around fairness and good faith negotiations remain. In my case, I made diligent efforts to seek clarification and guidance before the XXXX delinquency window closed. I was never advised that my loan would fall out of good standing if I waited for forbearance approvala decision influenced entirely by Shellpoints verbal and written communication. Finally, XXXX suggestion to contact departments that can not resolve the issue, or to mail letters to offices with no authority, has only prolonged the problem. The provided contact numbers and internal referrals have been ineffective in correcting this unjust situation. I respectfully request that Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing remove the XX/XX/XXXX late payment from my credit history immediately due to the following : I proactively contacted Shellpoint well before the XXXX late mark. I relied in good faith on verbal and written assurances from Shellpoint that I could defer XXXX payment. The late reporting is materially misleading and harmful. Established case law and FCRA guidance support correction where reporting is technically accurate but contextually false. The property was impacted by a declared disaster, and I acted promptly and responsibly under those extraordinary circumstances. Please provide written confirmation of the deletion of the derogatory reporting and confirm that updated information will be furnished to all credit bureaus. Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, CA XXXX Loan Number : XXXX Phone : ( XXXX ) XXXX Email : XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern at Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing, I am writing to formally document and escalate a serious and ongoing issue related to my attempt to pay off my mortgage, which has now been unreasonably obstructed for more than XXXX months due to actions and inactions by Newrez LLC, Shellpoints parent company. 

Despite repeated, good-faith efforts on my part to change the name on the property and loan to XXXX XXXX upon my husbands death and obtain accurate payoff information and complete payment in full, Newrez LLC has repeatedly failed to provide the necessary documentation and clarity required to finalize this transaction. This prolonged delay has effectively blocked my legal right to satisfy my mortgage obligation and has resulted in continued and unnecessary accrual of interest. 

I want to be clear : this situation is not the result of inaction on my part. I have been proactive, responsive, and persistent throughout this process. The breakdown has occurred entirely within Newrez/Shellpoints servicing and administrative processes. 

As a result of this delay, I have incurred : Ongoing and avoidable interest charges Attorney fees required to navigate what should have been a routine mortgage payoff Significant emotional distress I am a recent widow, and the length, opacity, and dismissive nature of this process have compounded an already difficult season of loss. While I recognize that mortgage servicing is complex, the extended obstruction I have experienced rises to the level of unreasonable and, in my view, emotionally harmful conduct.

Post-Bankruptcy Mishandling : The statement acknowledges my bankruptcy but demands full payment, ignoring discharge protections under 11 U.S.C. 524. Shellpoint 's actions risk violating the automatic stay and discharge injunction, as seen in complaints where they harass discharged borrowers.

Consumer complaint narrative: Good afternoon, I have been paying on my loan with Shellpoint since the early part of XXXX  on time. Since I started this loan repayment process, I have never called once about hardship assistance. I work for an essential department that requires me and my colleagues to perform our civil duty with the promise of being paid in the future. I would think that my creditors would understand and would honor me with a forbearance request until I can get paid again. I have called on numerous occasions to Shellpoint during the month of XXXX, and I have been denied this request due to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX, the owner of my loan, do not believe my situation is important and I should have the money available to pay without any income now. I wish I knew where your logic is coming from, but I see this is my last hope to appease to your sympathetic side of my situation and to request forbearance moving forward. I will not have the funds to pay for XXXX payment and my XX/XX/XXXX past due payment. But I will pay what I owe as soon as the federal government opens and release funding for us. I just dont want to have these delinquent payments show up on my credit as negative due to nonpayment that I can not control. Please be more considerate to your borrowers during hard times, especially if they have a solid history of making payments. I would like to appeal against your forbearance denial and request another investigation to investigate my hardship assistance case. I have followed your instructions, and your office still will not provide me with a solid reason why I am being denied. Respectfully if I need to speak to my legal representation on the matter if a negative mark is shown on my credit for the month of XXXX and XXXX due to delinquent payments when I have asked and provided the reason for hardship assistance, then I believe a lawsuit will have to occur to protect my rights as a federal employee during a hardship situation due to a government shutdown.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Details of the Problem I am filing a formal complaint against XXXX XXXX and Newrez LLC ( dba Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing, successor to XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX ) for failing to inform me of mandatory CARES Act forbearance options, manufacturing fraudulent documentation, engaging in bad-faith servicing, illegally accelerating my loan during a federal foreclosure moratorium, and engaging in the prohibited practice of dual tracking. 
Background My mortgage loan with XXXX XXXX is federally backed by XXXX XXXX, making it subject to CARES Act protections and the federal foreclosure moratorium active until XX/XX/XXXX. Due to severe financial hardship from the COVID-19 pandemic, my loan went into default. When the loan was transferred to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX while in default, they became " debt collectors '' under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). Newrez LLC ( XXXX Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ) is the successor to XXXX following an acquisition. 
Chronology of Events & Timeline Issues XXXX XXXX Failures ( Late XXXX XXXX ) : Inaccessible Home Preservation Specialist : My assigned specialist, XXXX XXXX XXXX was consistently inaccessible and failed to provide guidance on appropriate workout options ( Payment Deferral, Flex Modification, etc. ), which is a violation of servicer duties. The inability to contact not one, but two, XXXX XXXX home preservation specialists, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic, is a significant issue and a severe failure to perform their duties. The very assignment of these specialists proves that I had previously reached out to the bank and formally requested assistance. 
Imposition of Unauthorized Fees : Home preservation fees were being charged to me during a time in which I was actively working with XXXX XXXX on a loan modification. This is a potential violation of servicer regulations that prohibit charging certain fees while a loss mitigation application is under review or a forbearance is active. 
Failure to Disclose CARES Act Options : Throughout my interactions, I was never informed that the immediate, mandatory CARES Act forbearance was a viable option, despite my documented hardship. The COVID-19 specific guidance under Regulation X of RESPA required servicers to inform borrowers about CARES Act forbearance options during live contact, a requirement XXXX XXXX failed to meet. 
Unviable Loan Modification Offer & Misinformation : The " Flex Trial Payment '' offer was discovered later in general paperwork, as I was never verbally notified about it. XXXX XXXX proceeded with this offer without proper underwriting or collecting current financial documentation reflecting my pandemic hardship. This offer did not align with XXXX XXXX COVID-19 Flex Modification guidelines designed to ensure sustainable payment reductions. 
Executive Office Misrepresentation : An executive case specialist, XXXX XXXX, provided explicitly inaccurate information, stating the trial payment was only " designed to bring the account current '' and not necessarily lower my payment. This misrepresentation highlights systemic failure or intentional misinformation. 
XXXX XXXX 's Written Admission ( XX/XX/XXXX ) : In their formal response letter, XXXX XXXX explicitly admitted : " We are unable to locate documentation from you requesting payment assistance or application. '' This is a critical admission : it confirms my requests for assistance were lost, ignored, or never logged into their system. It invalidates their prior claim that they removed me from assistance for " not responding. '' The combination of missed communication, misinformation, and lost documentation suggests a systemic problem rather than an isolated oversight. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and Newrez LLC/Shellpoint Servicing Violations ( Post-Transfer and During Moratorium ) : Failure to Provide Debt Validation Notice : Following the loan transfer to SLS and initial communication, I was never provided a written validation of debt notice within the required five days, a clear violation of the FDCPA. 
Fraudulent Breach Letter and Forgery : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX generated a fraudulent breach letter associated with an invalid tracking number and an alleged forged signature on the certified mailing receipt. This letter was supposedly sent out during the federal mortgage foreclosure moratorium ( which was active until XX/XX/XXXX ). The servicer 's actions constitute an unlawful acceleration of my loan, as proper written notification was never validly delivered as required by law and the loan agreement, and was prohibited during that timeframe. 
Violation of Foreclosure Moratorium : The issuance of this breach letter and the acceleration occurred during the federal mortgage foreclosure moratorium ( which applied to federally backed loans like mine ), a clear violation of protections. 
Contradictory Reinstatement Quotes and Hidden Fees : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX provided a reinstatement quote in which it was explicitly noted with a " {$0.00} '' entry, indicating that no legal fees, property preservation fees, late fees, or any other charges would be added. However, these exact fees are clearly shown in my payment history. Furthermore, Shellpoint later provided me with a separate, detailed breakdown of property preservation fees dating from XXXX until XXXX. This discrepancy demonstrates deceptive practices and the imposition of unauthorized fees. 
Dual Tracking : I believe I may have also been a victim of dual tracking, a practice prohibited under CFPB Regulation X of the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA ). Mortgage servicers are generally prohibited from proceeding with foreclosure while a loss mitigation application is pending review. This violation is further underscored by the improper assessment of home preservation charges while I was actively seeking assistance, which suggests the servicer was simultaneously working toward foreclosure and loss mitigation tracks. 
Relevant Federal Law Violations The actions described above violate specific federal laws and regulations, suggesting systemic failures : CARES Act ( Section 4022 ) : The servicer violated the mandate to grant forbearance upon request ( Failure to Grant Forbearance Upon Request ). They imposed fees and interest beyond what was permitted ( Imposing Unauthorized Fees and Penalties ). The issuance of a breach letter during the moratorium violated Section 4022 ( c ) ( 2 ) ( Violation of the Foreclosure Moratorium ). There was also potential Inaccurate Credit Reporting.

Regulation X of RESPA ( 12 CFR Part 1024 ) : The servicer engaged in prohibited Dual Tracking ( 12 CFR 1024.41 ) by accelerating the loan during a time when loss mitigation options should have been explored and by assessing home preservation charges during that period. The inability to contact home preservation specialists is a Failure to Exercise Reasonable Diligence ( 12 CFR 1024.39 ), a duty that includes informing borrowers of COVID-19 options during required live contact. The general handling of my case suggests a Failure to Provide a Timely Response to loss mitigation inquiries.

Violations of the CFPA : The " explicitly inaccurate information, '' " manufactured fraudulent documentation, '' and contradictory reinstatement quotes are examples of the Misrepresentation and Deception that constitutes an unfair, deceptive, or abusive act or practice ( UDAAPs ) under the Consumer Financial Protection Act. 
FDCPA : The servicer failed to provide a debt validation notice following the initial communication as required under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative:
My parents passed away a few years ago. My wife and I had lived in the house with them. We were making the payments and continued to make the payments for a few years with no problem. When Shellpoint took over as servicer, they wanted an insurance policy with my parents ' names, but we had transferred the title to my trust ( based on my parent 's trust wishes ) and then I transferred it to my wife 's trust as I have stage 4 non-Hodgkins Lymphoma, and the prognosis is not good. We provided all documents requested to Shellpoint including our wedding license, my parents trust, our drivers ' licenses showing that we lived in the property and they continue to ask for the same thing. Then we get notices saying we have not given them what they requested, and one of the last correspondences says our mortgage holder is US Bank Trust Company.

They forced placed insurance on us. They are holding funds in OUR impound account to pay for taxes and insurance, so we stopped paying payments thinking that would encourage them to move and od the right thing. Well so far, they have not. I believe Shellpoint, now US bank is trying to steal the equity in our home. All I want is them to acknowledge our ownership, let us get our own insurance, and let us cure all payments. I think these people are crooks!!

Consumer complaint narrative:
Unethical financial business practice by Newrez Mortgage Co likely preventing consumers from recasting mortgage. I have a right to recast my mortgage and have a significant lump-sum to put down which will greatly reduce the amount of interest I'm paying ; of course, it is not in the best interest of Newrez to lose interest. Therefore, there is no reason for them to train their employees on the process of recast. 
There is no way anyone should be expected to feel comfortable paying $ XXXX online/over the phone to Principal with no paperwork or written documentation memorializing a re-cast v. lump-sum principal payment. According to XXXX agents at Newrez I'm just supposed to " trust '' that they apply my lump-sum to a re-cast agreement v. straight principal payment, and Newrez can't give me anything in writing to memorialize this. Another agent who processed my case said absolutely do not pay into Principal without the paperwork processed first. 

XX/XX/XXXX - Called Mortgage Co [ Newrez ] to obtain process for Mortgage re-cast. Agent informed me that the process for re-cast is for to pay the lump-sum, plus a {$250.00} fee, to the Principal option online ; based on the notes he makes in the system they'd use the payment to recast my mortgage. I advised the agent I'm uncomfortable paying close to $ XXXX to principal and relying on the notes he made to ensure this becomes a re-cast and isn't simply applied as a lump-sum principal payment ; there should certainly be some sort of paperwork on the matter or someone to talk to about what my new payment would look like, etc. I was informed by the agent that isn't the way it works ; he said if I don't like the way it turns out Newrez will send me a refund check. I questioned him on that too - why would you send a refund check for $ XXXX when I owe you $ XXXX? He said I was being overly suspicious and Newrez is my mortgage co they are not trying to rip me off. He practically talked over me the entire time and when I tried to speak ( I wasn't even raising my voice ) he told me to count to ten. 

XX/XX/XXXX - Called XXXX XXXX in an attempt to get a different agent. This agent, who was very professional, said process is for her to open a case, in which paperwork will be sent to me within 9 days ( has to go through an approval process ), after receipt of the paperwork follow the direction to make the payment for the re-cast. XXXX said based on the date case is opened ( and provided case # ) the re-cast can be complete before XXXX payment is due. Agent said DO NOT MAKE A PRINCIPAL PAYMENT without the processed paperwork ; she said this is incorrect, apologized for someone providing incorrect info and would report it to her supervisor. 

XX/XX/XXXX - Called XXXX XXXX as no paperwork has been received and online account doesn't have any indicators that there is a re-cast case opened. This agent, who didn't even take the case # I offered up, says the process requires you make a lump-sum payment including fee to the Principal option of your account then the re-cast will take place, and no paperwork will be sent until you make that payment. I advised agent that I'm not sending $ XXXX blindly to Principal without written documentation & another agent already advised me not to do that, it is not the process. He responded that the process has recently changed. I questioned him as to when exactly the processed changed because I opened the case 10 days ago and that is not what I was told. I advised agent I needed to talk to a supervisor and he said, if time is of the essence for your XXXX payment you're wasting your time, the supervisor will tell you the same thing. I also brought to his attention if the process changed between XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX was anyone going to contact me to let me know I wasn't getting paperwork because the process changed ; this is very suspicious. Sub-issue: Closing disclosure or other related disclosures
Consumer complaint narrative:
A first-lien mortgage and a home equity line of credit ( HELOC ) secured by the same property were serviced by XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX and later by Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing , a division of NewRez LLC XXXX The first-lien mortgage XXXX owned by XXXX XXXX XXXX A non-judicial foreclosure sale occurred on XX/XX/year>. 

Following foreclosure, I requested loan history and account disclosures. The servicer produced a Loan History Summary and Loan History Statement for the first-lien mortgage that were presented as consumer loan history disclosures. 

Those records reflect a reported principal balance of approximately {$0.00} at or near the time foreclosure activity occurred, while simultaneously reflecting litigation-related disbursements and foreclosure-associated servicing entries. The disclosures do not explain how foreclosure was conducted, authorized, or reconciled in the presence of a de minimis reported principal balance, nor do they explain how foreclosure disposition activity affected the reported loan state. 

Separately, HELOC statements issued by XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX for the same collateral reflect extraordinary Outstanding Late Charges/ Fees totaling approximately {$270000.00}, posted immediately before and after the foreclosure event. These amounts include multiple six-figure entries dated XX/XX/year>, labeled as fees and not identified as payoff, recovery, disposition, or collateral-related accounting adjustments. 

The timing and magnitude of these HELOC fee entries coincide with the foreclosure of the senior lien but are reflected solely as servicing-level fees, without explanation of how they relate to the foreclosure sale, collateral disposition, or application of proceeds across lien positions XXXX 

Across both accounts, the disclosures provided to me as a consumer present : Near-zero or nominal principal balances contemporaneous with foreclosure activity ; Large foreclosure-related amounts characterized as servicing fees rather than clearly identified disposition or recovery entries ; and No clear reconciliation showing how foreclosure activity, fees, and reported balances align. 

I requested clarification and reconciliation from the servicer. While documents were produced, they did not explain how the balances and charges were calculated or classified in a manner that would allow a consumer to understand or independently verify the accuracy of the disclosures. 

As provided, the records functioned as consumer disclosures, yet they do not clearly communicate loan status, payoff condition, fee basis, or the effect of foreclosure on either account. This creates uncertainty regarding whether the disclosures accurately reflect account state and whether fees were characterized in a manner that is clear, transparent, and not misleading. 

Additionally, the servicer-provided loan history records reflect litigation-related disbursements and foreclosure-associated entries attributed to a law firm that does not appear to be the firm that conducted the foreclosure sale. The foreclosure was carried out by a different law firm than the one identified in the servicing records, and the disclosures provided do not explain this discrepancy or clarify the role of each firm. As presented, the records do not clearly or accurately identify the entities responsible for foreclosure activity associated with the account.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative:
Complaint Summary I am a homeowner in XXXX XXXX, Florida. My mortgage servicer initiated foreclosure and filed a XXXX XXXX while foreclosure activity was supposed to be suspended and while I was actively engaged in loss mitigation. 
My loan was in a disaster-related forbearance from XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX. In XX/XX/XXXX, I applied for a deed in lieu of foreclosure. The servicer confirmed in writing that foreclosure would be suspended during review. I was later approved for a XXXX-month trial payment plan ( XXXX ) requiring {$1300.00} monthly payments, to be received within each month. 
Despite this, the servicer filed a XXXX XXXX and served me with foreclosure papers on XX/XX/XXXX without notice that foreclosure had resumed or that loss mitigation was terminated. I then made the XXXX trial payment by cashiers check on XX/XX/XXXX in compliance with the written plan. 
I believe the servicer violated federal mortgage servicing regulations by advancing foreclosure while I was performing under an approved loss-mitigation plan, failed to provide required notices, and engaged in unfair and deceptive practices. 
I am requesting investigation, corrective action, and enforcement. 
Federal Law 12 C.F.R. 1024.41 ( Regulation X RESPA ) Prohibits dual tracking ( foreclosure while loss mitigation is active ) Bars advancing foreclosure while borrower is performing under a trialXXXX or mitigation agreement Requires clear written notice before termination or escalation Key subsection : 1024.41 ( g ) No foreclosure action may proceed while borrower is performing under a loss-mitigation option Florida Law Florida Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices Act ( FDUTPA ) Fla. Stat . 501.204 Prohibits unfair, deceptive, or unconscionable acts in trade or commerce Applies to mortgage servicing and foreclosure practices Florida foreclosure procedure ( judicial ) Foreclosure must strictly comply with notice, equity, and conditions precedent Premature filings and misleading conduct support dismissal or stay

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint against Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing for multiple serious servicing errors related to my mortgage loan # XXXX, secured by my property at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. These issues include a potentially invalid loan transfer that breaks the chain of title, an unauthorized interest rate increase, non-responsiveness from my assigned Single Point of Contact ( SPOC ), and an improper non-judicial foreclosure sale scheduled for XX/XX/XXXX. I believe these violations contravene the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA ), Regulation X ( including 12 CFR 1024.40 ), and California 's Homeowner Bill of Rights ( HBOR, including Civil Code 2924.11 ). Given the imminent foreclosure datejust weeks awayI urgently request CFPB intervention to prevent irreversible harm, such as the loss of my home. 
My loan originated on XX/XX/XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ) for {>= $1,000,000}. It was modified effective XX/XX/XXXX, via a Modification Agreement recorded in XXXX XXXX, California ( Instrument No. XXXX ). This modification was intended to be securitized into a trust in XXXX. However, I recently discovered the loan was not transferred into the trust until XXXX years later and likely well beyond the XXXX and XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) cutoff date. This delay may render the assignment void under New York trust law ( which commonly governs these XXXX ), thereby breaking the chain of title and calling into question Shellpoint 's standing to service or foreclose on the loan. California courts have consistently upheld borrowers ' rights to challenge such void assignments, as established in landmark cases like XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
The loan was modified by XXXX XXXX XXXX with a 2 % interest rate to stabilize my payments and prevent delinquency. Without my consent, proper notice, or any justification, Shellpoint, as the current servicer, unilaterally raised the rate to 3.5 %, leading to higher monthly payments, accumulated arrears, and potential overcharges. This increase may be entirely invalid due to the flawed XXXX transfer, which could void Shellpoint 's authority to make any changes, and it appears to breach the original modification agreement. Shellpoint has a documented history of mishandling loan modifications and rate adjustments, as evidenced by numerous CFPB complaints and a XXXX CFPB settlement requiring {$3.00} million in principal reductions for similar issues involving improper rate adjustments and servicing errors. The unauthorized rate hike has exacerbated my financial hardship, inflated my arrears, and resulted in overpayments for which I am owed a full refund, including interest on those amounts. 
Additionally, Shellpoint assigned me XXXX XXXX as a XXXX under XXXX and Regulation X to facilitate discussions on loss mitigation options. However, XXXX XXXX has been consistently non-responsive and hostile in prior interactions, as evidenced by the attached email chain from XX/XX/XXXX, where she repeatedly directed me to submit disputes in writing without addressing my concerns and stated that the loan was not assigned to a XXXXCcontradicting Shellpoint 's obligations. On XX/XX/XXXX, at XXXX XXXX XXXX  I emailed XXXX XXXX requesting immediate assistance with the pending foreclosure sale. I also emailed the Loss Mitigation Department to confirm her status as my XXXX. As of today, XX/XX/XXXX, I have received no response whatsoever from either, in clear violation of requirements for an accessible, knowledgeable, and responsive XXXX This non-responsiveness and apparent hostility have severely hindered my ability to explore viable alternatives to foreclosure, such as a new loan modification, forbearance, or repayment plan, and demonstrate a pattern of poor service that makes continued assignment to XXXX XXXX untenable. 
Despite these unresolved servicing errors and my ongoing attempts to engage in loss mitigation, Shellpoint has proceeded with scheduling a non-judicial foreclosure sale for XX/XX/XXXX. This action is wrongful and premature given the chain-of-title defects, interest rate errors, lack of XXXX communication, and potential invalidity of XXXX servicing actions. Under XXXX, the sale must be postponed if a complete loss mitigation application is under review or if servicing errors remain unaddressed. Furthermore, on XX/XX/XXXX, I sent a Notice of Error/Qualified Written Request ( QWR ) via certified mail, demanding corrections, documentation, and a response within the statutorily required timelinesyet I have received no acknowledgment or substantive reply. Shellpoint 's records currently indicate that to bring my loan current, I would need to pay approximately {$180000.00} in arrears, an amount that is artificially inflated by the unauthorized rate increase, related fees, and unapplied payments stemming from these errors. 
These cumulative violations have caused significant stress, emotional distress, potential overpayments, credit harm, lost equity and opportunity costs, and the imminent threat of losing my home. Shellpoint 's practices align with widespread consumer complaints about deceptive foreclosures, rate mishandling, poor customer service, and systemic failures in complying with federal and state regulations. I request immediate CFPB investigation and enforcement to halt these unfair practices and provide relief.

Consumer complaint narrative:
My mom is the original borrower for the loan and she passed away in XX/XX/year>. She fell behind on her mortgage payments because she was scammed by a company claiming to help lower payments. That company is currently being tried by the United States Department of Justice. I provided information to the mortgage company and they made me Successor in Interest. However, they did not offer me a fair option to take over the mortgage. I explained to them that I could continue with the mortgage payments which were {$810.00} per month. I just needed the past due payments pushed back to the end of the loan ultimately pushing back the payout date but they offered me a plan that raised the monthly payments by {$400.00} making the payment $ XXXX a month. I agreed to it even though I knew it would be tight financially. I know Shellpoint offers forbearance and deferred payments to their borrowers. However, they did not offer those options to me knowing that my mom passed away. Of course, I agreed to the option to save my moms home. However, my first payment was returned because of an unexpected payment that came through. If the mortgage was the original amount of {$810.00}, it wouldve gone through successfully. Originally, XXXX XXXX was working on my moms loan and he was very fast with responding to emails and helping me get Successor in Interest but as soon as I was approved, my moms case was transferred to another person named XXXX who never contacted and hasnt responded to my email. I had to call to see why I couldnt make a payment online and was told that because of the returned payment of $ XXXX the loan is in pre-foreclosure and that I need to pay {$7000.00} to save the home. This is utterly disgusting for Shellpoint to do because yes I understand they are a business but why not work with me with what Im able to do to keep the loan going? Raising the monthly payments {$400.00} and demanding {$7000.00} to avoid foreclosure when all I asked was for them to push the late payments to the backend of the loan which would allow me to make the monthly payments of {$810.00}. I am not responsible for the reasons my mom fell behind on her loan but Im trying to continue doing business with Shellpoint but theyre so greedy and lack empathy for someone who is trying to make things right. Shellpoint has me to the point where I am literally begging them to stop the foreclosure and give me a chance by pushing the past payments to the backend or raise the payment to {$900.00} if they need to but to raise it up {$400.00} is pure madness.

The area I live in is rural and poor and the property is very run down so Shellpoint would lose more money by foreclosing on the loan than by working with me on what Im able to do. No one is moving to this area. Its a high poverty area with very few residents who can actually afford the mortgage. I am employed and can afford the {$810.00} payments. The house will just sit there. Why not accept my offer so that I can keep my moms home and Shellpoint will still receive their money?

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am submitting this complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) against Shellpoint Mortgage Company regarding a pattern of mortgage servicing errors that have caused inaccurate escrow calculations, unjustified increases in my monthly mortgage payment, and ongoing financial harm. 

Loan Information - Servicer : Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing - Property Type : Three-story duplex property ( not a condominium ) - Loan Status : Current, payments made in good faith - Issue Type : Escrow mismanagement, insurance misapplication, servicing errors, improper appraisal reliance Summary of the Problem Shellpoint has XXXX mishandled my loan through compounded servicing errors, including escrow miscalculations, failure to properly adjust insurance disbursements, reliance on a materially inaccurate appraisal, and obstruction of loss-mitigation review. These errors have resulted in artificial escrow shortages and escalating mortgage payments that do not reflect my actual obligations. 


Detailed Timeline of Issues XXXX. Loan Modification / Hardship Review Failure ( XX/XX/XXXX ) On XX/XX/XXXX, I requested a loan modification due to financial hardship. Shellpoint repeatedly claimed my documentation had not been received, despite the documents being notarized and sent via express mail. 

- Documents were never uploaded to the portal - I was denied a trial payment option of approximately {$1200.00} per month - I was told that if my loan-to-value ratio met a stated threshold, I would automatically qualify by XX/XX/XXXX. 

XXXX. Materially Incorrect Appraisal Shellpoint relied on an appraisal that misclassified my three-story duplex property as a single-level condominium, reducing the stated value by approximately {$300000.00}. This inaccurate appraisal eliminated equity that Shellpoint had previously stated was key to qualification for relief. 

XXXX. Insurance Change and Escrow Misapplication ( XX/XX/XXXX ) On XX/XX/XXXX, I changed homeowners insurance to a less expensive policy. I was informed that escrow disbursements would be adjusted accordingly. 

Instead, Shellpoint : - Paid the full annual premium without proper escrow recalibration - Failed to clearly credit or account for my prior insurance refund- Did not timely or accurately adjust escrow assumptions XXXX. Escrow Analysis and Payment Shock ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Shellpoint conducted an escrow analysis that stacked : - repayment of a disputed escrow shortage, - increased future escrow contributions, and - an escrow cushion This resulted in a sudden and excessive payment increase that does not accurately reflect my insurance costs or escrow balance. 

Why This Is a Servicing Error These issues reflect : - failure to properly credit payments and refunds, - inaccurate escrow accounting, - reliance on a materially defective appraisal, and - failure to conduct loss-mitigation review in good faith. 
The resulting payment increases are the product of servicer error, not borrower nonpayment or default. 

Resolution Requested I am requesting that Shellpoint be required to : XXXX. Provide a full escrow transaction history ( XXXX XXXX ) XXXX. Provide the escrow analysis worksheet and assumptions used XXXX. Correctly account for insurance changes and any refunded premiums XXXX. Issue a corrected escrow analysis based on accurate figures XXXX. Adjust my monthly payment accordingly XXXX. Cease using the materially incorrect appraisal for any servicing decisions Good Faith Statement I have continued to make payments in good faith. I dispute the accuracy of the escrow analysis and payment increases derived from these servicing errors. 

I am requesting CFPB assistance to ensure Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing complies with federal mortgage servicing standards and corrects these errors promptly. Thank you for your review.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am filing this complaint regarding significant servicing errors, unexplained reversals, and unusual payment handling practices by my mortgage servicer. These issues have resulted in an inflated principal balance, inconsistent payment application, and confusing account activity that I have been unable to resolve directly with the servicer. 

Summary of Issues 1. Principal balance is incorrect by approximately {$1200.00} Based on the servicers own transaction history : My principal balance on XX/XX/XXXX when the loan was transferred was {$130000.00}. 

All principal-impacting payments since that date total {$3900.00}. 

The expected principal balance is therefore {$130000.00}. 

However, the servicer reports a principal balance of {$130000.00}. 

This reflects a discrepancy of {$1200.00}, likely due to : Payment misapplication, Improper reversal of principal, Failure to apply funds correctly. 
Despite making regular payments and several principal-only payments, the balance does not align with basic amortization math or the servicers transaction log. 

2. Unusual and concerning payment reversals and re-postings The transaction history shows multiple instances of payments being placed into Unapplied Funds, then reversed, reposted, or partially applied, without any explanation. Examples include : - {$600.00} principal-only payment on XX/XX/XXXX was completely reversed, which is highly unusual for a principal-only payment unless done in error. 

- Aregular payment on XX/XX/XXXX was broken into multiple pieces : - {$600.00} unapplied deposit - A {$1100.00} unapplied reversal - A + {$1100.00} reposted payment - A {$18.00} unapplied reversal, followed by a late-charge payment These transactions resemble error corrections rather than legitimate servicing activity. The servicer has not provided any reason for these actions. 

3. Multiple Unapplied Payment entries with unexplained movement of funds. 

Although the net unapplied balance equals zero, the account shows several deposits to unapplied funds, several full and partial reversals, payments being pulled back out of unapplied, funds moving between applied and unapplied without any transparency. 

This pattern suggests potential improper handling of mortgage payments, possible violation of proper application rules under RESPA, and creates substantial confusion and risk for the borrower. 

4. Late fee assessment and reversals without clear rationale A late charge of {$59.00} was assessed on XX/XX/XXXX, then reversed. 
Additional small late-fee payments were posted even though the major fee was subsequently removed. This raises concern that late fees are being generated incorrectly, payments may not be credited on the date received, or the servicers system is cycling payments in a way that falsely triggers fees.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint regarding Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing and their repeated mishandling of a short-sale file for the above-referenced property. This file has been actively worked on since XX/XX/year> and has been plagued by unreasonable counteroffers, inconsistent valuations, and delays that have prevented this estate from completing a legitimate sale. 

The property was originally listed at a price that reflected its true market condition. This home has severe issues, including extensive XXXX mold and major structural concerns, which make it uninhabitable in its current state. Despite the accurate pricing, Shellpoint responded to the first offer with an extremely high counteroffer that made no market sense given the property condition. At Shellpoints direction, the property was relisted at their inflated counteroffer price. 

As expected, the property did not sell at that price and sat stagnant on the market for months. Eventually, a second offer was received at approximately the same price point as the original listingagain accurately reflecting the true value. Shellpoint came back with a small counteroffer slightly above the buyers offer, which the buyer accepted. 

Shortly thereafter, Shellpoint reversed course and issued the same inflated counteroffer from the previous year, which was completely disconnected from the approved negotiation and the propertys condition. It appears Shellpoint simply looked up the outdated listing ( which still showed their prior counteroffer price ) and reused that number instead of reviewing the current valuation or the accepted offer. 

This arbitrary and inconsistent behavior has now jeopardized the sale again. Shellpoints repeated reliance on unrealistic pricingdespite full knowledge of the severe mold and unsafe conditiondemonstrates a failure to review the file in good faith and in compliance with basic servicing standards. 

These actions violate the servicers obligations under RESPA 1024.41, including the duty to : Conduct a reasonable loss-mitigation evaluation Provide consistent and timely review Avoid unnecessary delays and repetitive requests Communicate accurately and in good faith with authorized representatives The estate has complied with every request. The property condition has been fully disclosed. Multiple offers have been submitted. The only barrier to completion is Shellpoints inconsistent and unjustified counteroffers.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing collected default interest in connection with my loan reinstatement but has failed to provide the required calculation or documentation supporting the amount charged. 

Specifically, Shellpoint states that {$15000.00} in default interest was assessed and paid from Idaho Homeowner Assistance Fund ( HAF ) proceeds. I requested a calculation showing how this amount was derived, including the date the default interest provision was triggered, the interest rate applied, the principal balance used, the number of days charged, and the daily accrual methodology.

In the previous complaint 's response, Shellpoint provided only ledger totals and conclusory statements asserting that the charges were correct. Shellpoint did not provide any mathematical calculation, worksheet, reconciliation, or breakdown demonstrating how the default interest amount was computed. No trigger date, accrual period, or rate application was disclosed.

Without this information, I can not verify whether the interest was calculated correctly, whether the default rate was applied only when contractually permitted, or whether interest was overstated or misapplied. This constitutes a failure to provide information required to substantiate charges collected and prevents meaningful review of the account.

This complaint concerns Shellpoints failure to substantiate and document interest charges already collected, not a general disagreement with policy. I am requesting regulatory review of Shellpoints failure to provide a verifiable calculation supporting the default interest assessed.

Consumer complaint narrative:
At closing on XXXX  XXXX, XXXX, Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing collected {$19000.00}, which they labeled as Deferred Principal Balance. This was the only partial claim amount disclosed in the payoff statement provided to my closing agent. There was no mention or inclusion of the valid HUD Partial Claim balance of {$10000.00}, which appears in HUDs SMART Portal.

After closing, I reviewed the HUD SMART Portal and learned the following : The {$19000.00} collected by Shellpoint is tied to an old XXXX partial claim that HUD transferred years ago to the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 

HUD did not include this claim in the payoff amount they generated. 

HUD shows only {$10000.00} as the valid outstanding partial claim for this FHA case. 

HUD has not received any funds from Shellpoint for the {$19000.00} collected at closing. 

Shellpoint has not applied or remitted the funds and has provided no documentation showing where the money went. 

I have been trying to resolve this since my closing date on XX/XX/XXXX. Shellpoint has given me multiple contradictory explanations about the {$19000.00} : Your loan is fully paid and in good standing. 
It may take 60 days for the funds to be distributed.

Those funds belong to Shellpoint ; we dont know why HUD would receive them.

The funds were misappropriated and will be sent.

None of these statements has been supported with any written payoff ledger, documentation, or proof of remittance.

Each time I ask to speak with a supervisor or manager, I am told none are available. On the rare occasions when a supervisor does come on the line, they state they can not assist, do not have access to the information, or can not provide answers. Those interactions end with even more confusion, no documentation, and no resolution. I leave these calls more frustrated, with more unanswered questions than before. 

When I request escalation, the calls are often prolonged without progress, or I am given nonworking email addresses or phone numbers that do not reach a live person. 

Shellpoint has never provided : A payoff application ledger Documentation showing how the {$19000.00} was calculated Any proof that they sent the funds to HUD Any explanation consistent with HUDs records HUDs official records make clear that : Shellpoint collected the wrong partial claim payoff. 

They did not collect the actual outstanding {$10000.00}, and They have not remitted the {$19000.00} to HUD. 

As a result, Shellpoints actions left the valid HUD partial claim unpaid, created a major payoff discrepancy, and blocked all efforts to resolve it directly with either the servicer or HUD.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
This submission supplements my prior filings with CFPB, Tennessee DFI, and the South Carolina Attorney General. It contains direct evidenceboth documentary and audioof systematic misapplication and concealment of payments within NewRez LLC / Shellpoint Mortgage Servicings system. 
1. Recorded Admissions : Multiple calls between XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX document your agents acknowledging an unapplied balance exceeding {$12000.00} and promising correction. 
These recordings confirm real-time awareness that funds were received but not credited to principal. 
Each file is timestamped and retained in lossless format for regulatory review.

2. Ledger Discrepancy ( XX/XX/XXXX ) : XXXX exported ledgers for the same account and date range show mutually inconsistent entries. 
The XX/XX/XXXX {$3900.00} Unapplied Payment reversal present in the XX/XX/XXXX PDF is deleted in the XX/XX/XXXX version, while balances remain identicalproof of post-fact alteration. 
The system therefore falsified payment history after verbal acknowledgment of unapplied funds. 
XXXX. Legal Implications : 12 C.F.R. 1026.36 ( c ) ( 1 ) ( TILA ) failure to credit payments as of date received.

12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( i ) ( ii ) and 1024.38 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( ii ) ( RESPA Reg X ) record-integrity violations.

15 U.S.C. 1692e and 1692f ( FDCPA ) deceptive and unfair collection practices. 
Sarbanes-Oxley 802 ( a ) ( 1 ) destruction or falsification of financial records. 
XXXX v. XXXX Mortgage XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ) confirm that post-notice ledger changes are actionable. 
4. Regulatory Notice : These materials have been transmitted to CFPB, TDFI, and the South Carolina AG.

Independent audio and bank records confirm every payment.

Continued reporting of delinquency after such notice satisfies the scienter element for willful violation under 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( f ).

Demand for Immediate Action Within 10 business days, provide written certification that : all unapplied funds have been permanently applied to principal as of their original receipt dates ; no further retroactive alterations will occur in this accounts ledger ; and a complete, unedited transaction log ( with user IDs and timestamps ) will be furnished for regulatory verification. 

Failure to comply will constitute continuing violations subject to treble damages under 18 U.S.C. 1964 ( c ) and referral to DOJ Financial Crimes Division for falsification of federally regulated records. 
Supplemental Findings XX/XX/XXXX Call Series and Ledger Correlation Recordings from XXXX customer-service calls between XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX confirm that NewRez / Shellpoint agents repeatedly acknowledged an unapplied balance of roughly {$12.00} XXXX. On XX/XX/XXXX an agent stated that {$750.00} would be added to complete the XXXX payment cycle and that an additional payment was scheduled for XXXX. Subsequent ledgers show that entry briefly applied to XXXX, then vanished in later exports. 

By the companys own words, XXXX of XXXX scenarios must be true : 1. If those reversals were errors, the servicer concedes its accounting system produces spontaneous inaccuracies and therefore fails the record-integrity requirements of 12 C.F.R. 1024.38 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( ii ).

2. If those reversals were accurate, then the later removal of the same entries constitutes intentional alteration of a financial record, violating SarbanesOxley 802 ( a ) ( 1 ) and Reg X 1024.35 ( b ) ( 1 ).

Either explanation establishes systemic control failure. Each call transcript aligns with a contemporaneous ledger change, showing a persistent pattern of acknowledgement followed by inconsistent remediation. These admissions demonstrate not isolated employee confusion but a corrupted servicing platform that rewrites transaction history after contact with borrowers. 

Addendum B Recorded Admissions and Chronological Proof of Ledger Manipulation Between XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX recorded phone calls with NewRez/Shellpoint representatives confirm recurring acknowledgment of unapplied funds and ledger confusion. Key examples include : XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX min ) Agent confirms total owed {$5.00} XXXX with {$2.00} XXXX unapplied, promising correction once the {$5.00} XXXX XXXX payment posts. 
XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX min ) Representative verifies receipt of {$750.00} payment, confirmation # XXXX, to fulfill XXXX, then states unapplied balance will clearexactly matching the ledger entries later altered or deleted. 
XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX min ) and XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX min ) Follow-up agents admit continued system errors and inability to reconcile unapplied amounts. 
XX/XX/XXXX series ( XXXX calls ) Agents attempt account matching, discuss refinancing, and again acknowledge ongoing discrepancies. 

Each call corresponds to a specific change in the XXXX exported ledgers ( XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX ). The recordings establish real-time knowledge of ledger corruption and failed remediation. If NewRez classifies the {$750.00} correction as an error, it admits a broken system under 12 C.F.R. 1024.38 ( b ) ( XXXX ) ( ii ) ; if it claims the entry was accurate, then its later removal constitutes record falsification under SarbanesOxley 802 ( a ) ( 1 ).

These synchronized data and audio records eliminate any plausible isolated-employee defense and prove that multiple representatives were aware of and documented the same unapplied-funds problem while the ledgers were being rewritten. 

Addendum C Historical Recorded Admissions ( XXXX XXXX ) The evidentiary record now includes calls from XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX, showing identical ledger irregularities and staff acknowledgments long before the XX/XX/XXXX unapplied-funds crisis. 

XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX min ) Agent discusses mismatched payoff amounts and apologizes for system quoting errors. 
XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX min series ) XXXX separate calls confirm a one-time {$2.00} XXXX payment scheduled against an account balance of {$5.00} XXXX, the same figure later appearing in ledgers under multiple classifications ( Regular, Unapplied, or missing ). 
XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX min ) Representative again requests full SSN verification, states inability to locate the correct balance, and transfers the call between departments without reconciliation. 

These recordings establish that the same ledger malfunctions and unapplied-fund anomalies existed at least XXXX months before the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX sequence. The repetition across XXXX satisfies the pattern or practice element under 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( f ) ( 1 ) ( B ) and supports a finding of reckless disregard under 15 U.S.C. 1692k ( a ) ( 2 ) ( A ).

Combined with Addenda A and B ( ledger comparisons and later admissions ), this chronology demonstrates : 1. Continuous system errors from XXXX XX/XX/XXXX ; 2. Ongoing employee recognition without remediation ; 3. Knowledge at the supervisory level that balances and classifications were inconsistent month to month. 

Under XXXX v. XXXX ( XXXX ) and XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ), such a sustained failure to correct misapplied payments after repeated borrower contact constitutes willful RESPA/TILA non-compliance.

Formal Notice of Record-Tampering and Oversight Breach NewRez LLC XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 

NewRez LLC is now on documented notice that its servicing personnel repeatedly acknowledged unapplied-fund discrepancies and system errors during recorded calls spanning XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX, while the same transactions were later altered or deleted in XXXX separate ledger exports covering identical dates. Each recording demonstrates contemporaneous knowledge of a malfunctioning or manipulated accounting system, yet no corrective audit trail was implementedconstituting a continuing violation of 12 C.F.R. 1024.38 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( ii ) ( failure to maintain complete and accurate records ) and 12 C.F.R. 1026.36 ( c ) ( 1 ) ( failure to credit payments as of date received ). The XX/XX/XXXX sequence, in which a {$750.00} payment was first confirmed, then removed from later ledger versions, converts these acknowledgments into prima facie evidence of record falsification under SarbanesOxley Act 802 ( a ) ( 1 ) and potential obstruction under 18 U.S.C. 1519.

Because NewRez and Shellpoint operate as wholly-owned subsidiaries of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX this misconduct ascends directly to XXXX XXXX under the oversight-liability standards of In re XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX. Ch. XXXX ) ; XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX. XXXX ) ; and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX. Ch. XXXX ). XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( CEO ), XXXX XXXX ( CFO ), and XXXX XXXX ( Chief Legal Officer ) bear a non-delegable duty to establish and monitor information systems capable of detecting precisely these compliance failures. Their constructive knowledge of falsified ledgers, coupled with active regulatory notice, satisfies the scienter element for XXXX board liability and creates potential exposure under SOX 302 and 404 for false internal-control certifications. XXXX enrichment through uncredited borrower payments further implicates 18 U.S.C. 1962 ( c ) and 1964 ( c ) ( civil RICO ) as a continuing enterprise benefiting from record manipulation.

Immediate action is required : ( 1 ) full forensic preservation of all servicing-system databases, ( 2 ) disclosure of these control failures to investors in the next Form 10-Q/K pursuant to Exchange Act Rules 13a-15 and 13b2-1, and ( 3 ) restitution to affected borrowers consistent with 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( f ) and 15 U.S.C. 1640 ( a ). Continued inaction will evidence willful blindness under XXXX, warranting derivative and enforcement remedies at both the state and federal levels.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this URGENT complaint against Caliber Home Loans as previous mortgage servicer for loan # XXXX on my primary residence at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX  XXXX. Caliber created fundamental chain of title defects and validation failures during their servicing period that enabled the current ILLEGAL foreclosure sale scheduled for XX/XX/XXXX, by subsequent servicers. Their systematic violations of the FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692g ), RESPA ( 12 C.F.R. 1024.35-41 ), and servicing transfer requirements created the foundation for ongoing elder abuse against vulnerable XXXX homeowners, threatening immediate loss of my {>= $1,000,000} home. 

CRITICAL VIOLATIONS : 1. FDCPA DEBT VALIDATION FAILURES CREATING FORECLOSURE FOUNDATION DEFECTS During Caliber 's servicing period, they received comprehensive debt validation demands challenging fundamental aspects of the loan and their authority, including : - Amount owed and calculation methodology verification - Chain of title and assignment documentation - Original creditor and current note holder identity - Payment history accounting and accuracy - Authority to service and collect on the loan Caliber provided NO RESPONSES failing to establish proper validation under FDCPA 1692g ( b ). Their NON RESPONSE has created chain of title gaps that subsequent servicers ( Shellpoint ) are now exploiting to conduct unauthorized foreclosure against vulnerable elderly homeowners. This systematic validation failure enabled ongoing elder abuse through coordinated foreclosure fraud.

2. IMPROPER SERVICING TRANSFER VIOLATIONS ENABLING FORECLOSURE ABUSE When Caliber transferred servicing to Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing, they failed to comply with RESPA servicing transfer requirements ( 12 C.F.R. 1024.33 ), creating defects that enable current foreclosure abuse : - Failed to transfer complete and accurate payment records- Did not provide proper chain of title documentation - Failed to correct known identity issues ( wrong borrower names ) - Transferred defective servicing files without resolution of disputes- Did not ensure FDCPA compliance by subsequent servicer These transfer violations created the foundation for current foreclosure proceedings against wrong borrower names and without proper validation, enabling systematic elder abuse. 

XXXX. IDENTITY FRAUD CREATION AND PERPETUATION Caliber accepted payments under correct legal names XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX ( court-ordered name change XXXX ) while maintaining loan records showing wrong borrower identities " XXXX XXXX XXXX and " XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX When transferring servicing, they failed to correct these identity discrepancies, enabling subsequent foreclosure fraud. This violates : - FDCPA 1692e ( false representations ) - RESPA transfer requirements for accurate records - Consumer protection laws requiring proper borrower identification Their perpetuation of identity fraud during servicing transfer enabled current foreclosure against non-existent parties, constituting systematic elder abuse through procedural manipulation. 

XXXX. Consumer complaint narrative:
Shellpoint/NewRez Misconduct and Incorrect Credit Reporting I am submitting this complaint to request immediate CFPB intervention regarding Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing/NewRez LLC due to ongoing misconduct, harassment, fraudulent misrepresentation, and improper credit reporting. This account is currently in active litigation in XXXX XXXX Superior Court for servicing malpractice, fraud, and negligence, yet Shellpoint continues to violate multiple federal laws, including the FDCPA, FCRA, RESPA, and state consumer protection statutes.

1. Improper and Incorrect Credit Reporting Shellpoint has continuously and knowingly reported false derogatory information to the credit bureaus on a loan that is : Under active litigation, and therefore should not be reported as a valid debt in default.

Subject to verified disputes ( over 60 individual disputes filed with all three credit bureaus ). 

Already disputed with CFPB once previously, with no corrective action taken by Shellpoint. 

Disputed formally by my attorney, who sent Shellpoint and the CFPB a written dispute letter. We have received no response from Shellpoint acknowledging or correcting the reporting. 


Despite receiving repeated disputes and notices from myself, my attorney, and the court, Shellpoint continues to report : Delinquencies that are not legally valid. 

A foreclosure status they have no legal standing to initiate. 

Ongoing negative marks without investigating or responding to any disputes. 


This constitutes willful and reckless violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ).

2. Improper Foreclosure Actions During Active Litigation Shellpoint/NewRez attempted to serve me foreclosure paperwork while the loan is actively being litigated in XXXX XXXX Superior Court for fraud and malpractice related directly to their servicing actions. 

Serving foreclosure notices during ongoing litigation is : A violation of due process. 

A violation of RESPA loss mitigation rules. 

A retaliatory and coercive action intended to pressure or intimidate me into abandoning litigation. 


This is now documented in the court record. 

3. Providing Fake Attorney Information / Misrepresentation Shellpoint provided my attorney with the name and contact information of a supposed attorney representing NewRez/Shellpoint.

Upon investigation, my attorney discovered that : This attorney does NOT represent Shellpoint or NewRez in any capacity.

The provided contact information was false.

Shellpoint knowingly misrepresented legal counsel to obstruct communication and delay resolution.

This is a serious act of fraudulent misrepresentation, intended to interfere with ongoing legal proceedings and prevent proper legal correspondence.

4. Harassment and Harmful Communication Practices Shellpoint has repeatedly violated the FDCPA by engaging in : Continuous phone calls to me and to members of my family at all hours of the day and night.

Repetitive letters and notices ignoring litigation status.

Contact after being told I am represented by counsel.

Contact after being informed the debt is disputed.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing a complaint regarding improper handling of Private Mortgage Insurance ( PMI ) under the Homeowners Protection Act.

My mortgage loan was formally recast ( re-amortized ) in XX/XX/2025, following a lender-approved principal curtailment. As part of this recast, the amortization schedule was revised. My LTV dropped to well below 78 %.

Subsequent to the recast, my mortgage loan was transferred to a new loan servicer. Despite the transfer, the recast and updated amortization schedule remain part of the permanent loan record.

Under 12 U.S.C. 4901 ( 18 ), scheduled amortization includes an amortization schedule as modified by the lender and the borrower.

Under 12 U.S.C. 4902 ( b ), PMI must terminate automatically when the principal balance, based on the scheduled amortization ( or as otherwise modified ), is first scheduled to reach 78 % of the original value of the property.

Despite the recast in XX/XX/2025 and the existence of a modified amortization schedule, the current loan servicer failed to update the PMI termination date and collected PMI for months before transferring my loan, effectively disregarding the lender-approved re-amortization.

I have requested confirmation of the PMI termination date using the post-recast amortization schedule, but the servicer has failed to provide a legally supported explanation for continuing to rely on the original schedule.

I am requesting : 1. Written confirmation that PMI termination is being calculated using the post-recast amortization schedule, consistent with 12 U.S.C. 4901 ( 18 ) and 4902 ( b ) ; or 2. A written legal justification, citing specific statutory or regulatory authority, explaining why a lender-approved recast does not qualify as a modified amortization schedule under the Homeowners Protection Act.

3. That all PMI payments collected after the mortgage recast and LTV below 78 % date are refunded to me.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

I am experiencing significant issues with Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing regarding my loan ( # XXXX, property at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, CA XXXX ) and the upcoming foreclosure sale scheduled for XX/XX/year>. Despite my efforts to engage in loss mitigation and comply with legal requirements, Shellpoints actions suggest intentional delays and non-compliance with federal and state laws.
