On XX/XX/year>, my application was deemed complete, with an acknowledgment letter dated XX/XX/year>, granting foreclosure protectionyet the sale date persists. 
I called Shellpoint and received recorded confirmation that XXXX XXXX was assigned as my Single Point of Contact ( SPOC ) to handle my case. This violates RESPA 1024.40 and California Civil Code 2923.7, which mandate a dedicated SPOC. Her earlier email on XX/XX/year>, also instructed me not to contact her unless reassigned, further complicating communication. 
Additionally, XXXX XXXX XXXX, Shellpoints attorney, confirmed on XX/XX/year>, that my settlement offer was rejected and directed all inquiries to his office, yet Shellpoint has not resolved my NOE/QWR or provided a new SPOC. The lack of coordination, combined with the looming sale date, suggests Shellpoint is running out the clock to avoid mitigation, a potential dual-tracking violation under RESPA 1024.41 and Cal. Civ. Code 2923.6.

Ive sent certified letters and followed up diligently, but responses are evasive or nonexistent. I demand Shellpoint assign a proper SPOC, respond to my NOE/QWR, and postpone the XX/XX/XXXX sale until my application is fully evaluated. We are not seeking forgiveness or special treatmentonly the opportunity to make payments and avoid unnecessary foreclosure while recovering from documented hardship. I am scheduled to begin part-time employment in XX/XX/XXXX and will be able to resume regular payments at that time.

Consumer complaint narrative:
THE XXXX XXXX ( WEAPONIZED VERSION ) A Philosophical Indictment With Legal Citations You told regulators : NewRez has nothing to do with XXXX. 
You repeated it to the CFPB. 
You sent it to state agencies. 
You embedded it in responses designed to reroute complaints. 

Yet your own XXXX speaks differently. 
On camera. 
With no confusion. 
No hesitation. 

He says : Businesses in XXXX ( XXXX ) Our MSR perspective ( XXXX ) Our operating center in XXXX ( XXXX ) Our complaint trackers ( XXXX ) Our digital tools ( XXXX ) Our capital keeping that capital ( XXXX ) Two truths can not coexist when they are opposites. 
A company can not be both integrated and unrelated. 
A platform can not be unified and independent. 
A XXXX can not speak in the voice of an organization he supposedly is not part of. 

This is the paradox that exposes the lie. 



I. The Paradox as Legal Evidence of Deception Under federal law, a contradiction of this magnitude triggers multiple statutory violations. 

UDAAP Deception 12 U.S.C. 5531 ( a ) prohibits practices that mislead consumers or regulators. 
A representation is deceptive when it is material and contradictory to reality. 

You manufactured a parallel universe : The regulator universe where NewRez XXXX The public universe where NewRez = XXXX  platform voice Your CEOs statements constitute admissions against interest. 
Your filings constitute misrepresentations. 

UDAAP Unfairness 12 U.S.C. 5531 ( c ) : conduct causing substantial injury that can not be avoided by consumers. 
Consumers can not avoid an injury if the servicer hides who controls the platform. 

Misrouting Jurisdiction 12 U.S.C. 5536 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ) forbids entities from intentionally giving false information to alter, avoid, or obstruct regulatory process. 

This paradox shows deliberate obstruction : You used corporate fragmentation as a shield. 

FTC Act 5 Deception Standard Your statements must be truthful at the time they are made.

They were not.

Sub-product: Home equity loan or line of credit (HELOC)
Issue: Applying for a mortgage or refinancing an existing mortgage
Sub-issue: Confusing or misleading advertising or marketing
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am submitting this complaint regarding NewRez Mortgage and what I believe to be highly misleading, predatory, and harmful practices toward consumers. 

I applied specifically for a XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) for my owner-occupied two-family home. I have photographic proof of the product I selected. My credit was pulled, and the application moved forward as if everything were normal. However, when I later checked the status of my application, I discovered that NewRez had unilaterally switched my application to a full mortgage refinancea product I never applied for, never consented to, and have no interest in pursuing. 

At no point did NewRez disclose that two-family homes are ineligible for their HEL product. Instead, after the credit pull, a mortgage XXXX informed me that my property type automatically converted the application into a refinance. This means NewRez knowingly allowed me to submit an application they could not honor, pulled my credit, and then forced me into a completely different, higher-cost product without my permission. 

Had the company provided even a basic disclosure or warningduring the online application flowthat two-family homes are not eligible for HELs, I would never have applied. My credit would not have been harmed, and I would not have been steered into an unwanted refinance. The lack of disclosure appears intentional and financially damaging to consumers. 

In the current age of fast digital mortgage applications, companies know that consumers rely on accuracy and transparency. XXXX failure to disclose ineligibility upfront, combined with their practice of altering applications after obtaining credit reports, suggests a deliberate attempt to funnel consumers into more lucrative products under the guise of an innocent automatic change. This behavior is deceptive, harmful, and erodes consumer trust. 

I believe this process is predatory in nature, as it creates a scenario where consumers are unknowingly routed into expensive products they did not ask forafter their credit has already been impacted. Mortgage lenders should be required to disclose eligibility criteria clearly and obtain explicit consumer consent before modifying an application in any way. 

I respectfully request that the CFPB investigate XXXX practices, including their online application flow, product conversion logic, disclosure failures, and credit-pull procedures, to prevent further consumer harm.

Consumer complaint narrative:
To : U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs Loan Guaranty Service Regional Loan Center Subject : Complaint Regarding Servicing Error on VA Refinance Loan Dear Sir or Madam, I am writing to file a formal complaint regarding a servicing error that occurred after my VA refinance in XX/XX/year>. 

At the time of closing, I had a significant surplus in my escrow account. Shortly after closing, I received a check from Newrez clearly marked as an escrow account refund. Believing this was legitimately mine as an escrow surplus, I deposited and used the funds to pay bills. 

After I cashed the check, Newrez canceled it without notice, which overdrafted my account and caused severe financial hardship. My loan officer advocated on my behalf, and the servicing department then issued me a replacement check for {$7000.00}, acknowledging my financial hardship. 

However, Newrez has now reversed this decision and debited my escrow account, leaving me with an {$11000.00} shortage in property taxes. They are attempting to collect this balance from me, which I can not afford. This has dramatically increased my monthly mortgage payment through no fault of my own. 

This situation was entirely caused by a servicing error : The escrow surplus should not have been disbursed if it was needed to pay taxes. 
I acted in good faith, with no knowledge that the funds were not mine to keep. 
The servicing departments own actions created this financial burden. 
I respectfully request that the VA investigate this matter and assist in correcting the servicing error. Specifically, I am asking that : Newrez take responsibility for the escrow accounting mistake. 
My escrow shortage of {$11000.00} be resolved without further financial harm to me. 
My monthly mortgage payment be recalculated fairly, without penalizing me for the servicers mistake. 
I served honorably, and I entered into this VA loan in good faith. I should not be forced into financial distress due to an error by the loan servicer. 

Please advise on next steps and provide any assistance available. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
In XX/XX/XXXXXXXX  I reached out to Shellpoint for financial assistance with my loan. Shellpoint 's process is a year long process due to the poor management and communication. In XX/XX/XXXX I was informed that the loan was processed for a partial claim with FHA and I would be receiving documents in the mail to be notarized. Unfortunately, the notary agency they used is impossible to contact as the hold times are more than one hour long! Shellpoint was not even able to communicate with their agency to schedule signing of the documents and had to have the documents redone due to dates on the documents. In XX/XX/XXXX, I finally received new documents with a scheduled signing date, however, Shellpoint incompetently spelled my name wrong on all of the documents prompting me to call to alert them of this error. They argued until they finally decided to research their own documents to find that they had spelled the name wrong. They then stated they would make the correction and notify me. I called twice per month to check on the status of my account as I was still receiving collection calls and getting dumped into foreclosure during this process. My last contact with them was XX/XX/XXXXXXXX  where I thought it was odd I had not received any notification, I was told everything was approved and still waiting. XX/XX/XXXXXXXX  I received a collection call stating my account was delinquent! I was confused and asked their representatives over and over until the call was escalated to loss mitigation division. After hours on the phone, they finally noticed that they put my due date XX/XX/XXXXXXXX  and I was already late! The due date was retroactive and that due to that I was now late ; that there is nothing that can be done but I need to hurry and pay it immediately or I would be facing foreclosure as XXXX 's payment would be due in the coming days. 
They did not offer an explanation as to why they failed to inform me of my due date, but they were able to see that they did not allow me access to pay on my account until the day prior to calling me after I had reached out and was told to wait. 

I don't understand how a mortgage company can set a payment to a retroactive date 3 weeks prior and charge late fees and start aggressive collection tactics without any recourse to remedy their error.

XX/XX/XXXX the balance was paid in full and funded to Shellpoint. I received a notice that the balance was paid in full in XXXX XXXXXXXX, however, Shellpoint continues to report the account as delinquent and now approaching 90 days past due. I contested with the credit bureaus and also reached out to Shellpoint for assistance with updating my account. Their representative " XXXX  '' [ paraphrased name as she was eating and smacking ] continued to make up differing dates as to when they would update the status, stating " they still need to do some stuff up in yo ' account, prolly around 30 days ''. Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this escalated complaint against Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing for continued violations of federal and state laws in handling my mortgage loan, including a bad faith failure to provide a substantive response to my prior CFPB complaint ( ID : XXXX, submitted XX/XX/year> ). Despite the urgency of my situationfacing potential foreclosure and irreparable harmShellpoint has only issued a generic interim response on XX/XX/year>, stating they need " additional time '' without addressing any specifics or taking action to halt violations. This delay, now over 30 days since my original submission, exemplifies a pattern of bad faith avoidance, disregarding CFPB guidelines that expect timely resolutions ( within 15 days for initial responses and up to 60 days only for complex cases ). Their inaction risks escalating my financial harm and violates their obligation to respond meaningfully under CFPB oversight. 
Recap of Ongoing Violations ( Detailed in Prior Complaint ) : As outlined in my previous complaint, Shellpoint has repeatedly violated the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA ), 12 CFR 1024.40 and 1024.41, and California 's Homeowner Bill of Rights ( HBOR ) /California Civil Code 2923.6 and 2923.7. Key issues include : Refusal to Assign and Communicate via Single Point of Contact ( SPOC ) : Under 12 CFR 1024.40 and Civil Code 2923.7, Shellpoint must provide a dedicated SPOC for loss mitigation coordination. Since my pro per litigation began, they have refused direct communication with me, insisting I contact their attorney ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) instead. This violates my rights, as litigation does not waive borrower protections. On XX/XX/year>, my advocate attempted contact on my behalf, but Shellpoint again refused, heightening my risk of losing my home. 
Failure to Acknowledge Complete Loan Modification Applications : On XX/XX/year>, a complete loan modification application was submitted via my advocate. Shellpoint failed to provide written acknowledgment within XXXX business days, violating 12 CFR 1024.41 ( b ). This mirrors prior non-compliance with applications submitted in XX/XX/year> and XX/XX/year>, which were denied without appeal rights or proper evaluation. 
Dual Tracking Violations : Shellpoint continues pursuing foreclosure ( tentatively scheduled for XX/XX/year> ) while ignoring my complete applications, in direct violation of Civil Code 2923.6 and 12 CFR 1024.41 ( f ). This persists despite documented chain-of-title defects, improper denials, and my prior CFPB complaint ( XXXX ). 
Pattern of Bad Faith : On XX/XX/year>, I sent a demand letter ( via certified mail and email to XXXX ) requesting SPOC assignment, application acknowledgment, and a foreclosure pause, citing RESPA and XXXX. No response or action followed, demonstrating deliberate evasion. 

Evidence of Bad Faith in CFPB Response Handling : Shellpoint 's interim response on XX/XX/year>, was boilerplate and non-substantive, merely requesting more time without providing any updates, explanations, or interim relief ( e.g., pausing foreclosure ). Given the imminent foreclosure risk highlighted in my original complaint, this delay is not justified and appears designed to run out the clock, allowing violations to continue unchecked. CFPB guidelines emphasize timely and thorough responses to protect consumers ; Shellpoint 's approach undermines this process and my rights. This is not an isolated incident but part of a broader pattern, as evidenced by numerous similar consumer complaints against Shellpoint for unresponsive loss mitigation and regulatory evasion.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Issue: Applying for a mortgage or refinancing an existing mortgage
Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX : I received the denial letter regarding my request to assume the loan for my home due to divorce. 
- The reasons provided in the letter were : -- Insufficient Income for Total Obligations -- Insufficient income for Mortgage Payments- Additionally, via email the Mortgage Consultant at the company provided me the following information they said they got from underwriting : -- XXXX : out of scope ( beyond XXXX ). Capital Gains is unable to be used as it is not supporting a consistent level of trading activity. XXXX was {$84000.00} and XXXX was {$7600.00}. In order to use Capital Gains, first thing that must be documented is a two-year consistent cash flow. Decline for insufficient income for total obligations, insufficient income for mortgage payments. 
- These numbers only make sense if they didnt include my capital gains income at all in the consideration which is not how it is supposed to be handled according the XXXX XXXX or XXXX  XXXX  guidelines. 
- Specifically, XXXX XXXX  Guidelines for Capital Gains ( XXXX other income ) say the mortgage company is supposed to -- Use a XXXX average to calculate the monthly income amount and -- Use the Most recent two years of realized capital gains to calculate that amount- I also told them I have documentation that my realized capital gains income for XXXX has already exceeded my capital gains income for XXXX and that the assets supporting that income have also grown during that time as well. 
- Furthermore, Ive been making the payments on the house since XX/XX/XXXX per the divorce orders so clearly I can and have been able to afford the payments. 
- However, they never asked for additional documentation. I had provided them everything they said they needed to process the assumption up-front, and then they never asked for anything else. Even after I told them I had additional documentation that would resolve the issues they raised, they still went on to deny and close the application without giving me a chance to submit it. They told me I would have to reapply if I wanted the new documentation to be considered knowing that when I first applied for this assumption they told me they would get back to me within 10 days, and then didnt get back to me to start the process of the assumption for 4 months because they were so backed up. 
- That means they ignored current evidence in their decision, and made it based on an out-dated and incomplete record, in addition to mishandling the capital gains income in their calculations. 
XX/XX/XXXX : Sent a formal letter to appeal the of denial of my mortgage assumption by email to the emails their denial letter said to reach out to AND the email their phone customer service department had told me to send it to when I spoke to them that morning - Sent follow-up email on XXXX XXXX - Sent follow-up email on XXXX XXXX - Sent follow-up email on XXXX XXXX- They never responded to these emails XXXX XXXX : Then sent a copy of the letter by certified mail on XXXX XXXX - Tracking shows NewRez received it on XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX XXXX : I sent a separate letter asking for all the details and documentation used in the decision - Specifically asked for : -- Provide a full explanation as to why my application was denied, including but not limited to what requirements, rules or regulations my application supposedly did not meet, and the math that resulted in that decision. 
-- Disclose the additional information used to make your decision as stated in the denial letter : Our Credit decision was based in whole or in part on information obtained from an affiliate or from an outside source other than a consumer reporting agency.

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/year>, I experienced a significant plumbing leak in my home which required immediate mitigation and subsequent repairs. My insurance company promptly issued a repair check, which was double-endorsed and required to be sent to Shellpoint due to my mortgage account being delinquent at the time of loss.

Once Shellpoint received the funds, I was informed that an inspection needed to be completed before any repair funds would be released. I explained to Shellpoints Loss Draft Department that no repairs had yet been performed because the contractor required 50 % of the payment upfront in order to begin work. Despite this, Shellpoint insisted that an inspection must still occurseemingly to verify work that had not yet taken place.

After numerous emails and a phone call with a supervisor, Shellpoint changed its rationale, stating that the inspection was now required to verify that mitigation had been completed. This was a complete contradiction to the original reason provided. In a final effort to resolve the issue, my husband and I conference-called Shellpoint with the contractor. During that call, Shellpoint stated that if the inspection showed 50 % of the work had been completed, the remaining funds would be released.

In the meantime, and after enduring months of living in hazardous and uncomfortable conditions, we were finally able to fund and complete the floor repairs with previously released funds. On XX/XX/year>, an inspector came to the property and confirmed that 80 % of the repairs had been completed and recommended the release of {$16000.00} in remaining funds.

Shockingly, despite this report, Shellpoint only approved {$10000.00} for releasewithholding {$14000.00} without providing any clear or reasonable explanation. This makes no logical sense, given that only 20 % of the work remains.

This experience has left me deeply concerned. Shellpoints policy appears to : Penalize homeowners for being delinquent at the time of loss.

Delay access to critical repair funds, forcing families to live in hazardous conditions.

Create unnecessary bureaucratic obstacles, including repeated inspections, even when contradictory or unreasonable.

Provide no clear or consistent standards for fund release or communication.

This is not only unfair but potentially dangerous. These policies disproportionately impact vulnerable homeowners already under financial stress, and seem designed to profit off hardship by delaying disbursement and justifying unnecessary inspection costs.

I urge the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to investigate Shellpoints practices regarding loss draft fund disbursements, particularly as they relate to homeowners who are delinquent. Their current policies are not aligned with reasonable repair industry standards and fail to take into account homeowner safety and basic human living conditions.

Thank you for your time and attention to this matter.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have reached out to NewRez servicing multiple times regarding the escrow shortage that I paid to not have an increase in my monthly payment amount, but they increased my monthly payment anyways. They refuse to acknowledge their deceptive website that has caused a significant financial burden to me due to their lies and trickery. 

The Newrez website specifically stated that if I paid the escrow shortage then my monthly payment would stay the same. However, after I paid the specific dollar amount, they increased my monthly payment anyways very close to the same monthly payment amount if I had not paid the shortage. 

This is a clear UDAAP violation as they tricked me into paying {$3800.00} for the shortage and still increased my monthly payment amount by {$230.00} ( or another {$2700.00} over 12 months ). 

I want my monthly payment amount to be the {$2200.00} that NewRez specifically stated would continue to be my monthly payment amount if I paid the {$3800.00} escrow shortage. 

Additional details are noted below. 

My monthly payment amount was {$2200.00}. I understand my taxes and insurance had increased and that there would be a shortage. On XX/XX/year>, I logged into my NewRez account to view my account details to consider whether I should pay the Escrow shortage. Or, per NewRez, if I did not pay the shortage, my monthly payment would increase to {$2500.00} ( or {$290.00} more per month or {$3500.00} over XXXX  months ). 

On XX/XX/year>, the NewRez website specifically stated, Your taxes and/or insurance has changed which caused your escrow account to have a shortage of {$3800.00} for the upcoming year. You can make a true-up payment using the button below and keep your monthly payment at {$2200.00}, a {$290.00} monthly difference. ( I do have a screenshot of the website ). 

I paid the escrow shortage of {$3800.00} on XX/XX/year>. However, NewRez still increased my monthly payment to {$2400.00} ( or {$230.00} more per month ). 

I only paid the {$3800.00} because NewRez specifically told me that my monthly payment amount would stay {$2200.00}. 

This is a clear UDAAP violation and NewRez refuses to acknowledge or remediate appropriately. 

The two options NewRez presented to me were 1 ) do not pay the shortage and increase your monthly payment by {$290.00} per month to {$2500.00}, or 2 ) pay the {$3800.00} shortage and keep the monthly payment amount at {$2200.00}. However, they tricked me into a hidden 3rd option that no fully informed consumer would ever choose the hidden option 3 ) pay {$3800.00} shortage today AND increase your monthly payment amount by an additional {$230.00} to {$2400.00}. 

I would like NewRez to correct my monthly payment amount to the {$2200.00} that their website specifically advised me since I paid the {$3800.00} shortage they specified. Or, I would like my {$3800.00} to be refunded and will pay the monthly payment of {$2500.00} they advised would be my monthly payment if I did not pay the shortage. 

Thank you for your assistance.

But, of course, YOU CAN PAY UTILITIES - JUST NOT FROM ESCROW. In accordance with Section 7 of the Security Instrument, these costs may be collected by the lender and will be added to the total debt owed by the homeowner, not taken from the escrow funds.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Complainants : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Property / Loan XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, TN XXXX Servicer / Respondent : Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing / NewRez LLC Parent / Risk Owner : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
Prepared by : XXXX XXXX Date Prepared : XX/XX/XXXX Executive Title Systemic Accept-and-Freeze Payment Misapplication, Unapplied Funds Hoarding, Escrow Misallocation, False Delinquency Reporting, and Post-Bankruptcy Collection Request for Immediate Forensic Audit, Preservation, and Enforcement Referral QUESTION PRESENTED Whether Shellpoint / NewRez have systematically accepted borrower payments, reclassified them to unapplied/suspense or unassigned, withheld and redeployed unapplied funds across months ( including issuing partial refunds ), frozen amortization and escrow accounting, and continued collection/billing activity ( including mailed statements ) against a discharged co-borrower conduct that violates federal consumer-finance statutes and justifies immediate CFPB intervention, monetary relief, remedial orders, and referral for enforcement. 

Short Answer : Yes. The attached forensic record ( transaction screenshots, enhanced XXXX recorded calls, mailed statements, and a reconciled payment chronology ) demonstrates repeated, same-day reversals of valid payments, admitted unapplied funds, and ledger concealment consistent with systemic servicing abuse under Regulation Z, Regulation X, RESPA, FDCPA/Reg F, and Dodd-Frank UDAAP authorities.

FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS FORENSIC CHRONOLOGY ( Verified ) 1. Preexisting Condition ( XX/XX/XXXX ) : Account showed {$2000.00} unapplied ( suspense/unapplied ledger ). 
2. XX/XX/XXXX XXXX Payment : XXXX XXXX made {$5000.00} on XX/XX/XXXX. System records and portal evidence show {$2000.00} applied to clear the XXXX unapplied, with the remainder posted toward XXXX obligations. 
3. XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX  ) Supplemental Payment : A {$750.00} supplemental payment was posted ; on a recorded call the agent stated the loan was all paid up. 
4. XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX  ) XXXX Payment ( XXXX  Event ) : XXXX made a {$3900.00} regular mortgage payment ( allocation per portal/XXXX  : Principal {$840.00} ; Interest {$2500.00} ; Escrow {$520.00} ). Initially posted as a Regular Payment, the identical amount was later reclassified the same day to Unassigned / Unapplied.

After reclassification the principal balance did not decline ( remained fixed at {$580000.00} ), demonstrating frozen amortization. 
The portal thereafter displayed Past Due {$5000.00}, Late Fees {$1000.00}, and Escrow Deficit {$2700.00} despite the account being current per the XX/XX/XXXX XXXX  agent confirmation. 
5. XX/XX/XXXX Call Admissions : During the XX/XX/XXXX call a Shellpoint agent acknowledged ~ {$12000.00} in unapplied funds on the account and referenced a {$4000.00} check being issued and that XXXX payments would be dispersed from unapplied funds. 
6. Forensic Ledger Trace : Independent XXXX/XXXX extraction and ledger reconciliation from XXXX XXXX reveal significant additional reversals and reclassifications. When traced end-to-end ( including prior months and manual adjustments ), the manipulated/unapplied exposure exceeds {$100000.00} in borrower payments that were cycled through Shellpoints unapplied/suspense accounts and redeployed selectively far more than the $ XXXX the agent acknowledged. 
7. Escrow Mischaracterization : On XX/XX/XXXX ( and across XXXX ), substantial non-escrow transfers/entries ( ~ {$5000.00} ) appear in portal ledger fields that were not authorized escrow deposits by the borrower. After full payments ( XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX ), the escrow shortage should have been eliminated ; instead, the escrow remained frozen around {$2700.00}, evidencing diversion/misallocation. 
8. Bankruptcy/Portal Discrepancy : Co-borrower XXXX XXXX filed XXXX XXXX ( discharge XXXX ). Shellpoint revoked XXXX  portal access ( bankruptcy coding ) while continuing to mail billing statements listing both borrowers and demanding payment contradictory communications inconsistent with XXXX discharge protections and suggestive of improper post-discharge collection activity. 



FORENSIC INTERPRETATION Same-day reversals of full, contractually-valid payments ( XX/XX/XXXX XXXX  pivot ) and the portal-visible failure to reduce principal show manual reclassification not explained by system lag. 
Agent admission ( $ XXXX ) + ledger trace ( $ XXXX ) creates a material discrepancy demonstrating Shellpoints concealment of the full scope of unapplied funds. 
Selective redeployment ( agent said XXXX would be paid from unapplied ; $ XXXX check reference ) proves the unapplied pool is an active internal float used at Shellpoints discretion rather than a passive suspense queue awaiting correction.

Escrow misallocation and non-escrow entries show conversion or mischaracterization of borrower funds.

The overall pattern is consistent with a corporate servicing model that accepts payments, sequesters them, re-timings application, and manufactures arrears to extract fees and leverage collection processes.

From the beginning of this situation, when we were only {$10000.00} behind, we had the funds to pay the amount owed upfront. However, they refused to accept any payment. In order to make progress with them, we had to hire a third-party nonprofit organization, XXXX. Despite all of this, we are still on the verge of losing our home with nowhere to go. 

We want to request that Shellpoint honor the terms of our TPP/modification for 40 years at 2.5 %, as they were the ones who dropped the ball in this process. I am asking the CFPB for assistance for my husband, who is a veteran of the U.S. XXXX XXXX, and has worked hard to reach this point. The only reasons we fell behind on our mortgage were due to the COVID-19 pandemic and a severe XXXX that nearly cost him his life. We are able to continue making our current TPP payments. 

This situation has been ongoing for almost three years now. I sincerely ask for help from the CFPB.

Thank you for your time.ost three years now. I sincerely ask for help from the CFPB. 

Thank you for your time.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally complain about a discrepancy in the payoff amount for my mothers mortgage account. 

I recently attempted to pay the final balance through your payment portal to satisfy the mortgage and close the account. However, I was informed that an additional {$3000.00} is required to complete the payoff. When I requested an explanation, I was told that this included a force-placed XXXX forbearance for XXXX months ( April 2020June 2020 ). 

The notice I received stated : * Your monthly mortgage payment amount of {$430.00} ( XXXX = {$1300.00} ) was placed on a temporary forbearance for a period of 3 months. Starting on XX/XX/year> and for the next 3 months, there will be no late payment charges. * First, the math does not align with the additional {$3000.00} being demanded. The forbearance amount referenced totals {$1300.00}, not {$3000.00}. 

Second, this forbearance was neither requested nor agreed to. My senior mother, the account holder, was unaware of this arrangement, and I, as her point of contact, was never notified. The letter further stated that we were required to opt out to avoid the forbearance, which is an unreasonable expectation, particularly for an elderly customer who may not fully understand such communications. 

Third, regular mortgage payments continued to be made during this period, making the retroactive application of forbearance unnecessary and unjustified.

My mortgage journey began in XXXX with XXXX XXXX. Over the years, the loan was transferred multiple timesfirst to XXXX, then to XXXX, and eventually to XXXX XXXX XXXX  ( XXXX ). When XXXX assumed control of the loan, I was already disputing charges related to a foreclosure that XXXX had imposed, which I believe was unlawful. XXXX claimed they had no records predating their acquisition of the loan, making it impossible to verify or challenge the disputed charges. 

At the time XXXX took over, the account was in arrears. In XXXX, they offered to reinstate the loan with a reduced interest rate and a balloon payment due in 15 years. However, they added over {$100000.00} in back payments and fees. I repeatedly requested a detailed accounting of these charges, but XXXX maintained they had no documentation prior to their involvement. To this day, I have never received a breakdown explaining how they arrived at the reinstatement amount. 

In XXXX, during the financial hardship brought on by the XXXX pandemic, I contacted XXXX  out of concern that I might miss a mortgage payment. A representative informed me that under the CARES Act, I could pause payments temporarily. I asked how repayment would work and was told I would owe a lump sum once the hardship ended. When I expressed concern about my ability to pay a lump sum, I was reassured that the arrears could be deferred to the back end of the loan. This seemed like a reasonable solution, and I accepted the forbearance, missing approximately XXXX payments during the pandemic. 

Unexpectedly, in late XXXX, XXXX notified me that the forbearance program was ending and demanded full repayment of the arrears. I reminded them of the earlier promise to defer the amount, but they now claimed that option was never guaranteed and was no longer available. They threatened foreclosure if I could not pay the full balance. 

I then applied for a loan modification, submitting extensive documentation over several months. As it became clear that I could neither meet the lump sum demand nor count on approval for the modification, I felt I had no choice but to sell my home to avoid foreclosure. I did so reluctantly and am now without stable housing. Due to my financial situation, I am unable to qualify for another mortgage. 
My credit has been affected by this as well. XXXX reported my payments during the forbearance period as delinquent even though they should have been protected under the CARES ACT. I have reached out to them and requested a reversal, but they have not complied. 

I believe XXXX misled me regarding the terms of the forbearance and failed to provide the transparency necessary for me to make an informed decision. Their lack of clarity and refusal to honor prior assurances directly contributed to the loss of my home. I suspect I am not alone in experiencing this kind of deceptive treatment. 

Additionally, I have attempted to access my modification submissions and past correspondence, but their system uses secure links that expire quickly, preventing me from downloading or retaining any records. 

I am seeking guidance on whether any recourse exists to hold XXXX  accountable for these actions.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
Complaint Narrative Payment Misapplication and XXXX XXXX XXXX NewRez LLC / Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ) On XX/XX/XXXX, a full regular mortgage payment of {$3900.00} was drafted from my checking account for Loan # XXXX. However, by XX/XX/XXXX, the portal ledger suddenly changed : Unapplied Balance : {$0.00} Late Charges Balance : {$1000.00} Next Coupon Date : XX/XX/XXXX. 

The earlier {$3900.00} payment was effectively erased or reclassified, and my account was reported as due for XX/XX/XXXX despite prior confirmation that it was already satisfied. 

This constitutes a payment-crediting violation under : 12 C.F.R. 1026.36 ( c ) ( 1 ) ( i ) Failure to credit payments as of the date received.

12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( b ) ( 1 ) Failure to properly apply periodic payments. 

Shellpoint and its parent NewRez LLC ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) have repeatedly used unapplied and reversed transactions to fabricate delinquency status, creating false late fees and misrepresenting escrow shortages. My call recordings from XX/XX/XXXX, and XXXX confirm that representatives acknowledged duplicate funds and stated that {$8000.00} would be applied toward XXXX and XXXX payments with a {$4000.00} refund check to be issued within 10 days. That refund was never issued, and the extra payment vanished from the ledger.

XX/XX/XXXX portal showing payment removed and late charges added. 
Matching NewRez and Shellpoint pages reflecting the same principal balance ( {$580000.00} ). 

Requested Resolution : Immediate correction of the account to reflect payments through XX/XX/XXXX as current. 
Full refund or credit of the missing {$3900.00} and all related late fees. 
Written confirmation of compliance with Reg Z 1026.36 ( c ) and RESPA 1024.35 ( b ).

Copy of complete payment application ledger for audit. 

This pattern mirrors systemic misapplication practices already under review by the XXXX  XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX correspondence XX/XX/XXXX ) and should be treated as part of a broader servicing-conduct investigation. 


CFPB Complaint Narrative ( Follow-Up Submission ) Category : Mortgage Servicing / Payment Processing / Misapplication Company : NewRez LLC XXXX Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing Product : VA Mortgage What happened : This is a supplemental complaint expanding on my prior CFPB filings against NewRez LLC / Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing XXXX It documents the servicers failure to respond to a formal regulatory demand, continued payment misapplication, and false delinquency reporting following multiple acknowledged transactions.

Despite this, no written acknowledgment or substantive response has been received within the XXXX business days required under 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( e ) ( 3 ) ( i ). Instead, a generic customer service template letter was issued without addressing any specific issue or evidence. 

The companys own records and screenshots show : A {$3900.00} payment received XX/XX/XXXX, confirmed online as applied toward the XX/XX/XXXX due date. 
The following day ( XX/XX/XXXX ) an additional {$750.00} payment was processed, bringing the account fully current. 
By XX/XX/XXXX, Shellpoint altered its online portal to remove the XX/XX/XXXX payment, reset the due date to XX/XX/XXXX, and added {$1000.00} in late charges, effectively fabricating a delinquency. 

This manipulation of payment records violates multiple consumer protection regulations, including : 12 C.F.R. 1026.36 ( c ) ( 1 ) ( i ) Failure to credit payments as of the date received.

12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( b ) ( 1 ) Failure to properly apply periodic payments.

12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( e ) ( 3 ) ( i ) Failure to acknowledge written notice of error within five days.

12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( e ) ( 1 ) ( i ) Failure to correct or provide written explanation within thirty days.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Company : Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing Loan Number : XXXX Issue Type : Credit reporting / Mortgage servicing / Force-placed insurance I am submitting this follow-up complaint in response to Shellpoint Mortgage Servicings CFPB response dated XX/XX/2025. 

While Shellpoint acknowledged that force-placed insurance was no longer needed and confirmed that the related charges were reversed and reimbursed after I provided proof of continuous insurance, Shellpoint refuses to correct the resulting negative credit reporting. This refusal is causing ongoing and material consumer harm. 

Key Facts ( Not in Dispute ) : I maintained continuous property insurance coverage at all times. Shellpoint placed lender-placed insurance at the time they did not have proof of insurance for my property and charged it to my escrow. Those charges caused an artificial escrow shortage and a subsequent past-due balance. They reported a delinquency to the credit bureaus, that arose solely because of the now-reversed force-placed insurance charges. After I provided proof of insurance, Shellpoint cancelled the lender/force-placed hazard insurance, reversed the charges and reimbursed the amounts.. 

Ongoing Material Harm : Since Shellpoint has refused to correct the credit reporting, I applied for a mortgage refinance and I am at the risk of being denied due to the late payment attributed to Shellpoint 's reporting. Should I loan be denied, it will constitute an actual material financial harm, not a hypothetical concern.

Basis of Dispute : Shellpoint asserts that the delinquency was accurate at the time it was reported. However, this position fails to address that : - The underlying obligation was later determined to be invalid and reversed - Continuing to report a delinquency caused by a reversed duplicate insurance purchase is materially misleading, even if it was technically accurate at a moment in time Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) ), furnishers are required to reasonably investigate disputes and correct or delete information found to be inaccurate or misleading.

Shellpoints response does not explain how continuing to report a delinquency caused by a duplicate insurance purchase that has since been reversed, complies with its obligation to ensure the accuracy and integrity of furnished information, particularly where the reporting is now demonstrably harming me, the consumer.

I am attaching : Proof of continuous insurance coverage Shellpoints CFPB response Evidence of charge reversal Refinance documentation I appreciate CFPBs assistance in resolving this matter, as Shellpoints position leaves me with ongoing credit damage for an issue they have already acknowledged and corrected financially but not in my credit record.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Despite the withdrawal of foreclosure proceedings, foreclosure-related fees, inspections, and servicing activity continued. When I attempted to obtain documentation regarding the account, foreclosure counsel stated in writing on XX/XX/XXXX that documentation did not need to be provided to me because I was considered a non-borrower and unauthorized party, despite my status as a legal heir. A prior CFPB complaint was submitted but did not resolve these issues. Sub-issue: Trying to communicate with the company to fix an issue with the loan closing
Consumer complaint narrative:
CFPB Rebuttal to NewRez LLC Response Consumer Statement / Rebuttal : I respectfully reject NewRez LLCs response because it does not validate the debt as required by federal law and continues to ignore critical issues.

Failure to Validate Debt NewRez admits it will not provide the original promissory note, the name and location of the custodian, or the chain of assignments. This violates RESPA ( 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( e ) ), Regulation X ( 12 C.F.R. 1024.36 ), and FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692g ( b ) ), which require a servicer or debt collector to validate the debt and identify the current owner. 

Borrower Misidentification and Spousal Joinder Defect The Note lists only me, while the Mortgage lists me and my wife. This mismatch means the lien is defective under long-standing case law ( Carpenter v. Longan, 83 U.S. 271 ( 1872 ) ) and under Florida Constitution Art. X 4 ( c ) and 38 C.F.R. 36.4306 ( VA ), which require valid spousal consent for homestead mortgages.

Unclean Hands and Bad Faith By refusing to validate the debt but continuing collection and foreclosure threats, NewRez acts with unclean hands and in violation of federal law. A party can not enforce a debt it refuses to prove.

For these reasons, I ask the CFPB to recognize that NewRez has not satisfied its obligations under law, and to require NewRez to provide full validation, including : Original note and custodian certification, Recorded chain of assignments, Securitization records, and Corrected title insurance.

Until they do, the alleged lien and foreclosure activity are unlawful.

To reiterate : Reasons the Mortgage Contract is Void 1. Borrower Misidentification ( Material Alteration ) The Note lists XXXX XXXX while my full legal name is XXXX XXXX XXXX. 

Under UCC 3-401 and 3-407, signatures and names must match ; any material alteration voids enforceability.

Case : Carpenter v. Longan, 83 U.S. 271 ( 1872 ) the note and mortgage are inseparable ; if the note is defective, the mortgage fails with it. 

XXXX. Unauthorized Addition of Spouse ( XXXX XXXX as Co-Borrower The loan application ( Form 1003 ) showed only XXXX as borrower. 

XXXX was added later on the Mortgage and Riders without application, consent, or underwriting. 

This is fraud and a material alteration under UCC 3-407.

It also violates 38 C.F.R. 36.4306 ( VA rules requiring voluntary spousal joinder ) and Florida Const. Art. X 4 ( c ) ( spousal consent for homestead must be voluntary and consistent ). 

XXXX. Mismatch Between Note and Mortgage XXXX signed the Note ; XXXX + XXXX signed the Mortgage. 

This creates a split obligation the debt and lien dont match.

Under Carpenter v. Longan and UCC 9-203 ( b ), no enforceable security interest attaches if the underlying obligation is defective or mismatched.

4. Lack of Mutual Assent ( Contract Formation Defect ) Contract law requires a meeting of the minds.

Borrower names varied ; Luisas inclusion was neither disclosed nor agreed at application.

Under Restatement ( Second ) of Contracts 20 and UCC 2-204, this is no contract at all.

5. Duress and Coercion at Closing I attempted to sign By : to show agency capacity ; both I and Luisa were told we must sign exactly as written or the loan would not close.

This constitutes duress, voiding consent.

Case : First Texas Savings Assn v. Dicker Center , Inc., 631 S.W.2d 179 ( Tex. App. 1982 ) contracts signed under duress are voidable.

6. Failure of Consideration / Illusory Contract The lender provided no proof of actual loaned funds ; the Note itself was used as the asset to fund the transaction ( securitization/rediscounting ).

Under UCC 3-303 ( value ), there must be consideration. Failure of consideration voids enforceability.

7. Defective Title Insurance / Lender Knowledge of Defects Master Closing Instructions required a Title Commitment naming lender as insured and matching the Note/Mortgage amount.

Because of borrower mismatches and defective spousal joinder, the lien was never properly insurable as first lien.

Equity sees this as proof the lender knew of defects and acted in bad faith/unclean hands. Precision Instrument Mfg. v. Auto. Maint. Mach. Co., 324 U.S. 806 ( 1945 ).

8. Failure to Validate Debt ( Statutory Violations ) Multiple QWRs under RESPA, 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( e ) and debt validation requests under FDCPA, 15 U.S.C. 1692g ( b ) remain unanswered.

A party in dishonor can not enforce. Glazer v. Chase Home Finance, 704 F.3d 453 ( 6th Cir. 2013 ).

Continuing foreclosure threats without validation is bad faith and fraud.

9. Improper Assignments and MERS Registration NewRez admitted loan was placed into MERS with no recorded assignments when sold/transferred.

Florida law requires assignments to be recorded ( Fla. Stat. 701.02 ).

Courts have voided mortgages for lack of proper assignment. U.S. Bank Natl Assn v. Ibanez, 941 N.E.2d 40 ( Mass. 2011 ).

10. Violated Rescission Rights TILA rescission notices have been served. Under Jesinoski v. Countrywide, 574 U.S. 259 ( 2015 ), rescission is effective by notice alone.

Servicer dishonored rescissions by refusing to release lien or tender.

Under 15 U.S.C. 1635 ( b ), failure to honor rescission voids security interest.

11. Fraud in the Inducement Closing proceeded despite known discrepancies : borrower identity, spousal joinder, duress, and assignment irregularities.

Fraud vitiates all contracts. United States v. Throckmorton, 98 U.S. 61 ( 1878 ).

Summary : The mortgage contract is void because : Identity mismatches ( Michael vs. Michael Adam ; Luisa added post-application ).

Note and Mortgage parties do not match.

No true meeting of the minds ( lack of assent ).

Executed under duress.

Failure of consideration.

Servicer dishonor ( RESPA/FDCPA ).

Improper assignment/MERS defects.

Failure to honor rescission rights.

Fraud and unclean hands.

Under equity and law, this renders the contract void ab initio, the lien unenforceable, and all proceeds from the transaction subject to restitution and disgorgement.

Previous response on CFPB show that certified mail documents were received that have evidence such as the loan application from closing with only 1 borrower and promise to pay i.e. the note with only 1 borrower. This is explicit prima facie evidence of knowledge of defective contract. Also, know that the note and the mortgage are inseparable per Carpenter v. Longan. If the servicer is not able to verify their own documents for invalidity due to not having these documents or are attempting to enforce defective instruments after being made aware, this constitutes dishonor, lack of standing, unclean hands, and intentional fraud. 

Respectfully, XXXX XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, NY XXXX Phone : XXXX Email : XXXX Date : XX/XX/XXXX RE : Rebuttal to Shellpoint/NewRez Servicing Response Disputed Account History, Escrow Errors, Bankruptcy Violations, and Misapplied Payments Borrower : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX. 
Property Address : XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, NY XXXX To Whom It May Concern : I am submitting this rebuttal in response to the letter provided by Shellpoint/NewRez regarding the servicing of my mortgage loan. After reviewing their response, I dispute several statements, omissions, and inconsistencies that do not reflect the actual history of my loan, my bankruptcy proceedings, or the payments made over the years. This rebuttal outlines the errors and unresolved issues that require further investigation. 
XXXX. XXXX XXXX Was Not Unwound Shellpoint admits the XXXX confirmed cramdown was not unwound. A cramdown that remains in effect must permanently reduce the principal and interest as approved in bankruptcy court. Despite this admission, Shellpoint claims they continue servicing the loan under the original terms, which contradicts their own statement. The current reported principal balance of {$240000.00} in XXXX is inconsistent with the effects of a valid cramdown and nearly XXXX  years of payments. 
XXXX. Improper Increases During Active Bankruptcy Shellpoint does not address why they : Added principal and interest during an active XXXX  XXXX bankruptcy, Increased my monthly payment from approximately {$1000.00} to over {$6100.00}, Demanded an additional {$10000.00} in XXXX during the cramdown, and Changed loan terms without court approval. 

These actions violate the automatic stay, the confirmed XXXX  XXXX plan, Bankruptcy Rule 3002.1, and federal restrictions against modifying loan terms during bankruptcy without court permission.

3. Misapplied Payments and Incorrect Due Date Shellpoint claims the last full payment received was on XX/XX/XXXX, yet also states the account is only paid through XX/XX/XXXX, and the next due date is XX/XX/XXXX. These statements can not logically both be true and point to misapplied payments, potential suspense account activity, or internal accounting errors that artificially exaggerate delinquency.

4. Unexplained Escrow Balance and Shortage Shellpoint reports an escrow balance of {$62000.00} and an escrow shortage of {$24000.00}. These numbers are extremely abnormal for a single-family home and indicate major escrow miscalculations, missing disbursements, or incorrect projections. Shellpoint provides no explanation for how such unusually high deficits occurred, especially during periods where they were receiving trustee payments and the property was under the XXXX program.

5. Incorrect Claim of Incomplete Loss Mitigation Documents Shellpoints statement that they did not receive all required documentation is inaccurate. I submitted complete documentation multiple times via email, fax, and their borrower portal. This pattern of claiming incomplete documents is a known issue and appears to be used to delay or deny proper review.

6. Foreclosure Referral Is Based on Servicing Errors Shellpoint referred my account to foreclosure based on a delinquency that appears to result from their own servicing conduct, including misapplied payments, due date resets, escrow inflation, and improper loan adjustments during bankruptcy. This foreclosure activity should be paused pending a thorough audit.

Requested Actions : I respectfully request : 1. A full forensic audit of the account, including all payment history, escrow activity, trustee disbursements, suspense account activity, and loan adjustments from XXXX. 
2. Correction of the due date, principal balance, interest capitalization, escrow calculations, and any inaccurate credit reporting.

3. Immediate pause of all foreclosure activity until the investigation is complete.

4. Written clarification explaining why payments were not applied correctly, why escrow reached {$62000.00}, why the cramdown terms were not honored, and why loan terms were changed during bankruptcy.

Conclusion : Shellpoints letter does not resolve or meaningfully address the issues raised and contains several contradictions. I respectfully request a complete and accurate review of the account and a corrected response supported by documentation. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

o Whom It May Concern, I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate mortgage delinquency reporting related to my property located in XXXX XXXX, Florida. 

The property was severely damaged by Hurricane Ian ( XXXX ) and later sustained additional damage from Hurricanes Helene and Milton. Each of these storms was a federally declared natural disaster affecting XXXX XXXX, Florida, pursuant to the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act ( 42 U.S.C. 51215207 ) and corresponding FEMA Major Disaster Declarations. 

As a direct result of these federally declared disasters and their impact on the subject property, my mortgage servicer approved a disaster-related forbearance from XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX, during which mortgage payments were suspended under approved hardship and loss mitigation programs.

Despite this approved forbearance, the mortgage company reported the account as delinquent beginning in XX/XX/XXXX. This reporting is inaccurate and misleading, as it fails to reflect the accounts protected status during an active disaster forbearance period. 

Additionally, in XX/XX/XXXX, I entered into a loss mitigation agreement that includes deeding the property back to the mortgage company, confirming that the loan was being resolved through authorized mitigation channels rather than borrower default.

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq. ), consumer reporting agencies and furnishers are required to ensure that reported information is accurate and complete. Reporting missed payments during an approved disaster forbearance constitutes inaccurate reporting under 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2.

I respectfully request that you conduct a reinvestigation and correct or delete all delinquency, late payment, or nonpayment notations reported during the approved forbearance and loss mitigation period.

Enclosed evidence of federally declared disasters impacting this property includes : FEMA Major Disaster Declarations covering XXXX XXXX, Florida for Hurricanes Ian, Helene, and Milton Insurance loss documentation and/or adjuster reports confirming storm-related damage to the property Local, state, or federal disaster assistance correspondence referencing the subject property Mortgage servicer forbearance approval referencing disaster-related hardship Loss mitigation agreement executed in XX/XX/XXXX Please provide written confirmation once your investigation is complete and the inaccurate information has been corrected.

Sub-issue: An existing modification, forbearance plan, short sale, or other loss mitigation relief
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint regarding my FHA-insured mortgage serviced by Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing / Newrez LLC .

My issue concerns the companys refusal to honor FHAs Special Forbearance Unemployment ( SFB-U ) extension policy as outlined in Mortgagee Letter XXXX, Section II.B.2 and HUD Handbook 4000.1 ( III.A.2.k.ii ( A ) ( 1 ) ).

My SFB-Unemployment plan began on XX/XX/XXXX, which is prior to XX/XX/XXXX the effective date of HUDs revised loss-mitigation rules that removed SFB-Unemployment going forward. 

Under Mortgagee Letter XXXX II.B.2, FHA explicitly states that forbearance plans initiated prior to XX/XX/XXXX, shall continue to be governed by the loss-mitigation requirements in effect at the time the forbearance plan was initiated Servicers must not curtail such plans solely on the basis of the policy revisions taking effect on XX/XX/XXXX. 

The prior rule, HUD Handbook 4000.1 ( III.A.2.k.ii ( A ) ( 1 ) ), provides for a re-employment period of up to 12 months under an SFB-Unemployment plan. 

Because my plan began before XX/XX/XXXX, I am grandfathered under the 12-month policy. However, Shellpoint/Newrez has repeatedly told me that my unemployment forbearance can not be extended beyond six months, contrary to FHA policy .

Timeline of my actions : XX/XX/XXXX My FHA unemployment forbearance plan began. 
XXXX XX/XX/XXXX I contacted Shellpoint several times by phone to confirm that I could extend up to 12 months. Multiple representatives and one scheduled loss mitigation appointment confirmed I would be eligible for monthly extensions through 12 months as long as I remained unemployed. 
XX/XX/XXXX I received an email from a Shellpoint representative ( XXXX  XXXX XXXX ) stating that my forbearance would end after six months ( end of XXXX ), citing maximum 6 months allowed.

I replied explaining that FHA policy allows 12 months for plans started before XX/XX/XXXX, and that both HUD and Shellpoint staff had confirmed this earlier. 
XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX I attempted to reach a manager multiple times by phone ; I was transferred and disconnected after long holds. 
I also sent follow-up emails to XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX ( the latter was returned as undeliverable ).

I contacted HUDs National Servicing Center ( via XXXX ). They replied that my inquiry was forwarded but they can not act due to the current federal government shutdown.

CFPB v. PHH Mortgage Corp., 2014-CFPB-0002 ( finding reallocation of timely payments deceptive ).

2. 12 C.F.R. 1024.38 ( b ) ( 3 ) ( i ) Failure to maintain accurate records.

Screenshots prove simultaneous public and internal ledgers with conflicting payment data.

3. 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( b ) ( 11 ) Failure to correct servicing errors relating to application of payments.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) Furnishing false delinquency information to credit bureaus.

5. 12 U.S.C. 5531 ( a ) Unfair and deceptive acts and practices ( UDAP ).

By zeroing unapplied funds and resurrecting the same amount as late fees, Shellpoint created an illusory default to justify foreclosure.

Hodges v. NewRez LLC, No. 1:22-cv-03025 ( D.Md. 2022 ) servicer failed to apply payments, initiated wrongful foreclosure.

Richards v. NewRez LLC, No. 4:24-cv-00491 ( S.D.Tex. 2024 ) borrower records show funds classified as fees instead of credits.

CFPB Enforcement File XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) used as precedent ; identical ledger reallocation scheme deemed systemic error. 

Your metadata trail mirrors these patterns : disappearing payments, duplicated late fee values matching prior unapplied credits, and portal totals that shift after consumer complaints.

Escrow deficits of {$3400.00} {$2700.00} fabricated by internal reallocation.

The identical reclassification patterns, matching dollar signatures, and reactive timing following regulatory complaints establish intent rather than error. 

Requested Action : Immediate joint CFPB-TDFI investigation into NewRez/Shellpoints payment-application systems and referral to the DOJ Consumer Protection Branch for potential violations of 18 U.S.C. 1005 ( False Entries in Bank Records ).

Consumer complaint narrative:
Although the complaint category I selected referenced financial hardship, the core issue here is that the mortgage servicer and foreclosure attorney have repeatedly violated my legal rights under the FDCPA, RESPA, and CFPB servicing rules. 

I submitted multiple debt validation requests via certified mail, asking for basic, lawful documentation : name and address of the current creditor, original note, payment history, chain of title, assignments/securitization details, legal authority to collect, and a breakdown of all charges and fees. 

Despite confirming receipt, they refused to provide the requested information, continued foreclosure actions while the loan is under dispute, and even claimed I wasnt entitled to the documentation I had lawfully requested, which is flatly false under 15 U.S.C. 1692g and 12 CFR 1024.41. 

In addition to this failure, representatives came to my private home on two separate occasions, XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/year>, to tape foreclosure warnings to my door. The foreclosure attorney later admitted only one such notice is required by law ( Utah Code 57125 ( 1 ) ( b ) ), meaning the second visit was unnecessary and served no legal purpose. This repeated conduct caused emotional distress for my family and constitutes a clear pattern of harassment, intimidation, and public shaming. 

I was fully engaged in communication with both Shellpoint and the attorneys office throughout this time, including notifying them of my CFPB complaint, and they still proceeded as if my legal rights and dispute process meant nothing. 

I am respectfully asking that the CFPB investigate this further, as my lawful request for validation was dismissed, I was misled about my rights, and my family has been subjected to repeated and escalating abuse of process during a time we were actively seeking legal clarity.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I paid off my HELOC in full on XX/XX/XXXX in connection with the sale of my home at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, FL. A single payoff wire in the amount of {$200000.00} was sent per the payoff quote, and the principal balance was reduced to zero with all accrued interest satisfied. 

After the loan was paid in full and after I no longer owned the property, Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing assessed lender-placed flood insurance charges and other administrative and third-party fees. These charges were not disclosed in the payoff quote and were assessed months after payoff. I was not notified in advance that such charges would be placed, nor was I advised that failure to take additional action would result in post-payoff insurance or fees. 

In XX/XX/XXXX, I formally disputed these charges in writing and requested closure of the HELOC retroactive to XX/XX/XXXX. Since that time, Shellpoint has reversed a portion of the lender-placed insurance charges, implicitly acknowledging servicing errors. However, Shellpoint continues to maintain a remaining fee-only balance of approximately {$730.00} and has not closed the account.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am submitting this complaint regarding my mortgage servicer, Newrez LLC, for its prolonged and unreasonable failure to process my request for removal of Private Mortgage Insurance ( PMI ), despite my compliance with all requested requirements and despite multiple written acknowledgments by Newrez confirming receipt of my documentation and appraisal fee. 

Borrower ( s ) : XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Servicer : Newrez LLC Property Address : Loan Number : I initially requested PMI removal in XX/XX/year>, based on improvements made to the property and anticipated loan-to-value eligibility. As part of this process, and at Newrezs direction, I provided a detailed list of property improvements and submitted a {$150.00} appraisal/XXXX  fee. 

Despite this, Newrez failed to timely act on my request. Over the ensuing months, I followed up multiple times due to the absence of any scheduled appraisal or written determination. 

On XX/XX/year>, Newrez issued a written response acknowledging : Receipt of the {$150.00} XXXX  fee on XX/XX/year>, and Receipt of my signed PMI removal form and list of improvements on XX/XX/year>, Stating that the request had been submitted to its Mortgage Insurance Department and advising that processing could take up to 30 business days. 

Subsequently, on XX/XX/year>, Newrez issued another letter confirming again that it had received the list of improvements and the appraisal fee, yet stating that the PMI cancellation request remains under review, without providing a decision, appraisal date, or explanation for the continued delay. 

As of the date of this complaint : No appraisal has been scheduled or completed, despite payment of the required fee. 

No written approval or denial of PMI removal has been issued. 

PMI continues to be assessed on my account. 

The request has been pending for many months, far exceeding reasonable servicing timelines. 

Newrezs repeated acknowledgments without action demonstrate a failure to properly process my request and a breakdown in mortgage servicing obligations. The continued delay has caused ongoing financial harm, including unnecessary PMI charges and the unresolved use of my paid appraisal fee. 

I believe Newrezs conduct is inconsistent with the Homeowners Protection Act ( HPA ) and federal mortgage servicing standards requiring timely, accurate, and responsive handling of borrower requests. 

Requested Resolution : Immediate scheduling and completion of the appraisal ( or written confirmation that it is no longer required ). 

Prompt written determination of PMI eligibility and removal. 

Retroactive termination of PMI effective as of the date eligibility was met. 

Refund or credit of any PMI premiums improperly charged after eligibility. 

Refund of the {$150.00} appraisal/XXXX  fee if the appraisal is not completed. 

Copies of Newrezs correspondence dated XX/XX/year> and XX/XX/year>, as well as recent mortgage statements showing continued PMI charges, are available and can be provided upon request. 

Thank you for your assistance. I respectfully request the CFPBs intervention to ensure timely resolution and compliance with federal consumer protection requirements. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint regarding remaining fees and charges assessed on my mortgage loan by Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ( NewRez LLC ), Loan No. XXXX, following Shellpoints recent admission that it improperly overcharged default interest on my account. 

In a prior CFPB response dated XX/XX/year>, Shellpoint formally acknowledged that default interest was incorrectly assessed for the months of XXXX, XXXX, and XX/XX/year> and waived {$10000.00} as a result. I appreciate that correction. However, Shellpoint did not address or substantiate several other charges assessed during the same hardship and assistance period, which remain unresolved. 

Specifically, Shellpoint assessed and collected multiple property inspection fees during a documented hardship period when : I had communicated financial hardship, a XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX application was pending, Shellpoint was instructed to coordinate with XXXX, no foreclosure activity had been initiated, and the loan was ultimately reinstated through state assistance. 

Shellpoint has not explained : why property inspections were necessary under these circumstances, what condition or risk justified repeated inspections, how frequently inspections were conducted and why, or how these inspections complied with the mortgage documents requirements that such fees be reasonable and necessary to protect the lenders interest. 

In addition, Shellpoint applied small late charges and inspection-related fees during internal reallocation of funds following the default-interest correction, without explaining why any such charges remained appropriate given the admitted servicing error, the pending assistance review at the time, and the subsequent reinstatement of the loan. 

Despite multiple prior inquiries, Shellpoint has not provided documentation or justification addressing the necessity, frequency, and contractual basis for these remaining charges. This prevents me from verifying whether the charges were appropriate or compliant with servicing obligations. 

This complaint does not dispute Shellpoints right to assess fees generally, but rather their failure to substantiate and justify inspection fees and related charges assessed during a hardship and assistance period, particularly after acknowledging servicing errors on the same account.

I am requesting regulatory review of Shellpoints assessment of these charges and Shellpoints failure to provide documentation demonstrating that they were necessary, reasonable, and properly applied.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative:
After getting behind on my mortgage my home loan was sold to Shellpoint. I paid off the legal fees and missed payments and got out of foreclosure, and since them I've been making my payments on time yet I've accrued many months of missed payments and associated late fees. It seems to me that there is a processing error on Shellpoint 's part of which I have never been notified, and I am finding it impossible to pay them the amount that I owe. 

Last month I twice tried to pay off the outstanding payments. The first time ( XX/XX/XXXX ) I assumed I had cleared up the problem by paying {$5300.00}. I noticed, however, that my " regular monthly payment '' had increased to reflect the amount that I owed in late fees, as opposed to my agreed upon monthly payment of {$1700.00}. Ten days later I noticed the balance hadn't changed. I once again ( XX/XX/XXXX ) attempted to pay off the balance and once again I assumed that I had settled the problem. 

Today ( XX/XX/XXXX ) I received a notification that {$6900.00} was going to post to my account and logged in to see that my payment history indicated immediate refunds of the amounts I had paid when they originally posted and did NOT deduct them from the supposed balance I had accrued despite my having been up to date on my monthly payments. 

I am now trying to pay and receive an error message and they won't accept any amount in payment. I can not figure out why they won't post my payments to my account and it feels as if there is a predatory ignorance that will result in the foreclosure of my home. 

Additionally their customer service phone number is entirely automated, with the option to speak to a representative hidden behind a many seconds long pause at the end of a many options long automated menu. Other options that intuitively feel like they'd lead to a representative instead g to extremely unhelpful dead ends. For example there's an option for the phone system to tell you a phone number to call for customer service which happens to be the number you called in order to hear that bit of information. Combined with the opaque payment process and lack of transparency in servicing my loan, the walls that are put up through the customer service process makes the whole system feel designed to interfere with one 's ability to pay their mortgage on time, ultimately ending in foreclosure due to corporate incompetence. Please help me.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint to address the improper reporting of a mortgage account that does not belong on my personal credit profile. 

XXXX  is currently reporting a mortgage account under the name XXXX with a balance of over {$4.00} XXXX and a past due amount of over {$130000.00}. This mortgage was never a personal obligation. It originated as a commercial mortgage issued to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, a business entity, and was handled entirely under that business structureincluding during recent bankruptcy proceedings. 

I am not personally liable for this loan, the bankruptcy court confirmation order confirms that the loan was treated as a business debt. Furthermore, the XX/XX/year> payoff letter from the servicer ( Shellpoint Mortgage ) clearly shows that XXXX XXXX, XXXX is the borrowernot me as an individual. 

Despite all this, XXXX  has listed this commercial account as a personal mortgage under my name, with derogatory payment information. This is false, harmful, and misleading. There is no court order, assignment, or legal justification for this reclassification. It appears to be a result of a data handling error by either the mortgage servicer or XXXX. 

This misreporting is a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ), which requires XXXX  to maintain procedures to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer data. It may also involve violations of the Furnisher Rule under Regulation V, which governs the accuracy of information supplied to CRAs. 

I am requesting the CFPB to review this matter and hold the responsible parties accountable for misreporting a business debt as a personal obligation. I have supporting documentation showing that the account belongs to a business entity and that no valid legal process exists assigning it to me personally. 

Thank you for your assistance in correcting this harmful error.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Sub-issue: Trying to communicate with the company to fix an issue while managing or servicing your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint against Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing for deliberate concealment, procedural violations, and direct harm related to my full mortgage reinstatement payment made on XX/XX/year>. 

On that date, Shellpoint representative XXXX XXXX confirmed on a recorded call that my {$17000.00} wire payment was received in full and ahead of the XX/XX/XXXX reinstatement quote deadline. I requested written confirmation that the XX/XX/XXXX foreclosure auction was canceled and my loan was current. XXXX XXXX stated I had to submit a written request, which I did on XX/XX/XXXX via a Qualified Written Request ( QWR ). Since then, Shellpoint has sent only six ( 6 ) identical acknowledgment form letters and has never provided the required written confirmation. 

In a XX/XX/XXXX recorded call, Shellpoint representative XXXX confirmed I was approved for a XXXX forbearance extension and that no adverse credit reporting would occur. This was reaffirmed in recorded calls on XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX adding each time I would receive a new reinstatement quote in the next few days. Yet on XX/XX/XXXX, when I called about the new reinstatement quote, representative XXXX XXXX blindsided me with the first-ever notice that foreclosure had already been initiated and a sheriffs sale was set for XX/XX/XXXX. She also disclosed again for the first time a new reinstatement quote dated XX/XX/XXXX, just over a week after my last call with XXXX. I had never received this quote in the mail or by any prior communication, and the letter itself made no mention of the foreclosure action already underway. 

Had I not called on XX/XX/XXXX, I believe I would never have been informed of the foreclosure sale or the updated reinstatement amount. This deprived me of my statutory right to cure and is consistent with a pattern of deceptive, non-compliant servicing practices. Because Shellpoint failed to promptly notify their foreclosure attorneys, I was also forced to contact the firm myself to halt the XX/XX/XXXX sale after learning on XX/XX/XXXX from the sheriffs office that the auction was still publicly listed and scheduled. 

Shellpoints actions have caused ongoing credit damage, legal threats from another lienholder, financial loss, and extreme emotional distress, compounding the financial trauma and emotional stress Ive endured as a XXXXXXXX XXXX  XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and my home. 

( Full complaint letter and supporting evidence are attached. )
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

We believe we have been subjected to predatory lending practices. We originally financed our home in XXXX and later refinanced it in the aftermath of the XXXX market crash to reduce our monthly payments. At that time, lenders were expected to assist homeowners by refinancing at fair market value. 

Despite paying on this mortgage for over 20 years, the numbers simply do not make sense. The home was purchased for {$280000.00} with a {$30000.00} down payment, resulting in a finance balance of {$250000.00}. Yet our current payoff amount still shows a balance of {$240000.00}. There is also a debit charge of {$81000.00} on the loan. According to the lender, after two decades of payments, only {$14000.00} has gone toward the principal. 

XXXX XXXX serviced the mortgage at the time of origination and refinancing. Shellpoint Mortgage Company now holds the loan. We are asking for help in resolving this situation.
