Sub-issue: Trying to communicate with the company to fix an issue related to modification, forbearance, short sale, deed-in-lieu, bankruptcy, or foreclosure
Consumer complaint narrative:
In XXXX, we applied for a mortgage forbearance with Shellpoint due to a loss in employment. At the time of application, we were advised that our post-forbearance payment would reflect a significantly lower interest rate and that any missed payments during forbearance would be added to the back of the loan and not treated as delinquent or immediately due. We relied on these representations when entering forbearance.

Since then, Shellpoint has failed to provide written confirmation of the forbearance terms and has given inconsistent and conflicting information regarding our loan status, payment amounts, and next steps. Payments, fees, and interest appear to have been applied in a manner that does not align with what was communicated to us. 

We have made numerous attempts to resolve these issues through scheduled calls and escalations dating back to XXXX. Multiple appointments were missed by Shellpoint without notice or follow-up. On XX/XX/XXXX, we specifically requested escalation due to the lack of resolution. During that call, we were advised that a supervisor had been contacted and that we would receive a callback at approximately XXXXXXXX XXXX. No call or follow-up email was ever received. We were also informed that representatives are not permitted to send follow-up emails, preventing us from obtaining written confirmation of our loan terms or escalation requests.

Most concerning, despite being in forbearance and actively seeking resolution, we were sent pre-foreclosure paperwork by mail. Receiving pre-foreclosure notices under these circumstances has caused significant confusion and distress and raises serious concerns about improper servicing and loss-mitigation handling.

As a result of these repeated communication failures and servicing inconsistencies, we remain unable to clearly understand our loan status or resolve the account despite repeated good-faith efforts.

Consumer complaint narrative:
CFPB Complaint Improper Disclosure of Another Borrowers Financial Information by Shellpoint Subject : Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing sent me a letter that contained another borrowers personal and financial information, including foreclosure-related details. 

Summary of the Issue On XX/XX/XXXX, I received a mailed response from Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing regarding my loan. Inside the same envelope, physically folded together with my letter, Shellpoint included a complete compliance letter for a different borrower. This other letter contained the borrowers full name, address, loan details, foreclosure reinstatement status, exact payment amount, and dates of financial activity. I have no connection to this individual. 

This is an unauthorized disclosure of non-public personal information, in violation of : Regulation P ( 12 C.F.R. 1016 ) Privacy of Consumer Financial Information GrammLeachBliley Act ( GLBA ) Safeguards Rule and Privacy Rule RESPA Regulation X failure to maintain accurate servicing records UDAAP prohibitions unfair and irresponsible servicing practices Details of the Disclosure Shellpoint mailed a letter addressed to me summarizing their review of my disputes. When I opened the envelope, a second letter fell out. That second letter is addressed to Estate of XXXX XXXX XXXX / XXXX XXXX XXXX and includes : homeowner name property address foreclosure reinstatement information the reinstatement payment amount : {$9800.00} the date received : XX/XX/XXXX the foreclosure status and application of funds internal Shellpoint servicing assessments All this information was physically provided to me without authorization. 

Consumer Harm and Risks Receiving another persons detailed mortgage and foreclosure information demonstrates that Shellpoint has failed to safeguard customer data and may be mishandling internal servicing operations. This raises serious concerns regarding : 1. Data privacy breaches 2. Document-handling failures 3. Potential cross-contamination of servicing records 4. Accuracy of my own loan information 5. Whether my loan is being serviced correctly or securely This disclosure occurred during an active dispute involving inaccurate ledgers, conflicting escrow data, and unapplied funds, which makes this breach even more concerning. 

Requested CFPB Action I am requesting that the CFPB : 1. Investigate Shellpoints failure to protect nonpublic personal information under Regulation P and GLBA. 
2. Review Shellpoints document-handling practices that allowed another borrowers confidential foreclosure information to be mailed to me. 
3. Require Shellpoint to confirm whether any of my information has been improperly disclosed to other borrowers.

4. Require Shellpoint to provide a compliant, accurate, and complete servicing history for my loan, as required under RESPA Regulation X.

5. Determine whether Shellpoints actions constitute unfair or abusive practices under UDAAP. 

Attached Evidence I can provide photos of the envelope and both letters exactly as received, showing the other borrowers financial records included with my correspondence. 

Governance Liability and Supervisory Failure Under Delaware Law, XXXX, XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX Because XXXX XXXX XXXX is organized under Delaware law, its board of directors and senior leadership owe fiduciary duties of care, loyalty, good faith, and oversight under Delawares well-established governance framework. The systemic failures documented in Shellpoint and NewRezs servicing operations including the privacy breach where another borrowers foreclosure letter was sent to me, contradictory ledgers, conflicting escrow data, and unresolved Notices of Error fall squarely within Delawares oversight-liability doctrine. 

Delaware courts have repeatedly held that a board must actively oversee mission-critical business functions, and failure to do so creates liability. Mortgage servicing is a mission-critical function for XXXX and its subsidiaries. The failures documented here constitute clear red flags under Delaware jurisprudence. 



1. Delaware Oversight Liability Under XXXX In In re XXXX XXXX XXXX. Derivative Litigation, the Delaware XXXX XXXX established that directors breach their fiduciary duty to act in good faith when they : Fail to implement adequate reporting, information, and compliance systems ; Ignore obvious signs of regulatory or operational failure ; or Permit systemic breakdowns in mission-critical systems. 

Shellpoint mailing another borrowers financial and foreclosure documents to me is a textbook red flag signaling a breakdown in : document controls safeguarding of personal data internal compliance review supervision of servicing operations Under Delaware law, the XXXX boards failure to prevent or correct such failures is actionable. 



2. Delawares Expansion of Oversight Duties in XXXX In re XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ) reaffirmed and expanded XXXX by holding that : Boards must actively monitor safety, compliance, and risk in mission-critical areas. 
Ignoring red flags or permitting known operational failures constitutes bad-faith oversight. 
When a company works in a highly regulated industry, its board must ensure stronger monitoring. 

Mortgage servicing is regulated under : CFPB servicing rules RESPA Regulation X GLBA and Regulation P federal privacy law state mortgage supervision statutes Shellpoints privacy breach, contradictory ledgers, and inaccurate escrow accounting show a collapse of controls in a mission-critical sector. 

Under XXXX, the XXXX board is exposed to liability for failing to supervise systems that affect borrowers homes, foreclosure statuses, escrow accounts, and private financial data. 



XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX for XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, the Delaware court held that directors act in bad faith when they consciously disregard known oversight responsibilities. 

Shellpoint and NewRezs documented failuresincluding : systemically inconsistent loan records misapplied funds conflicting payment histories failure to resolve Notices of Error sending me another borrowers foreclosure reinstatement letter reflect a breakdown of processes that senior leadership and the board were required to monitor. 

Delaware law does not allow a parent company to disclaim responsibility for compliance failures inside wholly-owned subsidiaries, especially when those subsidiaries perform the companys core business function. 



4. Responsible Parties Under Delaware Fiduciary Law The following individuals hold fiduciary duties under Delaware law as directors or senior leaders of XXXX XXXX XXXX, and therefore bear responsibility for supervising Shellpoint and NewRezs operations : XXXX XXXX of Directors XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, Chairman XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, Chief Accounting Officer XXXX XXXX Chief Legal Officer XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX of Investments XXXX XXXX Head of Tax and Accounting and all senior leaders responsible for compliance, servicing oversight, risk management, and borrower-data security. 

Under Delaware law, these directors and officers are obligated to maintain proper oversight systems ensuring that the companys subsidiaries operate within legal and regulatory standards. They failed to do so. 



5. Linking Shellpoints Failures Directly to XXXX Under Delaware Law The operational issues documented in my evidenceincluding : contradictory portal balances unexplained escrow deficits unreconciled unapplied funds misreported payment histories repeated failures to honor Notices of Error and the unauthorized disclosure of another borrowers foreclosure reinstatement letter are not isolated incidents. They represent a systemic breakdown in internal controls that XXXX was legally obligated to oversee under Delaware fiduciary duty principles. 

Delaware courts have consistently held that a parent company can not evade responsibility for compliance failures in its subsidiaries when : the failures are systemic, the function is mission-critical, and the board either ignored red flags or failed to create oversight structures. 

Every one of those conditions is met here. 



6. Conclusion Under Delaware fiduciary law, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX, the failures of Shellpoint and NewRez are legally attributable to the XXXX board and XXXX. The privacy breach alone indicates a collapse of internal safeguards. Combined with the contradictory loan records, mishandled payments, and unresolved servicing errors, these events demonstrate actionable governance failures under Delawares established oversight-liability doctrine. 

This section is suitable for direct attachment to your CFPB complaint, TNDFI submission, or any parallel enforcement packet. 

Supplemental Section : Evidence of Systemic Servicing Failure and Batch-Level Misprocessing In addition to the privacy breach described above, the documents Shellpoint mistakenly mailed to me include a full servicing analysis for another borrower ( Estate of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX This document is not mine, but the financial language, structure, and accounting logic used in that letter are functionally identical to the language Shellpoint used in its correspondence to me. 

This is not a coincidence. The similarities demonstrate that Shellpoint is not performing individualized servicing reviews. Instead, they appear to be relying on automated batch-level templates, mass-processing scripts, and uniform accounting waterfalls that do not accurately reflect borrower-specific financial reality. This is consistent with systemic failures previously documented in enforcement actions such as CFPB XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX CFPB XXXX XXXX XXXX, which found that servicers used automated systems and generic templates that failed to produce accurate borrower records or lawful notices. 

Identical Structure and Financial Logic The XXXX letter uses the same internal logic Shellpoint attempted to apply to my loan : We reviewed your account We applied your payment We determined how many payments it satisfied We resolved your delinquency/foreclosure status This template matches Shellpoints letters to me almost word-for-word, except that my letter contains none of the required financial detail because Shellpoint can not reconcile my ledger. This is evidence of : 1. A corrupted servicing database 2. Contradictory ledger records 3. Inconsistent escrow application 4. Impaired account calculations 5. Bulk-use templates that fill in details only when the system can calculate them This is exactly the type of operational failure that has triggered past CFPB enforcement under RESPA Regulation X and UDAAP. 

Systemic Failure Demonstrated by Comparative Analysis The XXXX letter includes : exact received amount ( {$9800.00} ) payment date ( XX/XX/XXXX ) number of payments that amount satisfied reinstatement status servicing rationale In contrast, Shellpoint refused to provide : any payment math for my account any explanation of unapplied funds any reconciliation of contradictory portal balances any clarification of payment reversals any accurate delinquency calculation The fact that Shellpoint can produce detailed calculations for other borrowers but not for me shows that my servicing file can not be reconciled by their system, a serious violation of RESPA 1024.35 ( b ) ( 5 ), 1024.35 ( b ) ( 11 ), and 1024.38 ( c ) ( 2 ), which require : accurate records proper application of payments maintenance of complete account information investigation and correction of servicing errors Evidence of Batch-Level Document Handling Failure Shellpoints accidental inclusion of the XXXX foreclosure reinstatement letter inside my envelope demonstrates : a failure of document segregation a breakdown of mailroom quality controls inattention to borrower confidentiality potential cross-contamination of account documents In combination with the identical templates and financial logic, this suggests that borrower servicing is not being handled individually but through mass-processing workflows, increasing the risk of : misapplied payments incorrect delinquency statuses erroneous foreclosure activity inaccurate payoff calculations compromised escrow data These failures directly violate the CFPBs servicing standards and have been treated as UDAAP violations in CFPB XXXX XXXX, CFPB XXXX XXXX, and CFPB XXXX XXXX. 

Request for Regulatory Review Given the evidence, I request that the CFPB investigate whether Shellpoint/NewRez/XXXX are : 1. Using automated servicing scripts that fail to produce accurate borrower-specific results ; 2. Relying on batch templates instead of individualized RESPA-compliant reviews ; 3. Producing contradictory, non-reconcilable borrower records ; 4. Failing to maintain adequate internal controls over document handling ; 5. Violating servicing standards under RESPA, Regulation X, GLBA, and UDAAP. 

The accidental inclusion of another borrowers financial analysis especially one structurally identical to my own letter supports my contention that the servicing system is fundamentally unreliable and incapable of accurately managing my mortgage loan.

Consumer complaint narrative:
RE : URGENT REQUEST TO REOPEN COMPLAINT & INVESTIGATE BAD FAITH RESPONSE CFPB Complaint ID : XXXX Against : Caliber Home Loans , Inc. / XXXX XXXX  XXXX Dear CFPB , I am writing to formally challenge Caliber Home Loans ' non-compliant and deceptive response to my original complaint ( ID : XXXX ) and request immediate escalation. Calibers submission violates CFPB rules and confirms the systemic misconduct I alleged. 

I. INVALID RESPONSE : REGULATORY NON-COMPLIANCE Caliber failed to respond to its own complaint, instead submitting a letter from Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ( dated XX/XX/XXXX ). This violates : CFPB Bulletin XXXX : " The servicer named in the complaint must respond directly... using its own business name. '' Procedural Rule 12 CFR 1024.35 ( b ) : Servicers must acknowledge/respond to notices of error in their capacity as servicer.

Critical Proof : The Shellpoint response references CFPB correspondence from XX/XX/XXXX, XXXXbut my complaint against Caliber was filed on XX/XX/XXXX. This confirms : The response was pre-generated for a different complaint ( my Shellpoint case ), Caliber/Shellpoint treat complaints interchangeably, proving operational collusion.

Demand : Declare this response non-compliant and require Caliber to answer in its own name within XXXX days. 

II. UNREBUTTED VIOLATIONS : ADMISSION BY SILENCE Calibers submission ignored every material allegation, constituting a de facto admission under CFPB guidance. Unaddressed violations include : A. Unauthorized Servicing & Standing Defects Caliber initiated foreclosure without proof of valid servicing transfer.

Violation : RESPA 6 ( e ) Failure to provide transfer notice within XXXX  days.

Leverage : " Servicers must prove standing to enforce loan terms. '' ( CFPB v. Citibank, 2017 ).

B. Fraudulent Foreclosure Documentation Caliber filed foreclosure documents using the incorrect legal name ( " XXXX '' vs. " XXXX  '' ).

Violation : FDCPA 807 ( 2 ) ( A ) False representation of legal status.

Leverage : Invalidates foreclosure under state law ( e.g., XXXX  Statute 702.10 ).

C. Illegal Evasion of Accountability Shellpoints letter requested " name change documentation '' while ignoring standing defects.

Violation : 15 U.S.C. 45 Unfair/deceptive practices. 

III. Issue: Applying for a mortgage or refinancing an existing mortgage
Sub-issue: Changes in loan terms during the application process
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint regarding a refinance application with my current mortgage lender, NewRez. 
The refinance was originally structured with closing costs to be paid from my escrow account. At the time this structure was proposed, the loan XXXX knew that my property taxes were scheduled to be paid from escrow in the month of closing and that the escrow account would be used for that purpose. 
Due to delays caused by the lender, the escrow account was depleted when the taxes were paid. Only hours before the scheduled closing, I received a revised disclosure showing approximately {$4000.00} in closing costs had been added to the loan balance. This represented a material change to the loan terms and the overall cost of the refinance. 
This material change was not discussed in advance, no alternatives were presented ( such as a lender credit, cash to close, or delaying the refinance ), and it was disclosed only in a docusign document hours before closing. As a result, I was left with no meaningful opportunity to review the revised terms, consider alternatives, or provide informed consent. 
Because of the timing and the significant increase in cost, I refused to sign the refinance documents. 
The lender has since acknowledged the situation but has not offered to correct the issue or cover the additional costs, despite the fact that the escrow depletion and resulting change were foreseeable and within the lenders control. The lender has also failed to respond in a timely manner despite repeated follow-ups. 
I believe the lender failed to provide clear, accurate, and timely disclosures of material loan terms as required under the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ). The refinance was initially structured in a manner that did not accurately reflect the true cost of the loan once the known escrow payment occurred, and the resulting material change was disclosed too late to allow for informed consent or meaningful choice. 

As a result of the lenders actions, I incurred significant time loss, stress, and uncertainty, and I was forced to abandon a refinance that had been represented as having no out-of-pocket closing costs. I also lost the opportunity to lock in the offered terms due to the lenders delay and late disclosure of materially higher costs.

Disclosure of a material increase in costs only hours before closing undermines the purpose of TILA and TRID timing requirements, which are intended to ensure borrowers have sufficient time to review, compare, and understand loan terms before consummation. 

The escrow depletion was not an unforeseen event ; it was scheduled, known to the lender, and occurred solely because the lender delayed closing, placing the resulting cost increase entirely within the lenders control. 

All communications with the lender occurred on recorded lines, and the lenders own records should reflect its knowledge of the escrow payment, the delays in closing, and the timing of the material change disclosed only hours before the scheduled closing.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
Complaint Title Violation of RESPA 2605 ( e ) Ignored Qualified Written Request and Retaliatory False Default Reporting What Happened On XX/XX/XXXX, I submitted a formal Notice of Error and Final Demand for Correction under 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 to NewRez LLC ( Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ).

The demand outlined {$12000.00} in unapplied funds and referenced recorded admissions by company representatives acknowledging the misapplication. I attached call transcripts, payment screenshots, and citations to federal statutes. 

The email was sent directly to multiple compliance officers at NewRez and XXXX  XXXX XXXX with copies to CFPB Enforcement, DOJ Civil Fraud, FTC, and VA Oversight ( see attached transmission proof ). 

Despite receiving this RESPA-protected correspondence, the company failed to : 1. Acknowledge the request within five business days as required by 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( e ) ( 1 ) ( A ) ; 2. Investigate and provide a substantive response within 30 business days as required by 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( e ) ( 2 ) ; 3. Correct the unapplied funds or stop false delinquency reporting.

Instead, NewRez generated a boiler-plate customer-service letter that ignored every point raised, then issued a Notice to Cure and foreclosure threat while still holding those funds.

This violates : 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( ii ) failure to credit payments as of date received ; 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( k ) ( 1 ) ( C ) duty to maintain accurate account information ; 15 U.S.C. 1692e ( 2 ) ( A ) false representation of debt ; 38 C.F.R. 36.4350 ( c ) VA servicers duty to apply payments promptly.

Evidence Attached 1. Email Final Demand for Correction, Restitution, and Damages Unapplied Funds and False Default Reporting ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 
2. Call transcript ( XX/XX/XXXX ) confirming {$12000.00} admission. 
3. Form customer-service letter dated [ insert date ] non-responsive reply.

4. Payment ledger showing unapplied funds and duplicate entries.

5. CFPB portal screenshots documenting 17 complaints.

6. Letter from XXXX XXXX ( Tennessee XXXX ) confirming state regulatory review. 



XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ) XXXX v. XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX Cir. XXXX ) XXXX v. XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX Cir. XXXX ) Each case confirms that a generic acknowledgment letter fails RESPAs 2605 ( e ) requirements and triggers statutory liability.

Summary for CFPB Review This complaint establishes a clear statutory violation of RESPA 2605 ( e ) and a pattern of predatory servicing practices against a XXXX veteran borrower. The companys continued misrepresentation and failure to apply funds constitute willful non Corporate Connection Between XXXX XXXX and NewRez LLC According to public filings with the XXXX Securities and Exchange Commission, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX : XXXX  ) explicitly identifies NewRez LLCoperating under the trade name Shellpoint Mortgage Servicingas a wholly owned subsidiary and core revenue-producing segment. In XXXX most recent Form 10-Q and Form 8-K, the company reports mortgage-servicing income, origination fees, and interest spread revenue derived directly from NewRezs operations. Those same filings list XXXX XXXX ( Chairman & CEO ) and XXXX XXXX ( CFO ) as certifying officers under SarbanesOxley Act 302 and 906, attesting that the financial statements fairly present in all material respects the performance of consolidated subsidiaries, including NewRez LLC. XXXX consolidated balance sheet, footnotes, and management discussion further confirm that NewRezs servicing rights, advances, and custodial accounts are recorded as XXXX assets under generally accepted accounting principles ( GAAP ) and materially affect shareholder earnings. 

Therefore, any representation to regulators or consumers that XXXX is not the appropriate company or has no connection to NewRez LLC is demonstrably false. Such statements constitute potential violations of 18 U.S.C. 1001 ( False Statements ), 15 U.S.C. 78j ( b ) and 17 C.F.R. 240.10b-5 ( Securities Fraud ), as well as the Consumer Financial Protection Act, 12 U.S.C. 5536 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ), which prohibits deceptive acts in the offering or administration of consumer-financial services. The inclusion of XXXX own SEC-filed 10-Q and 8-K exhibits establishes irrefutable proof of the parent-subsidiary relationship and the flow of financial benefit from NewRezs servicing activity directly to XXXX XXXX and its shareholders.

I fell behind on my mortgage payments due to a documented decline in business income and submitted a hardship and loss mitigation request to the servicer. I attempted to follow up regarding the status of my request and the assigned point of contact. 

On or about XX/XX/XXXX, I received an automatic reply stating that the assigned mortgage specialist is out of the office and will not return until XX/XX/XXXX. No alternate contact, reassignment, or substantive response was provided. 

As of today, I have not received confirmation that my loss mitigation request remains under active review, nor have I been provided with a replacement specialist. This lack of communication places me at risk of further delinquency or adverse action due to servicer inaction rather than borrower noncompliance. 

I am requesting assistance to ensure proper servicing, clear communication, and confirmation that my loss mitigation request is being handled appropriately without penalty during this period.

Sub-issue: Trying to communicate with the company to fix an issue related to modification, forbearance, short sale, deed-in-lieu, bankruptcy, or foreclosure
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have been a homeowner for 26 years and have always intended to remain current on my mortgage. Unfortunately, beginning in XXXX, I experienced a series of serious and uncontrollable hardships : In XXXX, I contracted XXXX. 
On XX/XX/XXXX, I was in a major car accident, which required an extended recovery period. I notified my mortgage servicer, Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing, after each event and asked for temporary assistance options. However, after notifying them of my XXXX accident, months went by without any follow-up or resolution from Shellpoint. I received no communication or support until I again reached out. I also filed an FHA complaint about the lack of communication and my mortgage company not following up. 
Then, on XX/XX/XXXX, while I was still recovering, I was in another serious car accident ( a hit-and-run ) that caused significant injuries, including surgeries, and extended medical treatment. These events left me unable to maintain regular payments, but I stayed in contact with Shellpoint and made every effort to find a solution. 
Shellpoint first offered me a three-month repayment plan, which was too short given my medical condition. When I asked for a longer plan, I was told it was not available. Instead, I was offered a 40-year mortgage modification, raising my interest rate from 4 % to 6.75 %, which made no financial sense since I have already paid on my home for over two decades. I contacted FHA, who told me I should qualify for a 6-month repayment plan. I was granted that plan. In XX/XX/XXXX, I learned that a down payment was required to start that plan. This was information that remember Shellpoint had informed me of earlier. ( I reported this as well ). When I spoke to a Shellpoint representative, she assured me that the down payment could simply be added into the repayment plan. I requested it to be added in when she called me back. However, when I called in on XX/XX/XXXX to make my first payment, I was told the plan had been canceled for failure to make that down payment. I was devastated! This confusion and lack of clear communication caused my account to fall further behind. I continued to request reasonable assistance ( a12-month repayment plan or a forbearance for medical ), but Shellpoint told me since it was the 13 month, they could not assist me and proceeded to offer the 40 year modification again. I was baffled because they had so many months prior, to help set me up the 12-mnth. 
Afterwards, My mortgage company point of contact said new options were coming but then later told me I still only qualified for the same 40-year plan. During the government shutdown, I have been unable to reach FHA or HUD for clarification or to escalate my concerns. There is no middle ground. Despite this, Shellpoint has proceeded with foreclosure activity. 
I recently called Shellpoint again to report their inconsistencies and misleading information that I have been receiving. I filed a report with them just last week, explaining that : -Several agents gave me different and contradictory information, -Some failed to return calls or refused to give me more detail information about my account and options. I this complaint on XX/XX/XXXX, no one has contacted me. 
Here are my concerns : 1. Poor communication and follow-up : Shellpoint failed to respond for months after my initial hardship report and has not followed through on promised callbacks. 
2. Conflicting information : Representatives gave inconsistent details about repayment options and down payment requirements. 
3. Lack of transparency : I was not informed of key repayment terms in time to comply.

4. Unreasonable modification offer : The 40-year modification raises my rate from 4 % to 6.75 % after 26 years of payments, which is not fair or appropriate for a medical hardship case.

5. Foreclosure despite ongoing communication : Shellpoint advanced toward foreclosure even though I was actively seeking resolution. 
6. No response to internal complaint : My formal complaint to Shellpoint has not been addressed, and supervisors have not followed up.

This is when I discovered, without any advance notice, that my mortgage servicer had paid the bill. 
XX/XX/XXXX I logged into my mortgage account and saw the escrow shortage/payment increase notice. 
My monthly payment increased from {$840.00} to {$2100.00} due to the escrow shortage created by the servicers advance. 



Key Issues I was not notified in advance that the servicer intended to pay the municipal bill.

I requested a recalculation and offered lump-sum payment options, but I was told the servicer would not re-run escrow unless the full amount was paid.

Sub-issue: Trying to communicate with the company to fix an issue related to modification, forbearance, short sale, deed-in-lieu, bankruptcy, or foreclosure
Consumer complaint narrative:
I inherited my late fathers home in XXXX and have issues with NewRez and Shellpoint since. 

They continued to advise they needed additional documentation from probate proving I am the sole heir, and when I provided the documentation I thought they needed ( several times, over multiple months ) they refused to advise that the documentation was not what they were asking for or would flat out tell me Im not sure it goes to a different department. 

We fell upon financial struggle that put us behind and an impending foreclosure date was provided earlier this year. I worked with someone who helped put the loan in forbearance, and advised I could then apply for a repayment plan or a modification. Once the two month forbearance was over, she reached out to gain additional information to move forward with an application for the modification. I provided all necessary information, and was not advised I was missing anything until I CCd her on an email to the loss mitigation department with the full list of documents requested. She then emailed me and advised she was no longer my point of contact and to call the XXXX number to reapply and be reappointed a new single point of contact. 

There was no further explanation, so I called and reapplied. Still, I was not advised that I had been denied for the modification, nor why ( that one document was missing and I didnt realize ). I was told 5-7 business days to be assigned a POC, and nothing could be done until I was contacted by that POC. I waited 5 business days days, called, and was advised that there was no updates yet. I called again the following Monday to be told that I was not eligible as I did not provide the correct documentation. Instead of reaching out to let me know so that I could make the easy fix needed, they waited for me to reach out despite that I was advised the opposite. 

In the last year I have called and discussed my options at least 20+ times with someone over the phone, as well as daily/ weekly communication via email. This entire time I was under the impression that we were working toward a loan modification application, when in reality they were giving me the run around and I feel as if this was their intention all along. 

I have received little to no advice, education, etc from the company, and in turn believe they are unlawfully stalling to force foreclosure ( which is coming up in a week ).

Immediately Preserve ( Scope ) Preserve all relevant materials whether in active systems, archived storage, backups, shadow copies, XXXX services, mobile devices, chat systems, voicemail, or third-party vendor platforms including but not limited to : Account & Transaction Records Complete transaction histories, integrated servicing ledgers, suspense/unapplied payment records, escrow histories, payment posting logs, and all versions of account statements for Loan No. [ XXXX ] ( from XX/XX/XXXX to present ). 

Call & Voice Records All inbound/outbound call recordings, call metadata, transcripts, IVR logs , and quality-assurance notes that reference the loan, the borrower ( XXXX XXXX ), or CFPB complaint IDs. 

Communications All emails, text messages, XXXX messages, internal tickets, and correspondence ( including attachments ) referencing the borrower, loan number, CFPB complaints, TDFI/other regulator contacts, or any of the attached exhibits. 

System & Audit Logs Database logs, audit trails, XXXX  submission logs, XXXX node edits, reconciliation reports, database modification timestamps, user IDs responsible for edits, hashes, backups, and any change/delete events. 

Vendor & Third-Party Records Records held by vendors ( call-recording providers, MSP platform providers, XXXX hosts, backup vendors, auditors ) concerning the loan or related complaints. 

Compliance & Legal Files All internal compliance reviews, investigation notes, escalation memos, Board materials, committee minutes, legal-department memos , regulatory correspondence ( drafts and final ), and any communications with outside counsel regarding these matters. 

4. Custodians Preserve all materials from the following custodians ( including but not limited to ) : XXXX XXXX ( CEO ) XXXX XXXX ( CFO/CAO ) XXXX XXXX ( Chief Legal Officer ) XXXX XXXX XXXX ( Head of Risk ) Compliance, Customer Care , Collections, Servicing Ops, IT, Audit, Investor Relations, and any named employees or agents that have handled Loan No. [ XXXX ] or related CFPB submissions. 

5. Suspension of Deletion / Alteration You are instructed to suspend any automatic deletion, overwriting, rolling-off, patching, purging, or other alteration of relevant data in live systems, backups, archives, and third-party platforms until further written notice. This includes disabling any auto-archival or data-retention jobs that could modify timestamps, hashes, or content. 

6. Confirmation & Certification Within seven ( 7 ) business days of receipt of this Notice, please confirm in response to the complaint through CFPB portal. 
a ) The legal hold has been implemented ; b ) The list of named custodians and systems is being preserved ; and c ) The company has taken steps to suspend any scheduled deletions or overwrites. 

Provide the name and contact information of the person ( s ) responsible for the preservation in each business unit ( Legal, IT, Compliance ). If you decline to implement preservation, identify with specificity the categories you refuse and explain the legal basis. 

7. Consequences of Non-Compliance Please be advised that any deletion, alteration, or failure to preserve relevant documents or ESI after receipt of this Notice may constitute spoliation and subject the company and responsible individuals to remedies including : court sanctions, adverse-inference instructions, monetary sanctions, referral to regulatory or criminal authorities ( including CFPB, SEC, DOJ ) , and use of spoliation as evidence of consciousness of guilt. 

8. Production / Next Steps This Notice does not waive any rights. If counsel is retained by the company or if you have outside counsel already handling these matters, please provide counsels contact information. I ( and/or my counsel ) will be requesting formal production of preserved materials and a written preservation certification as the matter proceeds.

On XX/XX/year>, when I contacted customer service to inquire about my remaining escrow balance from the old loan, I was informed that this {$66.00} late charge had already been deducted from my expected escrow refund. I was further told that this is company policy, that the collections/customer service department does not communicate with the refinance/loan department, that I have no recourse, and that there is nothing I can do to dispute or remove the fee.

This late charge is improper and constitutes a servicing error under RESPA ( 12 CFR 1024.35 ) because : - The delinquency was caused solely by following the explicit, repeated instructions of the lenders own employees during a XXXX XXXXXXXX transaction. 
- XXXX XXXX  refinances routinely defer the payment for the month of closing without penalty to the veteran. 

- The imposition of late fees caused by the servicers own refinance process or miscommunication between its departments constitutes a servicing error ( incorrectly imposed fees ).

Consumer complaint narrative:
Re : XXXX XXXX Demand & RESPA Notice Unfair and Deceptive Mortgage Servicing Practices To Whom It May Concern : I am the borrower on the mortgage loan secured by XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. I am writing pursuant to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  to demand relief for unfair and deceptive acts committed by NewRez LLC XXXX Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ( Shellpoint ) in connection with servicing this loan. The XXXX XXXX Notice dated XX/XX/XXXX, identifies factual inaccuracies and omissions. 

Facts Shellpoint received preservation payments that were recognized in my bankruptcy proceedings in from XXXX through XXXX yet continues to assert I defaulted inclusive of this period. 
Shellpoint withheld a required appraisal for approximately XXXX  months before negotiating loss mitigation, in violation of federal servicing standards and industry duties of good faith. 
Shellpoint offered a conditional modification/settlement of $ XXXX that I accepted but they failed to honor. 

Per the XXXX Right-To-Cure notification, there is {$1700.00} as an unapplied balance, further evidence of misapplied preservation payments and other accounting issues. 
Shellpoint referred my loan to outside counsel ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) to collect on disputed amounts, misrepresenting my account status. This notice is defective because it implies personal liability on a discharged debt in violation of Bankruptcy Code - Discharge Injunction Violation ( 11 U.S.C. 524 ( a ) ).

Key Errors in Shellpoints Right to Cure Notice 1. 1 ) Failure to account for courtapproved preservation payments. 
I made preservation payments in the amount of {$2300.00} per month from XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX pursuant to orders entered in my bankruptcy case. Your Right to Cure Notice asserts nonpayment of every monthly installment from XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX. By ignoring XXXX years of preservation payments recognized by the bankruptcy court, the Notice materially overstates the arrears and is misleading. 
XXXX. XXXX ) Servicing transfer/recordkeeping deficiency. 
Shellpoint requested I supply proof of the XXXX payments because it did not have the complete prior servicers history ( See enclosures : Years XXXX and XXXX are missing in their entirety ). After I directed Shellpoint to the bankruptcy court docket, Shellpoint still forwarded inaccurate loan histories and noticed default for the entire period. This demonstrates a failure to maintain accurate loan records following a servicing transfer and to conduct a reasonable investigation of my dispute. 

XXXX. XXXX ) Escrow and unapplied funds discrepancies. 
The Notice reflects multiple stepups in escrow amounts and an unapplied balance of ( {$1700.00} ) held in suspense. Shellpoint has not explained why those funds were not applied to reduce arrears or principal. Without a contemporaneous escrow analysis and a full suspense account history, Shellpoint can not lawfully demand inflated arrears or declare default based on amounts not actually due. 

Errors Under Massachusetts and Federal Law Massachusetts law ( G.L. c. XXXX, XXXX ) requires strict compliance with default/Right to Cure requirements ; misstated or misleading arrears figures render a notice defective. Further, federal servicing regulations require accurate account maintenance, timely investigation and response to borrower disputes, and goodfaith lossmitigation handling. As with XXXX XXXX XXXX Shellpoint in XXXX for mishandled servicing & foreclosure practices, there is already precedent for misconduct. 

Violations Unfair and deceptive acts under XXXX. XXXX XXXX, c and XXXX ; Violations of 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( RESPA ) and 12 C.F.R. 1024.35, 1024.36 ; and 1024.41 ; Violations of 12 C.F.R. 1024.38 ( servicing policies and procedures ) ; Bad faith conduct similar to conduct found unlawful in the XXXX XXXX Attorney Generals settlement with Shellpoint. 

Demand for Immediate Action Provide a written correction and reconciliation of my account that credits all preservation payments made between XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX ; Produce a complete payment history/transaction ledger from XX/XX/XXXX to present, including suspense account activity, unapplied funds, and application dates ; Produce all lossmitigation logs and the appraisal order/receipt timeline, along with all communications with prior servicers ; Provide escrow analyses supporting each escrow amount reflected in the Right to Cure Notice and correct any overcharges ; Issue a corrected Right to Cure Notice, if Shellpoint continues to contend a default exists, reflecting accurate arrears and dates ; Cease any foreclosure activity and collection efforts based on inaccurate figures until the above corrections are completed. 

Response Deadline This is both a XXXX XXXXXXXX demand and a RESPA Notice of Error/Request for Information. Please provide a written response within 30 days under XXXX XXXX and within the timelines specified by 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 and 1024.36. Failure to timely correct and respond will result in the pursuit of all remedies, including suit for damages, attorneys fees, and multiple damages for willful violations. 

Enclosures First and second request for Loan History from Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing Shellpoint Mortgage Timeline from the Compliance Department noting the history of requests for an accurate Loan History and Declinations of Loan Modification Requests on XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX. 
Debt Collection Notice from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX United States Bankruptcy XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX attached to Affirmation of Debtor Opposition to Lift Stay Motion Exhibit A. 

If Shellpoint fails to make a reasonable written offer of settlement within 30 days, I will file suit seeking multiple damages, costs, and attorneys fees as authorized by XXXX XXXX, XXXX. 

The files with the loan history ( first and second requests ) from Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing are too large to upload, and by certified mail I have forwarded a complete history/package to your XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX all enclosures listed above. Shellpoint 's Compliance Department mailed me a timeline asserting there there are no errors or omissions, however, as I pointed out on several occasions, the years XXXX XXXX XXXX are missing in their entirety which you will note when my package is arrives. To that end, the XXXX XXXX is defective.

Consumer complaint narrative:
In XXXX XXXX, Shellpoint unexpectedly contacted my then-boyfriends phone number, stating I was past due after transferring to their company ( I was unaware of this at this time ) and discussing information without my consent. When I contacted Shellpoint to clarify, they were unable to verify my identity because, although my name, address, and date of birth matched, the Social Security number linked to the account was not mine. One of the agents of Shellpoint had even told me the last 4 digits of the social security number that was linked to my account during one of my interactions I had when trying to resolve my account. 

XX/XX/XXXX : While attempting to set up online access, I discovered that entering my Social Security number on the find my account tool on their website and also giving my zip code, it pulled up the account to a couple with the same last name and same city as me. Their last 4 of account number, policy number and company to their insurance, their full names, and address information was shown and it was linked to my social I had input in the find my account tool. 
This meant Shellpoint had incorrectly linked my Social Security number to another borrowers mortgage account, while simultaneously assigning a different Social Security number to my account. 

In XX/XX/XXXX, after I filed a complaint with the Oregon Department of Consumer and Business Services, Shellpoint acknowledged updating my Social Security number but dismissed the seriousness of the matter, stating they saw nothing else wrong. 

This mishandling represents a major privacy and compliance failure, exposing both my identity and another households private mortgage information and social. 


Separately, Shellpoint engaged in deceptive and unprofessional servicing of my account : XX/XX/XXXX : A trial modification offer was posted to my Shellpoint portal. 

XX/XX/XXXX : I received an email from XXXX XXXX confirming approval for a trial plan leading to a permanent modification. 

I successfully made the required trial payments ( in fact, four payments instead of the three required ). 

I was told by the loss mitigation team via phone on XX/XX/XXXX, that I would receive documents by mail within 23 weeks to finalize the modification. 

These documents never arrived. Instead : XX/XX/XXXX : My portal showed that the loan assistance plan was no longer being offered. 

XX/XX/XXXX, onward : I repeatedly contacted Shellpoint to resolve the issue and attempt to make monthly payments. I was told only the Loss Mitigation Team could assist me, but each time agents attempted to transfer my call, they were unable to reach anyone. Several agents on different occasions tried to connect me, but no one from Loss Mitigation ever picked up. I was repeatedly promised callbacks that never occurred, leaving me unable to make my required payments. 

XX/XX/XXXX : I received a letter by mail claiming my account was past due $ $ $ ( subject to additional interest and fees ) and assigning me a single point of contact. 
However, that contact was never available and never returned messages. 

XX/XX/XXXX : Out of desperation, I reapplied for assistance through the portal, submitting a new application and supporting documents. 

XXXX XXXX : Despite repeated calls, no one from the Loss Mitigation Team contacted me. 

XX/XX/XXXX : I finally received a portal message stating that my modification was retracted because the investor declined to participate, citing the end of the HAMP program. This directly contradicted the trial modification I had already completed and was told I would be finalizing.

Shellpoints conduct constitutes multiple violations of OAR 137-020-0805 : 1. Subsection ( 3 ) Misrepresentation : I was told I was approved for a modification, made trial payments, and was promised finalization documents. Instead, the plan was rescinded without notice or justification. 

2. Subsection ( 6 ) Failure to deal in good faith : Agents acknowledged the urgency of my case but consistently failed to connect me to the Loss Mitigation Team or provide promised callbacks.

3. Subsection ( 5 ) Failure to comply with RESPA : Shellpoint failed to provide timely, accurate, and complete servicing information, leaving me unable to make payments or resolve my account. 

4. Privacy violations : Shellpoint mishandled sensitive borrower information by incorrectly linking Social Security numbers, exposing my identity and another couples mortgage information and social.

I have been unfairly placed at risk of foreclosure despite complying with Shellpoints trial plan.

My credit and financial security have been jeopardized. 

My personal identity and Social Security number were mishandled, exposing me to potential fraud and privacy violations. 

The stress, anxiety, and uncertainty caused by Shellpoints conduct have affected not only me, but also my family members residing on the property.

Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing has engaged in deceptive servicing, failed to deal in good faith, and mishandled sensitive borrower information in violation of Oregon law, federal RESPA requirements, and borrower privacy protections. 

Given the seriousness of these violations, I request immediate relief. 

In addition to this complaint filed I will be filing a complaint with the Oregon Department of Justice - Consumer Protection Section to request they take requested action towards this matter and ensure that Shellpoint / New Rez doesnt continue to do this to others too!

ODJ Requested Actions : Investigate Shellpoint/NewRez for unlawful debt collection and deceptive trade practices. 


Require Shellpoint/NewRez to explain and remediate their mishandling of my Social Security number and account information. 

Impose penalties or enforcement measures necessary to deter these unlawful practices against other Oregon consumers.

Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing / NewRez LLC Loan Number : XXXX Complaint : I filed XXXX XXXX XXXX and received my discharge on XX/XX/2024. My mortgage account was with Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing. 

After discharge, I entered into a loan modification agreement with Shellpoint / NewRez, which created a new binding contract and enforceable obligation. I have been making all payments on time under this new agreement. 
However, Shellpoint / NewRez refuses to report my mortgage account to the credit bureaus. In a written letter, they stated that I must obtain a reaffirmation of the debt from the court, which is not possible, because reaffirmation agreements must be filed and approved before discharge. Asking me to do something legally impossible is unreasonable and unfair. 
Because this loan modification was executed after bankruptcy discharge, it should be treated as a new contract and reported as such. Their refusal to report is preventing me from rebuilding credit, despite my consistent payment history. 

What I Want : - Require Shellpoint / NewRez to begin reporting my mortgage account and ongoing payment history to XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX. 
- If they refuse, require them to provide a clear legal justification as to why a post-discharge loan modification is not reported.

Consumer complaint narrative:
am filing a complaint regarding repeated errors by Newrez LLC in setting up and processing my mortgage payment. Despite multiple attempts to resolve the issue, Newrez has incorrectly entered my bank account information several times, causing payment rejections and unnecessary disruption. 

Chronology of events : XX/XX/year> : I received the welcome packet from Newrez. The same day, I created my online account and set up a recurring monthly mortgage payment. 

XX/XX/year> : I received an email from Newrez stating that my recurring payment had been canceled. I immediately logged in and re-established the recurring payment. I received a confirmation email showing it was successfully set up. 

XX/XX/year> : I received notice that the payment was rejected again. 

XX/XX/year> : I called Newrez customer service to determine the cause. The representative read the bank account number they had on file, and it included an extra digit, making it an invalid account number. The representative told me that I must have entered it incorrectly. I accepted responsibility at the time, and she stated the issue was fixed. 

XX/XX/year> ( approximately one hour later ) : Because I no longer trusted the information, I called back. I asked a different representative to read the bank account number on file. To my surprise, the account number was still incorrect, with the same extra digit. The first representative had not corrected the problem, and the incorrect information remained in the system despite her confirmation. 

These repeated errors have caused my payments to be rejected, my recurring payment to be canceled without my action, and significant concern about whether the loan will be serviced correctly going forward. I made good-faith efforts to pay on time, yet Newrezs internal mistakes repeatedly prevented the payment from being processed. 

At this point, I have lost confidence that Newrez can accurately manage my payment information or properly process my mortgage payments. I am requesting the CFPBs assistance to ensure : My loan is brought current with no late fees, penalties, or negative credit reporting, Newrez corrects and verifies my banking information, and Newrez provides a written explanation of how these repeated data-entry errors occurred and what steps they will take to prevent further issues. 

I have documentation for each attempted setup, including confirmation emails and call logs, and can provide them upon request.

Consumer complaint narrative:
SUMMARY Shellpoint Improperly Reduced Escrow When Removing PMI, Causing {$8900.00} Avoidable Shortage DETAILED COMPLAINT : I am filing a complaint against Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ( NMLS # XXXX ) for escrow account mismanagement that has caused me significant financial harm totaling {$8900.00}. 

LOAN INFORMATION : Shellpoint Loan Number : XXXX Property Address : XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Loan originated : XX/XX/XXXX Loan transferred to XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX WHAT HAPPENED : In XX/XX/XXXX, I requested cancellation of Private Mortgage Insurance ( PMI ) after reaching sufficient equity in my home. Shellpoint approved my request and removed PMI starting with my XX/XX/XXXX payment. 

THE CRITICAL ERROR : When Shellpoint removed my PMI in XX/XX/XXXX, they simultaneously and improperly reduced my monthly escrow collection by the exact amount of the PMI that was removed. 

DOCUMENTED EVIDENCE : According to my monthly mortgage statements from Shellpoint : XX/XX/XXXX Statement : Total monthly payment : {$3600.00} Escrow collection : $ XXXX PMI : Included in payment ( ~ {$270.00} ) XX/XX/XXXX Statement ( after PMI removal ) : Total monthly payment : {$2900.00} Escrow collection : $ XXXX REDUCED BY {$270.00} PMI : {$0.00} REMOVED XX/XX/XXXX Statement : Escrow collection : $ XXXX ( continued at reduced rate ) XX/XX/XXXX Statement : Escrow collection : $ XXXX ( continued at reduced rate ) Current Escrow Balance : {$5600.00} WHY THIS IS IMPROPER ESCROW MANAGEMENT : PMI and escrow are completely separate financial instruments. Removing PMI should have NO impact on escrow collection amounts. 
My homeowners insurance premium was increasing dramatically from approximately {$3500.00} to {$6100.00} for the XXXX policy year. 

Shellpoint should have INCREASED my escrow collection to $ XXXX to properly cover the increased insurance premium and annual property taxes, calculated as : ( {$6100.00} insurance + {$6000.00} taxes ) 12 months = $ XXXX. 
Instead, Shellpoint DECREASED my escrow collection from {$750.00} to {$470.00} - a reduction of exactly {$270.00}, which is precisely the amount of PMI that was removed. 
This created a systematic undercollection of $ XXXX ( {$1000.00} - {$470.00} ) for three months ( XXXX, XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX ), totaling {$1600.00} in undercollected escrow. 

THE RESULTING SHORTAGE : XX/XX/XXXX : When my annual homeowners insurance premium came due ( {$6100.00} ), my escrow account only contained {$5600.00}. Shellpoint paid the insurance premium, creating a negative balance of - {$510.00}. 

XX/XX/XXXX : My loan was transferred to XXXXXXXX XXXX with this negative escrow balance of - {$510.00}. 

XX/XX/XXXX : When my property taxes came due ( {$6000.00} ), XXXX paid them from the escrow account. Combined with the negative balance transferred from Shellpoint, plus the federally required XXXX escrow cushion ( {$2000.00} ), this created a total shortage of {$8900.00}. 

FINANCIAL HARM : As a direct result of Shellpoint 's improper escrow management, I am now experiencing the following financial harm : Current Monthly Payment : {$4200.00} Principal & Interest : {$2400.00} Escrow ( correct amount ) : {$1000.00} Shortage repayment : $ XXXX for 12 months Payment Should Have Been : Approximately $ XXXX Principal & Interest : {$2400.00} Escrow ( if properly managed ) : {$1000.00} Additional Financial Burden : $ XXXX 12 months = {$8900.00} This shortage was entirely avoidable. If Shellpoint had : NOT improperly linked PMI removal to escrow reduction Conducted a proper annual escrow analysis as required by RESPA Increased escrow collection to the appropriate amount when insurance increased Maintained escrow at the previous $ XXXX ( or increased it appropriately ) Then this shortage would not exist, and I would not be paying nearly $ XXXX extra for an entire year. 

RESPA VIOLATIONS : Shellpoint 's actions appear to violate the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA ), specifically : 12 CFR 1024.17 ( b ) - Failure to conduct proper escrow account analysis 12 CFR 1024.17 ( c ) - Failure to collect amounts sufficient to pay anticipated disbursements 12 CFR 1024.17 ( d ) - Creating an avoidable escrow shortage through mismanagement ADDITIONAL CONCERNS : The fact that Shellpoint reduced my escrow by the EXACT amount of the removed PMI ( {$270.00} ) suggests either : A systematic error in their servicing platform that automatically reduces escrow when PMI is removed, or An intentional practice to keep borrowers ' payments artificially low during the transition, creating shortages that result in higher payments later Either scenario represents serious escrow mismanagement and potential RESPA violations.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

I immediately contacted the company multiple times over six weeks, including letters and phone calls, requesting review of the call recording, acknowledgment of the error, and compensation. The company has failed to confirm that the AVR call recording was reviewed or provide a resolution. 

I am seeking confirmation that the payment call was reviewed, acknowledgment of responsibility for the error, and compensation for the financial and operational harm caused.

to confirm that Claimant ( XXXX XXXX XXXX has no property tax arrears in the amount of {$3600.00} that Shellpoint Mortgage falsely represents with no evidence, other than faulty accounting practices.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Servicing Manipulation Through Dual-System Reporting Finding : Analysis of borrower portal data from XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX, reveals that NewRez LLC and its subservicer Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing, both controlled by XXXX XXXX XXXX , maintained conflicting digital records for the same VA-guaranteed loan XXXX No. XXXX ). 

The NewRez portal reflected the account as current, while the Shellpoint portal simultaneously reflected delinquency, late fees, and a negative escrow balance. Both systems displayed the identical principal balance ( {$580000.00} ) and property information, confirming that they draw from the same master data repository. This shows deliberate dual-system manipulation, not an isolated clerical error. 



Evidence : 1. Recorded call logs and transcripts ( XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX ) confirm Shellpoint representatives repeatedly acknowledged holding {$12000.00}, later corrected to nearly {$100000.00}, in unapplied fundspayments received but not credited to the loan. 
2. Shellpoint Cure Default letter ( XX/XX/XXXX ) demanded {$6800.00} by XX/XX/XXXX while records proved the borrower was fully paid through that date. 
3. Portal captures from both NewRez and Shellpoint show contradictory account statuses within the same billing cycle. 
4. CFPB complaint chain ( XXXX. XXXX through XXXX ) documents consistent ledger falsification, delayed posting, and repeated non-responses to statutory Notices of Error. 
5. XX/XX/XXXX call recording specifically references an account balance discrepancy of {$3900.00} versus {$4000.00} and confirms the servicers own admission that an escalation complaint was filed due to incorrect figures. 



Interpretation : This dual-reporting practice constitutes a systemic servicing manipulation scheme, wherein XXXX-controlled entities distort loan performance data for profit. 
Externally, the portfolio appears performing, sustaining XXXX reported servicing income and securitization valuations. 
Internally, borrowers are shown as delinquent, generating illegal late-fee revenue and foreclosure leverage. 

These acts violate multiple federal provisions : 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( b ) ( 1 ) failure to credit payments as of the date received ; 12 C.F.R. 1026.36 ( c ) ( 1 ) misapplication of payments ; 12 U.S.C. 5531 ( a ) unfair, deceptive, or abusive acts ( UDAAP ) ; 15 U.S.C. 1692e ( 2 ) ( A ) false representation of debt ; and 18 U.S.C. 1344 ( 1 ) bank fraud via manipulation of custodial funds and investor reporting. 

Supporting precedents include : XXXX v. XXXX XXXX  XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) ; XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX La. XXXX ) ; and CFPB XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX ( consent order ). 
Each confirms servicer liability for misapplication and dual-ledger deception under RESPA and TILA.

Risk Impact and Damages : The harm from this manipulation is quantifiable and severe : 1. Financial Damages {$100000.00} Unapplied Funds : These are payments made in good faith, sequestered by the servicer in suspense accounts in violation of 12 C.F.R. 1026.36 ( c ) ( 1 ). The funds should have been immediately credited to principal, reducing long-term interest accrual and amortization costs. 
2. Derivative and Consequential Damages {>= $1,000,000} : This figure is substantiated by measurable and foreseeable consequences of the servicers unlawful conduct, including : Credit impairment and reputational injury : False delinquency reporting to credit bureaus, lowering XXXX scores and obstructing refinancing or VA program eligibility. 
Emotional and psychological harm : Threatening letters and cure default notices received despite confirmed payments, constituting harassment under the FDCPA and CFPB consent orders. 
Legal exposure and litigation costs : Continuous need to file CFPB, XXXX XXXXXXXX, and AG complaints, compile forensic evidence, and retain counsel due to Shellpoints systemic non-response. 
Time-value losses : Deprivation of use of approximately {$100000.00} in funds since first misapplication. 
Market impact : Damage to borrowers standing with federal guarantors ( VA/HUD ) and impairment of property equity, causing long-term asset depreciation. 
These harms fall squarely within compensatory and punitive categories recognized under : 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( f ) ( actual damages + additional statutory up to {$2000.00} per violation ), 15 U.S.C. 1692k ( a ) ( actual and punitive damages for FDCPA violations ), and Common-law tort precedents for bad-faith servicing ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ) ). 

Accordingly, total damages are now quantified as : {$100000.00} ( principal misapplied ) + {>= $1,000,000} ( consequential, statutory, reputational, and punitive ) = {>= $1,000,000} aggregate claim.
