Sub-issue: Applying for or obtaining a modification, forbearance plan, short sale, or deed-in-lieu
Consumer complaint narrative:
In XX/XX/XXXX I contacted the lender Newrez to explain that my payment dates have changed with my employer because my employment changed. This was going to cause my pay days to not line up with the payment dates of the mortgage loan. I would have to at that time pull my loan out of their automatic payment plan. 
I asked if there was any way to change the loan payment due date. They said no only if I refinanced the loan. Due to interest rates that wouldn't have been a wise decision. 
I explained my main concern is that my monthly payment would become late. Then I would get a late fee of {$120.00} added to my due dates which would prevent me from being able to make my full payment. 
I stopped the automatic payment plan set up with Newerz and set up auto pay with my personal bank XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX. Unfortunately, my credit union mailed the loan payment checks to Newrez and by the time my checks cleared for Newrez I started to receive late payment fees of {$120.00} on XX/XX/XXXX. 
I called Newrez in XXXX and asked if they could waive the 1st late payment fee. I explained that with the elate payment fee on my account it is preventing me from setting up automatic payments with Newrez. Their system will not let you make modifications to the auto pay or set up auto pay if there is a late fee on the account or past due money owed. 
They told me to just pay the late fee and then I would be able to set up the auto pay. 
I explained it was my first late payment and that their policy states they can waive the first late payment fee. The representative I talked to in XXXX told me they would waive it after I made my full payment of what was due for the month. I explained to her that If they didnt waive it now then I wouldn't be able to set up auto payments on their website to come out semimonthly ( once every 2 weeks ) and by the time may bank sends them the payment for the month it will be late by on day past their grace period and then there will be an additional late payment fee added to my account and that would once again prevent me from setting up auto pay and also it would prevent me from having enough money the next month to pay the full loan payment with the additional late payment fee.

I told them Im trying to do the right thing ; Im wanting to pay what is owed. I want to set up auto pay semimonthly so my payments will not be late. 
I was told by the Newrez rep to call back after the XXXX payment went through, and they would waive the late payment fee. 
I called back in XXXX after the payment cleared. It did clear late and there was another late payment fee added to my account. This time the rep told me they can only waive the first late payment fee and not the second one. I tried to explain that I was previously told they couldnt waive the first late payment fee until my loan payment was current and the only reason the 2nd late payment fee was added to the account was because I couldnt set up the auto pay on their website until there was no late payment fee so my bank mailed the payment check and by the time it clears it was late. I told them I was told by their rep all I had to do was call back after the payment clear and they would help me. 
Well, they didn't help me. I was charged a late payment fee in XXXX and XXXX. 
I called back in XXXX and explained the above to a new rep from Newrez. She said they dont do waivers of late payment fees. I told her that is not what I was told in XXXX or XXXX when I called. She said there was nothing she could do. I asked to talk to a supervisor. I was transferred to a supervisor. I explained all the above and told her Im trying to set up auto pay but cant on their website when there is a late payment fee. I explained that I paid the late payment fee with my XXXX payment but since I wasn't able to set up auto pay in their system the pay in XXXX was late by one day and now there is another late payment fee and ow I cant set up auto pay again and Im getting trapped in this endless cycle and I just need them to please waive the late payment fee of {$120.00} so I can set up auto pay in their system. She told me she would send up the notes of my problem to a manager and see about getting the late payment fee waived.

The call ended and a few hours later I called back to check the status, and I was told by the first rep I talked to that they dont waive the 2nd late payment fee. I painfully explained my story to that rep again, she said there was nothing she could do, and she transferred me to a supervisor. That supervisor told me she sees the notes in the account, and it looks like I now need to send in a written request for them to waive the late payment fee but would need to make the account current before they would set up auto pay. I explained that was never told to me before that I had to write a written note requesting why I need them to waive the late fee. I explained Ive been calling about this issue for the past 3 months, and Im told something different every time. She told me if I paid the late payment fee it would fix the issue. I explained that I had been told that 3 times before and it never fixes the issue because I cant afford the late payment fee, I cant pay the loan from my bank on time because of how long it take the check to process that they send and I cant set up the auto pay with their bank ( Newrez ) until there is no late fee on the account. She basically said there was nothing she could do and she was sorry. She did ask me to send in a payment at that time, and I explained I couldnt afford it. 
On XX/XX/XXXX I paid the last late payment fee of {$120.00}. I then went on Newrez website to set up the auto pay for semimonthly. At this point in time, I had to pay 3 late payment fees over the course of 3 months and each month I was told by Newerz reps the fee would be waived when I made the account current and each time, they never did that. THEY LIED TO ME EVERY TIME. 
On XX/XX/XXXX I filled out and application on the Newrez website for loan assistance. I had to change home insurance companys this year because my previous company was going to drop my coverage because they no longer provide Dog Bite coverage. I had to find a new home insurance company that offers dog coverage. When this switch happen it caused Newrez to make payment to the new insurance company which put my escrow in the negative. Currently Im {$2600.00} behind on my escrow balance and with my current income compared to what I owe monthly to other debts I can no longer afford my current mortgage payment, and I can not pay into the escrow to make the account current. If they revise my current mortgage and escrow and adjust the monthly payment to increase to pay the balance owed in my escrow it will definitively make my monthly payment even more expensive which will force me to stop making the monthly payments. I have about {$9000.00} in debts I need to pay off so I can afford my mortgage again. I will be able to pay off those debts in 3 months if Newrez is willing to pause my mortgage payments for the next 3 months. I will be able to pay the escrow balance in that time also. If Newrez was to let my not pay my mortgage payments for 4 months I would be able to pay off the {$9000.00} in debts and the escrow balance. If they review my escrow balance in XX/XX/XXXX, which is when they say they will, they will determine the need to increase my escrow monthly payment which will increase my mortgage payment which will effectively put me in a position where I will not be able to pay or afford my mortgage. 
I have not heard back from them on my application for loan modification or payment pauses. I also have no faith in them helping me as they lied to me over and over again about helping me with the late payment fees. Which they never did help me with. 
On XX/XX/XXXX I logged into the Newrez website set up the semimonthly auto pay and Im hoping all will be ok now.

I just need some type of health. If they are willing to pause my payments for 4-5 months it would let me pay off the other debts, I have that will free up the month I need monthly to make the full mortgage payment and pay off the escrow before they increase my monthly escrow payments.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Sub-issue: Trying to communicate with the company to fix an issue while managing or servicing your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
What happened : I am the homeowner of the property for which Shellpoint holds the mortgage. After storm damage from XXXX XXXX, my insurer ( XXXX XXXX ) issued claim proceeds. The first check ( endorsed by Shellpoint ) went stale before I could deposit it due in part to lack of response and delay by Shellpoint to my many written queries for assistance ( copies can be provided ). This check was voided. XXXX then reissued the same fundshalf via XXXX and half by replacement check naming Shellpoint as mortgagee. The replacement funds were disbursed in this fashion due to the delays and the home falling into further disrepair as a result. 

I sent Shellpoint email on XX/XX/year> explaining to them what happened with the first check and explaining to them my concern that the replacement check would be misapplied as 'additional ' funds and would then cause them to re-categorize my claim as a 'monitored ' claim and the would hold the funds in escrow and the money would not be released to me. When they did not acknowledge or reply to my email sent to the address they explicitly instruct clients to send loss-draft concerns to, I wrote again on XX/XX/year> and to date, have not received any response whatsoever. 

I then called the Loss-draft department and as always, was directed to a noisy call center and someone who spoke broken XXXX, someone with whom I had a goodly deal of difficulty communicating. I did my best to communicate with this person, albeit I kept getting put on hold, tried to explain, was told " Yes, yes, will not hold your money, will return check ''. I was uncomfortable with the conversation so I called back, hoping to speak with someone else that could at least speak XXXX. I was able to communicate better, I thought, with the second person who seemed to at least understand what I was saying and said that I " was not to worry, I will document this in your file, Ma'am ''. 

I then created PDF documents I uploaded into Shellpoints insurance portal ( which they acknowledged receipt of ), and in spite of copies of the same being included with the replacement check, Shellpoint still misapplied the funds into escrow. 
Shellpoint has carelessly and negligently misapplied this replacement check as additional funds and diverted it into escrow, instead of endorsing and releasing it to me. This is incorrect : the check represents the same proceeds already approved and already endorsed, not supplemental or new funds. 

In spite of being explicitly told this in documents I uploaded into Shellpoints insurance portal ( which they acknowledged receipt of ), and in spite of a clear letter of explanation being included with the replacement check, Shellpoint still misapplied the funds into escrow. In spite of XXXX phone calls and XXXX EMAIL, they STILL kept the funds that they literally already signed off on less than a month ago. 

I even sent the original voided check back at my own expense by XXXX, further proving these were replacementnot newfunds. Shellpoint ignored this documentation and still withheld the money and discarded the prepaid overnight label that I provided for them at considerable expense to myself. I certainly would not have paid to overnight a check to them for them to keep it, nor would I have paid for an overnight label for them to discard. 

This error has delayed necessary storm repairs and exposed the home to additional damage. My XXXX have done work for which they can not be paid. They are angry, the home is still in disrepair and the good working relationship I have with them is suffering as a result of this negligence. 

On XX/XX/year> I called Shellpoint again regarding the replacement claim check. Initially, my call was routed through the usual call-center process. The call-center representative spoke XXXX clearly and told me that my claim had been classified as a monitored claim because it was over {$40000.00}. I immediately pointed out that the replacement check was for approximately {$15000.00}, and that half of the original funds had already been wired directly to me by XXXX. The representative responded in a patronizing tone, explaining, No maam, it was {$30000.00} plus {$15000.00}, and that is over {$40000.00}, effectively treating the replacement check as additional money rather than the reissue of the same funds already approved and endorsed. 

When I mentioned that I was preparing to file a CFPB complaint, my call was escalated to a supervisor named XXXX XXXX. XXXX placed me on hold to review the file, then returned with the same incorrect position, treating the replacement check as if it were additional funds. I pushed back and reminded her that I had already provided extensive documentation proving this was not new funding, including : XXXX. Multiple emails from XXXX confirming the reissue process, XXXX. Uploads through Shellpoints own insurance portal with photos of the original endorsed check clearly marked VOID, XXXX. A letter of explanation included with the replacement payment, and XXXX. The actual original endorsed check itself, enclosed so they could confirm it had never been cashed. 
XXXX eventually acknowledged that she could see the paperwork in their system and that the replacement check should not have been escrowed. I also raised the issue that I had paid for and provided my own FedEx overnight label to expedite the process, but Shellpoint discarded it, insisting we dont do FedEx. As a result, their mishandling has caused even further delay while the funds are routed through their slower XXXX system. 

The bottom line is that Shellpoint admitted the funds were misapplied, but their error has already resulted in weeks of unnecessary delay. Their continued insistence on treating a replacement check as additional funds directly contradicts the documentation they had in hand. 

At this time, Shellpoint has emailed me a tracking number. However, their insurance portal continues to reflect that my funds are in my restricted escrow account, an inconsistency that underscores the continued gross mishandling of my claim and represents a dereliction of their fiduciary duty to my claim.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am submitting this formal complaint against Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ( dba NewRez LLC ) for repeated inaccurate, misleading, and deceptive servicing practices regarding my mortgage loan. 
This includes falsely acknowledging and responding to inquiries/disputes I never submitted, mischaracterizing prior communications sent to other servicers ( XXXX XXXX XXXX and NewRez LLC ) as directed to them, and providing contradictory/inaccurate information about loan ownership and status. 
This also includes sending a deficient inquiry response masquerading as a " Validation of Debt '' letter, which fails to meet FDCPA requirements for proper debt validation and instead frames it as a reply to a non-existent QWR/dispute under RESPA/Regulation X XXXX 
Below, I outline all the key issues in detail, including the concrete limitations of Shellpoint 's XX/XX/XXXX letter as a claimed " Validation of Debt '' notice, broken down point-by-point using the exact requirements of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) validation notice under 15 U.S.C. 1692g and Regulation F ( 12 CFR 1006.34 ). These issues demonstrate systemic inaccuracies that have created material errors in my loan records, potentially impacting servicing, credit reporting, payments, or future obligations. 
Detailed Outline of Key Issues : XXXX. No Correspondence Sent to Shellpoint by Me I never sent any inquiries, Qualified Written Requests ( QWRs ), Notices of Error, written disputes, or other correspondence to Shellpoint. All prior requests went to XXXX XXXX XXXX and NewRez LLC only. Despite this, Shellpoint has falsely characterized and responded to non-existent submissions as if they were formal disputes directed to them under RESPA/Regulation X. This mischaracterization is a foundational inaccuracy in their communications. 
XXXX. False Acknowledgment in the XX/XX/XXXX Letter Shellpoint 's XX/XX/XXXX letter falsely states : " this letter is to acknowledge your recent inquiry regarding the above referenced loan. '' It also claims that, if seeking creditor information, the owner is XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX at XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. No assignment to XXXX XXXX Loan XXXX XXXX is recorded in public county records. This letter invents a " recent inquiry '' from me that never occurred, creating a false record of borrower-servicer interaction. 
XXXX. Inaccuracies and Deficiencies in the XX/XX/XXXX " Validation of Debt '' Letter ( Reference No. XXXX ) This letter, titled " Validation of Debt '' but not functioning as such, falsely states it is " in response to your inquiry '' ( none sent ) and claims Shellpoint is/was the servicer for XXXX XXXX Loan Acquisition LP ( " XXXX XXXX XXXX '' ). It lists the loan owner as " XXXX XXXX XXXX '' at XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, with details including principal balance {$0.00} ( exclusive of accrued interest, fees, or charges ), origination XX/XX/XXXX with XXXX XXXX, original principal {$580000.00}, maturity XX/XX/XXXX, and notes the loan transferred from Shellpoint servicing to XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX. Enclosures included Note, Deed of Trust, " Goodby Letter, '' and Loan History. 
o The " FNMA XXXX XXXX '' reference is inaccurate/misleading : Fannie Mae sold non-performing loan pools ( FNMA XXXX XXXX ) in bulk to private investors ( e.g., RCF II-associated entities ), removing them from Fannie Mae ownership. " FNMA XXXX XXXX '' is a historical sale identifier, not a current owner. Ownership claims conflict with no recorded assignment to RCF II and public practices for such pools. 
o Shellpoint treated non-existent submissions as formal disputes under XXXX XXXX, claimed to investigate them as QWRs, asserted they lacked sufficient detail, and denied servicing errorsdespite no submission from me. 
o As a purported debt validation, the letter is deficient and masquerading as compliant. 
Concrete Limitations of the XX/XX/XXXX Shellpoint Letter as a Claimed " Validation of Debt '' Notice XXXX. Missing the mandatory " debt collector '' disclosure Required : The letter must clearly state that it is from a debt collector ( or use language substantially similar to : " This communication is from a debt collector '' ). 
In this letter : Completely absent. Nowhere does it say Shellpoint is acting as a debt collector or that the communication is from XXXX. 
Result : Fatal defect. This alone disqualifies it as a valid FDCPA validation notice. 
XXXX. No statement of XXXX dispute rights Required : Must include clear language such as : '' Unless you notify this office within XXXX  days after receiving this notice that you dispute the validity of the debt, or any portion thereof, the debt will be assumed to be valid by the debt collector. '' " If you notify this office in writing within XXXX  days from receiving this notice that you dispute the validity of this debt, or any portion thereof, this office will obtain verification of the debt or obtain a copy of a judgment against you and a copy of such verification or judgment will be mailed to you by the debt collector. '' " Upon your written request within the XXXX period, this office will provide you with the name and address of the original creditor, if different from the current creditor. '' In this letter : XXXX mention of any XXXX dispute window, verification process, or original creditor request. Instead, it tells me the alleged " dispute '' ( which I never sent ) lacks detail and that they found no servicing error. 
Result : No dispute rights are communicated not a validation notice. 
XXXX. No " validation period end date '' or clear XXXX clock Required : The letter must specify when the XXXX period ends ( or at minimum make the timeline obvious ). 
In this letter : No date is given for when any dispute period starts or ends. 
Result : No clock is set fails. 
XXXX. Incomplete / non-compliant debt amount and itemization Required : The current amount of the debt as of a specific date, plus either : A full itemization ( principal, interest, fees, etc. ), or A reference to a recent periodic statement under Reg Z 1026.41 ( for mortgages ). 
In this letter : Only gives " {$0.00} ( exclusive of accrued interest, fees, or other charges ) ''. No total amount due is stated. No itemization of the excluded items ( e.g., accrued interest at 7.00 %, fees, or other charges ). No reference to a recent periodic statement under Regulation Z. The exclusions make the figure meaningless for debt validation purposes. 
Result : Does not provide the actual debt amount I would need to dispute or pay. 
XXXX. Wrong framing and timing Required : A validation notice must be sent within XXXX  days of the debt collectors initial communication with the consumer regarding the collection of the debt ( or be the initial communication itself ). 
In this letter : Explicitly frames itself as a response to " your inquiry '' and " your dispute '' meaning it assumes prior contact and treats this as a follow-up. A true validation notice is proactive, not reactive. 
Result : Can not be an initial validation notice because it presupposes prior communication. 
XXXX. XXXX language dominates not FDCPA What it does instead : Spends most of the letter explaining why certain questions are outside the scope of a Qualified Written Request under RESPA/Regulation X , directing me to public records ( SEC , county recorder ), refusing to provide internal documents, and concluding no servicing error occurred. 
Result : This is clearly written as a RESPA response letter ( or partial denial ), not an FDCPA validation notice. The XXXX laws have different triggers, obligations, and content requirements. 
Bottom-line concrete summary : This letter is not and can not reasonably be considered a valid FDCPA debt validation notice because it fails every single core mandatory element : No debt collector disclosure ; No XXXX dispute/verification language ; No end date for the validation period ; No complete debt amount or proper itemization ; Wrong timing and framing ( response, not initial notice ) ; Focused on RESPA limits instead of FDCPA rights XXXX It is a defective RESPA/QWR response that Shellpoint has dressed up with the label " Validation of Debt '' but it does not satisfy the legal requirements to trigger the FDCPA 's validation protections or obligations. Shellpoint failed to properly validate the debt under FDCPA. It is not a compliant validation, so any collection activity after an actual FDCPA dispute could remain improper until they send a proper notice and verify. 
XXXX. Shellpoint 's Well-Documented Pattern of Similar Issues and Complaints Shellpoint has a history of engaging in the types of practices described above, as evidenced by high volumes of consumer complaints and regulatory actions : o High volumes of CFPB complaints : Frequently tops or ranks high in mortgage/home-equity complaints ( e.g., XXXX in XXXX XXXX, XXXX in XXXX XXXX, XXXX in XXXX XXXX for home-equity alone ; earlier peaks like XXXX in certain quarters post-acquisitions/transfers ). Common themes include trouble during payment process, inaccurate information, struggling to pay mortgage, servicing transfer errors, misapplied payments, deceptive communications, and inadequate responses. 
o Enforcement actions : CFPB fined Shellpoint {$2.00} XXXX in XXXX for misrepresenting loan modification program terms to borrowers. 
o Class action settlements : {$500000.00} in XXXX for misleading mortgage statements sent to CARES Act forbearance participants ( violating FDCPA/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. Other suits involve illegal inspection fees ( e.g., XXXX findings of over {$270000.00} unlawfully charged ), unauthorized forbearance placements, inaccurate credit reporting, force-placed insurance errors, and deceptive default notices. 
o Ongoing litigation/complaints : Multiple class actions and consumer reports allege deceptive practices, unauthorized fees, inaccurate debt validation/ownership claims, poor record-keeping during transfers, and failure to correct errors ( e.g., high XXXXConsumer ratings averaging XXXX stars, with hundreds of reviews citing fraud, unethical behavior, and predatory servicing ). 
I have sent Shellpoint a corrective letter disputing these inaccuracies and putting them on notice of this CFPB complaint. However, I have escalated to the CFPB for formal investigation and resolution.

Consumer complaint narrative:
To the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, am pleading for your urgent assistance. My mortgage servicers mishandling of my account has placed me, my son and my fianc in a living nightmare. I have sent multiple emails and made repeated calls, yet they still attempted foreclosure on my home. They failed to pay my escrow in a timely manner, which caused my homeowners insurance to be cancelled during an active disaster claim. Now they are attempting to force me into overpriced force-placed insurance.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, NY XXXX XX/XX/year> Re : Defense of the Foreclosure Abuse Prevention Act ( FAPA ) and Its Retroactive Application Dear CFPB, I am a New York homeowner who has been defending against foreclosure for many years. I write today to urge you to stand firmly in defense of the Foreclosure Abuse Prevention Act ( FAPA ) and, most importantly, its retroactive application.

For too long, large financial institutions and their foreclosure law firms have abused homeowners through endless litigation gamesserial filings, voluntary discontinuances, and repeated acceleration and de-acceleration of the same loan. Families like mine have lived for more than a decade under the crushing weight of lawsuits that should have been barred years ago. Without retroactivity, the very abuses FAPA was designed to stop will continue to punish those of us who have already suffered most. 
In my own case, I have endured repeated filings by banks and servicers, nine separate settlement conferences, and years of uncertainty that robbed my children and me of peace of mind. I have faced intimidation, wrongful credit reporting, and contradictory claims about who even owns my loan. These are not technicalities. They are human costslost time with family, financial devastation, and the constant fear of losing ones home. 
Retroactive application of FAPA is essential because the misconduct happened in the past. To deny retroactivity would reward banks and servicers who already manipulated the system, while leaving families unprotected. That would turn justice on its head. 
Banks argue that retroactivity strips them of vested rights. But the real vested rights are those of New York families to live free of stale and abusive lawsuits. The Legislature passed FAPA precisely because of this abuse. If retroactivity is stripped away, the law becomes a hollow promise, fixing the future while abandoning the families whose suffering demanded reform in the first place. 
I respectfully ask you to continue to defend FAPA in the courts and in the public arena, and to make clear that its protections apply retroactively. Thousands of New York families are counting on this law to finally put an end to abusive foreclosure practices. 
Thank you for your commitment to fairness, justice, and the protection of New Yorkers. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX Homeowner  & Mother of XXXX
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

XXXX ) NewRez is actively creating false delinquency, charging wrongful late fees, issuing contradictory payment demands, misapplying payments, and furnishing false credit reporting that contradicts both my bankruptcy and their own internal records. 

This is an immediate risk of wrongful foreclosure on a veterans home based on corrupted data. 

I am asking CFPB to treat this as a priority, high-risk case. 



XXXX. My Mortgage Was NOT XXXX NewRez Is Misrepresenting It My Chapter XXXX bankruptcy ( Case XXXX ) did not discharge or surrender my VA mortgage. 
Schedule D lists NewRez as a secured creditor with approx. {$600000.00} owed. 
I retained the property. 
The mortgage survived bankruptcy. 
I continued to make payments before and after discharge. 

Despite this, NewRez has been reporting to Experian that the mortgage is : XXXX through Chapter XXXX Paid off Closed Never late This is false, misleading, and illegal. 



XXXX. XX/XX/XXXX & XXXX, XXXX Calls : Servicing Collapse After Discharge A. XX/XX/XXXX First Recorded Failure ( Post-Discharge ) On XX/XX/XXXX, I called to make my XXXX payment. Consumer complaint narrative:
FORMAL ENFORCEMENT COMPLAINT CFPB & TENNESSEE DFI Complainant : XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX veteran ) Co-Borrower : XXXX XXXX Respondents : NewRez LLC XXXXb/a Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
Loan No. : XXXX : XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, TN XXXX Date : XX/XX/year> I. SUMMARY This complaint documents Shellpoints continuing and willful violations of the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA ) and Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ). 
Despite multiple properly formatted Notices of Error under 12 C.F.R. 1024.35, the servicer replied only with generic form letters ( see Exhibit F dated XX/XX/year> ). 
Such responses do not satisfy RESPAs requirements and instead demonstrate deliberate avoidance of statutory investigation and correction duties. 



II. FACTUAL CHAIN 1. XX/XX/year> Payment Misapplied A {$5000.00} payment was made and accepted but recorded as two partials ( {$3900.00} + {$1000.00} ). 
Ledger screenshots show no proper crediting and shifting escrow deficits. 
2. XX/XX/year> Recorded Admission Shellpoint agent confirmed {$12000.00} held in unapplied funds, with {$4000.00} refund within 7 days. 
No refund ever received ; instead, borrower received a Notice to Cure. 
3. XX/XX/year> Final Demand for Correction Sent to Shellpoint Compliance, XXXX  to CFPB, DOJ, FTC, SEC, VA OIG, and Congressional offices. 
Demand included restitution, ledger audit, and {$500000.00} damages + {$100.00} XXXX15-day accrual clause. 
XXXX. XX/XX/year> Generic Response ( Exhibit F ) Shellpoint mailed a form acknowledgment : We are working to gather the requested information. 
It did not address any alleged errors, provide findings, or satisfy RESPA 1024.35 ( e ). 
This constitutes a procedural default and a continuing violation. 
XXXX. XX/XX/year> Formal Notice of Error Re-Issued Reiterated violations and included supporting screenshots and recordings. 
XXXX. XX/XX/year> XXXX XXXX Tennessee DFI confirmed it opened a formal review based on CFPB complaints and attachments. 
XXXX. XX/XX/year> Failure-to-Respond Notice Filed Complainant notified Shellpoint that generic acknowledgments do not satisfy 1024.35 ( e ) ( 3 ) and that damages would continue to accrue. 



III. APPLICABLE LAW 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( ii ) : Failure to credit payments as of date received. 
12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( e ) ( 3 ) : Failure to investigate and respond with written findings within 30 days.

12 U.S.C. 2605 ( k ) ( 1 ) ( C ) : Duty to maintain accurate account information.

12 C.F.R. 1026.36 ( c ) ( 1 ) : TILA obligation to apply payments upon receipt.

38 C.F.R. 36.4350 ( c ) : VA servicer duty to apply payments promptly for veteran borrowers.

15 U.S.C. 1692e ( 2 ) ( A ) : False representation of amount or status of debt.

12 U.S.C. 5531 : Prohibition on unfair or deceptive acts or practices ( UDAAP ). 



IV. EVIDENCE OF BAD FAITH Exhibit F Shellpoint Letter ( XX/XX/year> ) A form letter addressed to Dear Homeowner ( s ), containing no error discussion or correction. 
This document is proof of systemic failure to comply with federal mortgage-servicing standards and will be submitted with audio recordings and portal screenshots as corroboration. 



V. DAMAGES AND REMEDY DEMAND 1. Base Damages : {>= $1,000,000} for financial injury, credit reporting harm, and emotional distress. 
2. Unapplied Funds : {$100000.00} retained without application or interest. 
3. Continuing Damages : {$100000.00} per 15-day interval of non-compliance after XX/XX/year>. 
4. Mandatory Relief : Full ledger audit and application of all funds as of original receipt dates. 
Suspension of any collection or foreclosure activity pending correction. 
Removal of negative credit entries resulting from these violations. 



VI. REQUESTED REGULATORY ACTION The Complainant requests that the CFPB and Tennessee DFI : 1. Issue a civil investigative demand to NewRez LLC and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
2. Order immediate borrower restitution and account reconciliation.

3. Initiate multi-agency referral to DOJ Civil Fraud and VA OIG for systemic servicing abuse.

4. Require public disclosure of findings under CFPB Supervision and Examinations policy. 



VII. CONCLUSION Shellpoints XX/XX/year> form letter demonstrates reckless disregard for federal law and borrower rights. 
This pattern is consistent with prior CFPB enforcement actions against NewRez for servicing failures and requires urgent regulatory sanction and consumer relief. 

Respectfully submitted, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, TN XXXX Date : XX/XX/year> XXXX

My mortgage loan originated on XX/XX/XXXX. It was recently transferred to XXXX in XXXX. Upon transfer, a Newrez agent informed me the loan maturity date is XX/XX/XXXX. This is a 49-year term loan on a loan originated in XXXX, which is a significant error.

On XX/XX/XXXX, I sent a formal Qualified Written Request ( QWR ) /Notice of Error via certified mail which was signed for by Newrez XXXX XX/XX/XXXXXXXX The QWR specifically requested : 1. Life-of-loan amortization schedule 2. Complete transaction history 3. Principal balance breakdown 4. Escrow history 5. Copies of the Notes and Assignments As of XX/XX/XXXX, over 90 business days have passed without a substantive response or acknowledgement. This is a direct violation of RESPA ( 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( e ) ) and Regulation X ( 12 CFR 1024.35 & 1024.36 ), which require acknowledgment within 5 business days and a response within 30 business days. 

I am requesting that the CFPB compel Newrez to provide the requested documentation and correct the maturity date error on my account.

Consumer complaint narrative:
A check with the correct loan number as mailed to the lender back in the month of XX/XX/XXXX. I called the lender to make sure that I was given the correct mailing address and I asked what needed to be on the check to make sure that the payment was properly applied without any issues. I was given the address as the address on the mortgage statement and I was advised to make sure that the loan number was on the check. 

The check was sent in XX/XX/XXXX with all pertinent information as the Shell Point lender advised. The check was cashed by Shell Point on XX/XX/XXXX but the payment was not applied to the loan. However, there were payments received prior to XXXX XXXX, XXXX ( on XXXX and XXXX XXXX that covered XX/XX/XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX payments ). Another payment was made in XXXX but returned for insufficient funds and then paid again on XXXX XXXX, XXXX covering XX/XX/XXXX payment ). 

I sent Shell Point Loss Mitigation an email on XXXX XXXX, XXXX inquiring about the missing payments from the cashed check ( check number, the loan number, the property address, & proof of the cashed payment ) and received no response. I called XXXX XXXX, XXXX and spoke with someone in Shell Point Loss Mitigation they told me to send an email to NewRez proof the cashed check payment. I was told that I would receive a letter in the mail regarding the open investigation. I receive XXXX letters XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX regarding the inquiries being reviewed. I never received a letter that indicated a resolution or need for further information. I called on XXXX XXXX, XXXX and spoke with XXXX reps in Shell Point loss Mitigation and I was advised that the email that I sent on XXXX XXXX, XXXX could not be opened and they asked me to send another email with a pdf file of the proof of the cashed payment to XXXX. I sent the email the same as the conversation and referenced the reps names that I spoke with. Once again, I never received a response. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, the lender hired XXXX XXXX ( a company that specializes in property preservation, maintenance, and repair for residential properties in default or foreclosure ) and someone from the company left a letter on the door that indicated the property was vacant, to contact them in XXXX days if the property was not vacant, and if they are not contacted they will start preservation services including securing the property. When I called Shell Point, Loss Mitigation said the loan was not in foreclosure but it was XXXX  months behind and they hired XXXX to inspect the property. When I explained that they noticed indicated the company would start preservations, XXXX XXXX insist they were there to inspect the property only. When I inquired about the missing cashed payment, they told me that the payments were updated on XXXX XXXX, XXXX and covered XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX payment. I told the rep that XX/XX/XXXX payment was paid on XX/XX/XXXX and reflects the payment was made prior to an edit of the stated XXXX XXXX, XXXX. 

The rep told me that nothing was going to change and that the loan was XXXX  months past due and in danger of foreclosure. I repeatedly asked the rep to explain how an edit made to the loan on XXXX, XXXX reflected a payment that was paid XXXX XXXX, XXXX and she refused to explain. I made several attempts to explain how the math did not add up to fit her explanation. When I asked for a supervisor, she placed me on an extended hold over totaling over an hour. Then I called back and spoke to a male that asked me I resided in the property and I told him that the property was not vacant multiple times. The male rep insist he was going to note that I did not answer the question. He asked me another question that I answered, and again he stated he was noting that I did not answer his question, and when I told him that he was noting that I did not answer him when I did. He accused me of telling how to do his job. I asked to speak with his supervisor and the rep asked me why. I told asked him if he didn't hear the way he was speaking to me and he placed me on an extended hold. 

XXXX, Shell Point Loss mitigation stated that he was on the leadership team. I complained about the previous rep and XXXX only said the rep was not supposed to speak to me the way he did. XXXX looked into my issue of the unapplied cashed check and at first told me the adjustment made was to payments applied to the principal only and that {$1800.00} was applied with {$200.00} unapplied. I told him that the math did not add up once again compared to the amount of the check that had not been applied to the loan. XXXX, placed me on hold to research my inquires for the cashed check and ultimately told me that Shell Point still did not have proof the cashed payment and asked me to resubmit the email again. I told him that I sent the same email several times already with not response and they still did not have it. I also asked why they could not research the cashed check with the check number and XXXX told me that only thing he could suggest was for me to resend the email. I confirmed the email that I sent he previous emails as the XXXX and XXXX confirmed that the email was correct. I told him that I did not understand why Shell Point was not willing to do more considering how long it has been for them to apply the payments given the facts and that they have cashed a check with the loan number on it. I specifically asked why no one was willing to follow up. XXXX said that he would follow up XX/XX/XXXX and when they should have the email. But I never heard back. The loan account is passed due because they have not applied the cashed check payments to the loan. 

Today, XX/XX/XXXX, I received an email from a XXXX that stated they could not find the account after I forwarded the original email that contained the loan number, address and check number. They requested the loan number or address. I forwarded them another email with the information included, explaining that I have made several attempts to resolve this issue, etc. Also, I attached the thread of emails to this complaint.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this updated complaint against Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ( Shellpoint ) regarding ongoing issues with the servicing of my mortgage loan, account number XXXX, for the property at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, CA XXXX. Since my previous communications, additional violations have occurred, including another rushed denial of my loss mitigation application and refusal to postpone the impending foreclosure despite federal protections. I believe Shellpoint has violated federal laws, including the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA ), the Consumer Financial Protection Act, and rules prohibiting dual-tracking ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ). Below, XXXX detail the updated events, the company 's misconduct, and my requested resolution. 
What Happened Background on My Loan and Property Value : My original loan in XXXX was approximately {$1.00} XXXX, which I dispute has inexplicably remained around {$1.00} XXXX. My home is valued at least {$4.00} XXXX, with substantial equity that makes foreclosure unnecessary and harmful. The loan is serviced by Shellpoint and held by XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ( XXXX ). 
Recent Hardship and Multiple Modification Applications : I lost my job in XX/XX/XXXX, a clear hardship affecting my payments. I submitted complete applications, acknowledged as such by Shellpoint on XX/XX/XXXX ( complete as of XX/XX/XXXX ), and again on XX/XX/XXXX ( complete as of XX/XX/XXXX ). Each promised a 30-day review and foreclosure protection. 
Pattern of Rushed Denials : Despite these acknowledgments, Shellpoint denied my applications prematurely. The XX/XX/XXXX, denial cited reasons like the approaching foreclosure sale, maximum modifications reached ( I've had three prior ones ), insufficient hardship verification, failed XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) test, excessive delinquency, and other programmatic ineligibility. No additional documents were requested before denial. Similarly, following the XX/XX/XXXX acknowledgment, I received another denial on XX/XX/XXXX, with similar excuses and no opportunity to address issues. This pattern suggests no genuine review is occurring. 
Lack of Communication and Deflection : Shellpoint continues to ignore my emails ( which I can see are opened ) and calls for months. Customer service refers me to the legal department, where attorney XXXX XXXX XXXX insists all communication go through him. He has repeatedly stated no further modifications are possible due to the prior three, ignoring my new hardship. Emails from Shellpoint 's Loss Mitigation XXXX XXXX XXXX ( e.g., in the chain ) confirm receipt but provide no substantive help. Recently, XXXX XXXX from XXXX requested a statement, underscoring Shellpoint 's failures. 
Foreclosure XXXX, XXXX, and Rejection of XXXX : The foreclosure sale remains scheduled for XX/XX/XXXX, despite protections granted in the acknowledgments. On XX/XX/XXXX, I emailed XXXX XXXX requesting postponement or cancellation and proposing a {$500000.00} short payoff settlement to resolve everything. On XX/XX/XXXX, he rejected the offer, reiterated ineligibility for modification, and refused to postpone the sale, stating " no reason to further postpone '' despite the active review period ( which should end around XX/XX/XXXX, per the XX/XX/XXXX letter ). This appears to be stalling to force foreclosure, violating dual-tracking prohibitions. 
Legal Action : I filed a verified complaint in XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( Case No. XXXX ) on XX/XX/XXXX, alleging dual-tracking, HBOR violations XXXX slander of title, emotional distress, and more. Shellpoint 's demurrer attempts to dismiss it, but these recent events bolster my claims. 

Under RESPA, I am entitled to responses to qualified written requests ( QWRs ) and direct communication, which Shellpoint has denied. 
What the Company Did Wrong Violation of Loss Mitigation Rules : Shellpoint must evaluate complete applications fully, considering new hardships like my job loss ( 12 CFR 1024.41 ). Denials based solely on prior modifications or without requesting needed info violate these rules.

Failure to Respond to Inquiries : RESPA ( 12 U.S.C. 2605 ) requires timely acknowledgments and responses, which Shellpoint has ignored, deflecting to an unresponsive attorney. 
Dual-Tracking Prohibition : Foreclosure can not advance during evaluation of a complete application. The acknowledgments explicitly granted protection, yet the XX/XX/XXXX sale proceeds, constituting illegal dual-tracking. 
Unfair, Deceptive, or Abusive Acts : Rushed denials, refusal to postpone despite protections, and rejecting a reasonable settlement feel abusive, especially with my equity and hardship. This ignores CFPB guidelines and appears designed to foreclose.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Urgent Request for FHA Escalation Escrow Deficiency Hardship Due to Delayed County Tax Assessment Loan Number : XXXX Borrower : XXXX XXXX Property Address : XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX FHA Case Number- XXXX To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to urgently request an FHA escalation and formal review of my escrow deficiency under the applicable HUD guidelines. My name is XXXX XXXX, borrower of the above-referenced FHA-insured loan XXXX serviced by NewRez. 

My escrow account recently incurred a deficiency of {$19000.00}, which was paid to XXXX XXXX as a result of a delayed and retroactive reassessment of four years of property taxes ( XXXX ) on my newly built home. The county failed to apply the correct tax valuation for several years, and the correction was only made this year. As a result, a large lump-sum tax bill was drawn from my escrow account. 

This unexpected deficiency caused my monthly mortgage payment to increase from approximately {$1200.00} to {$2900.00}, creating an immediate and severe financial hardship. I am current on my mortgage and have a strong payment history, but the new payment amount is not sustainable. 

FHA/HUD GUIDELINE SUPPORT To support my request, below are the exact FHA/HUD provisions that apply to my situation : 1. HUD Handbook 4000.1 II.A.1.k.iii ( E ) Escrow Shortages HUD states that when a servicer identifies an escrow shortage : The Mortgagee may require the Borrower to repay the shortage amount in equal monthly payments over a period of up to 12 months or a longer period if necessary to avoid borrower hardship or if the shortage is unusually large or the result of a non-recurring or extraordinary event. 
This applies directly to my situation since : The shortage is unusually large, It resulted from an extraordinary, non-recurring county reassessment, and Immediate repayment over 12 months clearly imposes hardship. 

My Wife lost her job due her position not needed anymore and caused a burden month in month out to stay on top of my bills and my XXXX beautiful children XXXX And XXXX Which are Waiting For XXXXs. ( I may not have one if this does not get situated ) 2. HUD Handbook 4000.1 II.A.2.a.iv ( C ) Servicer Responsibility for Hardship Review This section requires servicers to : Evaluate the Borrowers circumstances and provide payment solutions consistent with FHA requirements when the Borrower experiences a financial hardship outside of their control that threatens their ability to sustain mortgage payments. 

My hardship is directly tied to a government administrative delay and not borrower behavior. 

3. HUD National Servicing Center Guidance Escrow Related Loss Mitigation HUD servicing policy notes that servicers must : Offer an affordable repayment arrangement for escrow shortages when the shortage was created by unforeseen circumstances not caused by the borrower. 

This is exactly my situation. 

MY REQUEST UNDER FHA GUIDELINES Based on the above HUD provisions, I respectfully request : 1. FHA acknowledgment that this escrow deficiency resulted from a county error and qualifies as a non-recurring, extraordinary event under HUD 4000.1 II.A.1.k.iii ( E ).

2. Authorization or instruction to my servicer ( NewRez ) to offer a repayment plan of 3660 months, consistent with HUDs allowance for extended repayment periods in hardship or extraordinary circumstances. 
This extended timeline is the only way for me to remain current and maintain sustainable homeownership. I am fully committed to paying what is owed, but the 12-month repayment period is not feasible.

REQUEST FOR NEXT STEPS Please advise what documentation or additional information is needed to complete this escalation. I appreciate your urgent attention to this matter, as the current payment amount is not sustainable and timely support is essential. 

Thank you for your assistance. 

SincerelyXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative: Our home was rendered unlivable by XXXX  XXXX late last year. We worked out a disaster forbearance agreement with our mortgage servicer at the time, XXXX XXXX. This lasted 90 days and renewed a few times, until ending XX/XX/XXXX. At this same time ( start of XX/XX/XXXX ), our mortgage servicing was transferred from XXXX XXXX to Shellpoint Mortgage Services. Shellpoint, so I'm told, continued the disaster forbearance for 1 month. After ending it with no options to ensure our credit remained intact, they reported us delinquent on the loan 120+ days, I think at the end of XXXX. There was no contact about this that either my wife or I can recall, no demand to pay the money " or else '', nothing. They just reported us as delinquent on a plan originally worked out to help us recover from a natural disaster. On XX/XX/XXXX Shellpoint called us to discuss the loan modification, we agreed and made a payment immediately. There was no discussion during this call or at any other time about our credit getting destroyed. We would have been able to catch the loan up in full if notified/requested, but that never happened. We are now stuck unable to buy a new home for a year due to the delinquency reported on our credit, when our own home was first damaged by a hurricane, then burned down on XX/XX/XXXX. During our hardship, we proactively reached out to both mortgaging servicers to make sure everyone was kept in the loop during major events such as the home fire, and periodically throughout, we answered when they contacted us, and when they told us the forbearance was over and a new agreement and payment was required, we did it. In short, we did everything asked of us and then some, yet we have still been unfairly punished by Shellpoint. To remedy, all we care about right now is getting that 120+ day delinquency off of my ( and my wife 's ) credit, because no mortgager will work with use while that exists. We did what was asked of us and don't deserve to be treated this way. We'll happily work out any kind of payment arrangement with Shellpoint, including paying the full amount we are behind ( or the modified loan terms, we're flexible ), to make this happen. This was communicated to a supervisor ( XXXX, didn't catch last name ) just now XX/XX/XXXX and we were told there is nothing he can do. Please help us get our credit fixed by having that delinquency removed, which will allow us to get a home and finally get some sense of normalcy back.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Summary I am filing a complaint concerning Newrez 's mismanagement of my VA loan escrow account, specifically regarding an unjustified homeowners insurance estimate and inconsistent escrow calculations. 

Detailed Incident Description : On Saturday, XX/XX/XXXX at XXXX Newrez notified me via email that my homeowners insurance renewaldue XX/XX/XXXX, XXXXwould cost {$3300.00}. 
In XX/XX/year>, Newrez paid {$1200.00} to XXXX for insurancemaking the new estimate 170 % higher, but without providing any explanation for this rise. 
When contacted by telephone XX/XX/year>, Newrez was unable to clarify how they reached the {$3300.00} estimate. A second phone call for follow-up, a representative, XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/year> recorded line claimed they received a bill from insurance. 
However, on XX/XX/year> my insurance agent and XXXX confirmed that no insurance evaluation or billing has been completed for the upcoming year. 
My escrow account balance is insufficient to cover this projected amount, yet Newrez is collecting {$580.00} monthly. 

Pattern of Escrow Mismanagement Newrez has inconsistently estimated and collected escrow amounts in the past. 
After I deposited funds to cover a tax shortfall from XXXX XXXX, Newrez refunded the amount, then increased my monthly escrow payments again without justification. 

Regulatory Citations 1. VA Loan Servicing Guidelines ( XXXX  and XXXX  Handbooks ) : Servicers are required to manage escrow accounts responsibly, including ensuring accurate payment of insurance premiums and responding to borrower inquiries about escrow and insurance in accordance with VA regulations and RESPA standards. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ] VA Handbook XXXX XXXX XXXX mandates that servicers maintain accurate escrow analysis for both taxes and insurance and must apply escrow funds appropriately. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 2. RESPA & CFPB Regulations : Under 12 CFR 1024.17 ( Escrow Accounts ), servicers must conduct annual escrow analyses and ensure any shortages or overages are clearly explained and documented.

Shellpoint charged more than {$12000.00} in foreclosure-related fees in XXXX months My monthly statements show escalating fees from XXXX 2025, including : Attorney Fees : {$1600.00} {$1600.00} {$1600.00} {$1900.00} Foreclosure Costs : multiple FC charges rising to {$3100.00} Filing Fees : charged twice for a total of {$2000.00} Property Inspections : {$30.00} per month ballooning into {$510.00} balance These totals exceed {$12000.00}. The foreclosure was only filed and served, with no hearings, no motions, no litigation. 

XXXX. I paid {$11000.00} toward the arrears and an additional {$5400.00} yet the reinstatement amount is not decreasing correctly I made : {$11000.00} down payment {$5400.00} additional payments However, Shellpoints statements show : Reinstatement amounts fluctuating inconsistently Large fees absorbing my payments instead of applying them to principal & interest No proper reflection of the payments I made No reduction of default as required under the mortgage contract and federal law XXXX. Shellpoint appears to be misapplying payments Federal law requires payments to be applied first to : Principal Interest Escrow Late charges Fees Instead, Shellpoint appears to be : Routing payments into fees first, not principal/interest Allowing charges to accumulate faster than I can pay Obscuring how payments were allocated Increasing the reinstatement amount despite substantial payments This violates 12 CFR 1026.36 ( c ) ( 1 ), RESPA, and Regulation X.

4. Shellpoint charged unearned and anticipatory fees There was no legal activity in the foreclosure case to justify : 4 months of repeated attorney flat fees Thousands in FC costs Multiple filing fee charges Inspections totaling {$510.00} Regulation X prohibits : duplicated default fees padded foreclosure fees unearned legal costs anticipatory/estimated fees costs not actually incurred XXXX. These servicing errors create material financial hardship Because Shellpoint is : inflating the reinstatement amount misapplying my payments adding unearned fees failing to properly credit the {$16000.00} Ive already paid I am unable to accurately reinstate the loan and avoid foreclosure. 

This is causing severe financial and emotional distress and undermines home retention efforts.

Sub-issue: Closing disclosure or other related disclosures
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, I sent a Qualified Written Request for a VA loan for information on the assignments, chain of title, and other pertinent information from a servicer that had a different address than the promissory note. No response after XXXX  days. On XX/XX/XXXX I sent a notice with an opportunity to cure defects that had been found, no response in XXXX  days. Sent a notice of default on XX/XX/XXXX, for failure to respond with requested information violating Respa. During this period a certified mail document came that did not include all the required document validation and a notice from this servicer that they were not required to send these documents. All green cards from certified mail have been returned. 

As this was happening, a forensic audit was performed and documents came in showing potential issues with chain of title, defects in assignments that were not recorded, and additionally separation of the mortgage and note as undisclosed securitization trust XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  was found to be holding XXXX of these documents while the servicer was claiming to hold the other one and enforce a loan. Supreme Court has ruled with XXXX v. XXXX that these mortgage and note can not be separated. With the addresses not matching, the closing documents, and no assignments made in public records to either of these entities, I have not made a payment due to fraud and additionally hardship from unforeseen events taking place immediately on assumption as well as looking for validation of mortgage servicer. 

Additionally, as this process was happening, my wife started to look into the documents and was found to not be on the title, but was listed on the mortgage. She was not given a homestead consent and the part of the promissory note declarations was not filled out during the closing voiding the contract as this is violation of her rights as this is our only home, a primary home which was also a requirement for the VA loan. This caused multiple days of problems and lost trust in our relationship, almost a divorce as she thought I was responsible for this and deliberate. I was specifically adamant that she would be on the title when going through the process and we had conversations about this before ever going into this VA process. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I sent a Release of Lien and Compromise due to fraud in the contract, No Holder in Due course, non-response and evasion of the QWR, and Respa/Tila violations. I additionally request another QWR, and I included the forensic audit findings and affidavits of the situation as well as fee schedules for violations with a XXXX  days to respond or be in default. As of XX/XX/XXXX, NewRez LLC is in default of the first QWR request, and with a second request to Relase the Lien and Comromise, no response has been made. A green card returned with XX/XX/XXXX on it for acceptance of this. 

On XX/XX/XXXX I then sent a final notice, evidence demand letters, a hardship affidavit, and a co-borrowers affidavit to the mortgage servicer via certified mail, received XX/XX/XXXX via green card receipt, XXXX, requesting release of a XXXX and extinguishment of a VA loan originated on XX/XX/XXXX, due to alleged fraud, lack of funding, and no valid assignment. The notice highlighted a monthly payment demand of approximately {$7300.00}, which I can not pay due to financial hardship ( e.g., rental income loss of {$2300.00}, baby-related costs of $ XXXX $ XXXX, overtime loss of $ XXXX {$2000.00}, and purchase costs of {$9700.00} ). The co-borrowers affidavit, dated XX/XX/XXXX, confirmed their fraudulent exclusion from the property title despite signing the loan documents. I have returned all tacit agreements Nunc Pro Tunc and have not consented to any agreement sent to me by this servicer as there has been no validation from them as a holder in due course or any response they have provided with the chain of title issues. As it sits it has been 55 days and only certified mail response was sent from them on day XXXX without the required documents dishonoring the QWR request. 

Public records and mortgage documents, reviewed as of XX/XX/XXXX, showed no recorded assignment to the servicer or a related trust, and no evidence of funds advanced by the originator, a broker. I acquired certified copies of the XXXX documents which were the warranty deed and mortgage without listing NewRez LLC or XXXX XXXX on any document allegedly violating both state and federal requirements of assignment. 

The servicer has threatened foreclosure despite these unresolved claims, which also involve alleged violations of federal laws ( e.g., Truth in Lending Act, Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act, VA regulations ) due to lack of disclosures and improper title handling. I attempted to resolve this administratively, but the servicers inaction suggests servicing errors and potential fraud. I want the CFPB to publish this description on consumerfinance.gov so that others can learn from my experience. The CFPB will take steps to remove my personal information from this description but someone may still be able to identify me. Learn how it works. I consent to publishing this description after the CFPB has taken these steps. 
Publishing this description will not affect how the CFPB handles my complaint.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern : I am filing this complaint against Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing for inaccurate credit reporting, failure to correct an acknowledged servicing error, and unfair treatment following the refinance payoff of my mortgage. 

Shellpoints refusal to remove a derogatory late payment mark despite having full knowledge that the delay was caused by a third-party settlement company, not me has caused severe and ongoing financial harm. 

1. Background and Timeline I was a mortgage customer of Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing. 

My mortgage was refinanced through XXXX XXXX XXXX, with the closing and payoff handled by XXXX XXXX XXXX, the settlement company selected by Optimum. 

The payoff to Shellpoint was due on XX/XX/year>, but XXXX XXXX XXXX payoff was processed XXXX day late, XX/XX/year>. 

This delay was entirely outside my control as the borrower. I had already completed all loan documents and obligations before the XX/XX/year> deadline. 

2. Shellpoints Improper Credit Reporting Despite being paid in full on XX/XX/year>, Shellpoint reported a late payment to the credit bureaus. This single entry has had a severe and disproportionate impact on my credit standing : A drop of more than XXXX points across all three major credit bureaus ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) ; The appearance of a derogatory mark in early XX/XX/year> ; The potential for higher interest rates and lost financial opportunities as a result of this incorrect reporting. 

I contacted Shellpoints customer service department multiple times to explain that the payoff delay was due to the settlement companys one-day error, not any missed payment or inaction on my part.

Shellpoint representatives acknowledged receipt of the payoff but refused to remove or adjust the late mark, stating that the payment was received after the due date, without considering the documented context or my lack of fault.

3. Shellpoints Noncompliance with FCRA and Servicing Standards Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), furnishers of credit information such as Shellpoint are required to : Accurately report information to the credit bureaus ; and Conduct a reasonable investigation when a dispute or error claim is raised.

Shellpoints continued refusal to correct this inaccuracy, despite clear evidence that I was not responsible for the delay, constitutes a violation of the FCRA.

It also reflects a failure to exercise good faith and fairness in mortgage servicing practices, in violation of the Consumer Financial Protection Act.

4. Harm Suffered As a direct result of Shellpoints actions, I have suffered : A XXXX point credit score decrease, A derogatory tradeline that inaccurately suggests delinquency, Stress, financial disruption, and reputational harm, Loss of access to favorable credit terms and potential denials for future credit applications. 

This situation has caused unnecessary hardship and damage to my financial reputation all stemming from an error I did not cause. 

5. Supporting Documentation I am prepared to provide the following documents to assist in this investigation : Final payoff statement showing payment receipt on XX/XX/year> ; Proof of closing and payment authorization on or before XX/XX/year> ; Communications from XXXX XXXX XXXX confirming the one-day delay ; Correspondence with Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing requesting correction ; Credit reports showing the derogatory mark posted in early XX/XX/year>. 

6. Conclusion Shellpoint Mortgage Servicings actions demonstrate a lack of fairness, accuracy, and compliance with federal consumer protection laws.

As the borrower, I fulfilled every financial obligation on time. The delayed payoff was the result of third-party negligence not my own and Shellpoints decision to penalize me for this has caused substantial and lasting damage. 

I request the CFPBs intervention to ensure the inaccurate information is corrected and that Shellpoint is held accountable for its actions.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint because Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing has violated RESPA / Regulation X and the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) by failing to properly acknowledge my XX/XX/XXXX Notice of Error, and by furnishing multiple materially inaccurate credit reporting entries across all three credit bureaus. These errors significantly harm my creditworthiness and misrepresent my mortgage history. 

XXXX. Failure to acknowledge my Notice of Error ( RESPA violation ) On XX/XX/XXXX, I submitted a detailed Notice of Error through Shellpoints online portal. Under XXXX CFR XXXX ( d ), Shellpoint must acknowledge receipt within five business days. Instead, I received only a generic we received your email message that did not reference a Notice of Error, did not acknowledge the identified errors, and did not confirm an investigation. As of this filing, Shellpoint has not provided a proper RESPA acknowledgment.

2. Materially inaccurate principal balance My Shellpoint statement shows a principal balance of {$190000.00}, while XXXX reports {$280000.00}, overstating my mortgage by nearly {$100000.00}, in violation of FCRA 623 ( a ), Metro-2 standards, and Regulation X 1024.38.

3. Incorrect balloon / deferred balance My statement reflects a balloon balance of {$89000.00}, yet XXXX reports {$110000.00}, a discrepancy exceeding {$25000.00}.

4. Incorrect date opened and original balance XXXX reports a Date Opened of XX/XX/XXXX and an original balance of {$180000.00}. Shellpoint did not service my loan during that period and began servicing only after reinstatement in XXXX. These fields were improperly merged from a prior servicers data. 

5. Improper delinquency reporting Shellpoint is furnishing delinquency history from periods before it serviced my loan. My mortgage was reinstated in XX/XX/XXXX and brought current. Shellpoint may not furnish delinquency information for periods it did not service. 

6. Duplicate mortgage tradeline on XXXX XXXX is reporting two mortgage tradelines for the same loan, with the Shellpoint tradeline containing negative history belonging to the prior servicer. This merged reporting inflates my debt, falsely suggests two mortgages, and violates FCRA 623 and Metro-2 transfer-of-servicing rules.

7. Improper foreclosure remark on a closed account XXXX displays foreclosure proceedings started on the closed prior servicer tradeline, even though foreclosure never completed, never went to sheriff sale, and the loan was fully reinstated through the ERMA program. Shellpoint added foreclosure-related remarks for a period it did not service, creating a misleading and harmful credit representation.

8. Systemic Metro-2 furnishing failures Across all three bureaus, Shellpoints reporting includes incorrect balances, dates, delinquency history, transfer coding, duplicate tradelines, and inconsistent data.

9. Incorrect 30-day delinquency on XXXX XXXX XXXX Shellpoint continues to report a 30-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX on XXXX XXXX XXXX despite this XXXX already being corrected and removed from XXXX following a prior CFPB complaint. The XX/XX/XXXX payment occurred during a temporary repayment plan that I later cancelled and fully cured. Continuing to report this late inconsistently violates the FCRA. 

10. Continued automated repayment-plan notices after cancellation Despite cancelling my repayment plan, curing the account, and returning to my contractual monthly payment, Shellpoint continues to issue automated repayment-plan approval notices. These communications indicate that XXXX systems have not properly terminated loss-mitigation coding and are contributing to the continued furnishing of an incorrect scheduled monthly payment of approximately {$2100.00} instead of my contractual payment of {$1500.00}. 

XXXX reinstated the loan in XX/XX/XXXX and continued making the monthly payments from XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX. Shellpoint began servicing in XX/XX/XXXX while the loan was current and being paid. Despite this, Shellpoint is furnishing foreclosure and delinquency history for periods it did not service and inaccurately reporting a loan modification that never occurred. 

These inaccuracies are materially harming my credit profile and must be corrected.

Date : XX/XX/year> To : XXXX XXXX, XXXX Department Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing Cc : Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) From : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, CA XXXX Loan Number : XXXX CFPB Complaint ID : XXXX XXXX Subject : Rebuttal to Shellpoint Response and Credit Reporting Violation Dear XXXX XXXX, I am writing in response to your XX/XX/year> letter regarding my complaint with the CFPB. Your response does not address the main issue and contains inaccurate statements that are contradicted by Shellpoints own records.

Your letter states that XXXX was not part of the forbearance period. This is false. I relied on Shellpoints verbal and written statements that I could defer the XXXX payment while waiting for disaster relief processing. 



Second, under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, furnishers must report accurate and not misleading information. Reporting a late payment when a borrower was told no payment was due is misleading and violates the FCRA. Court decisions such as XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX Experian XXXX XXXX confirm that even technically accurate reporting can violate the law when it is misleading in context. 



Third, the documentation you referenced does not disprove that a forbearance began in XX/XX/year> or that your representatives advised me to defer payment. I am requesting complete call transcripts and internal servicing notes from XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/year> to verify what Shellpoint agents told me. 



XXXX, Shellpoint failed to act in good faith. I contacted your company multiple times before the payment due date, received assurances that I could defer payment, and followed those instructions. My credit was damaged because of Shellpoints errors. This conduct violates the FCRA and the CFPBs servicing and communication standards under Regulation X. 



I am demanding that Shellpoint take the following corrective actions : Remove the XX/XX/year> late payment from all credit bureaus immediately. 
Provide written confirmation of the correction to me and to the CFPB within 15 business days. 
Produce all internal records, call notes, and documentation related to this dispute. 




Your refusal to correct a clear reporting error despite your own forbearance confirmation and my consistent communication is a serious violation of the FCRA and consumer protection laws. If this issue is not resolved quickly, I will take further legal action against Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing and any responsible individuals for failing to comply with federal law. 



Sincerely, XXXX XXXX Phone : ( XXXX ) XXXX XXXX Email : XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint because NewRez LLC ( dba Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ) has mishandled my request to remove Private Mortgage Insurance ( PMI ) under the Homeowners Protection Act ( HPA ) and failed to provide timely, accurate servicing responses under the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA ). 

I opened a conventional mortgage with NewRez in XX/XX/XXXX. In XX/XX/XXXX, I called NewRez to inquire about removing PMI and was instructed to obtain an appraisal. I paid {$550.00} for an independent professional appraisal and submitted the report, along with the requested documents, to NewRez in XX/XX/XXXX. 

The appraisal ( dated XX/XX/XXXX ) established a current property value of {$760000.00}. Based on my current mortgage principal of {$560000.00}, my current loan-to-value ( XXXX ) ratio is 74.2 % below the HPA-required 80 % threshold XXXX and also under XXXX stated stricter 75 % limit for requests within the first XXXX years of the loan. 
After I submitted the appraisal and supporting documents, NewRez repeatedly delayed their review, sending form letters that the request was still under review without providing any further action or documentation. I followed up through their portal multiple times and received no meaningful response. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I finally reached a helpful customer service representative who apologized and said, This is ridiculous, I am so sorry. She then told me that I could have ordered an appraisal through NewRez for only {$150.00} an option that was never disclosed to me when I originally called and paid {$550.00}. This indicates a serious failure of communication and consumer protection, particularly given the financial and time delays this caused. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, NewRez issued a formal denial of my PMI removal request, but they : -- Ignored the current XXXX of 74.2 % based on the submitted appraisal -- Refused to accept the paid appraisal and instead insisted on a Brokers Price Opinion ( XXXX ) -- Incorrectly cited HPA rules and introduced new requirements never disclosed during the original request process This reflects both a violation of HPA ( improper handling of PMI cancellation requests ) and RESPA ( failure to provide complete and timely responses, failure to communicate servicing information clearly and accurately ). 

Steps I Took to Resolve This - Submitted complete PMI removal request with paid appraisal on XX/XX/XXXX - Contacted NewRez at least XXXX times via their portal with no response - Filed a formal Qualified Written Request ( QWR ) on XX/XX/XXXX - Received denial on XX/XX/XXXX, with inaccurate and incomplete explanation
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Escalation of Inaccurate Credit Reporting Complaint Against Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing Dear CFPB Investigator, I am formally escalating a complaint regarding Shellpoint Mortgage Servicings ongoing inaccurate reporting of my mortgage account ( # XXXX ) under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and Regulation X ( 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ). Despite multiple written disputes, Shellpoint has failed to correct false information or conduct a reasonable investigation. 

Timeline of Events : XX/XX/XXXX : I submitted a written dispute to Shellpoint outlining that my mortgage account was being inaccurately reported as XXXX through Bankruptcy Chapter XXXX. I included supporting documentation showing that I reaffirmed the loan and have made continuous, timely payments. 
XX/XX/XXXX : Shellpoint responded, acknowledging that the account was marked as XXXX through Bankruptcy XXXX XXXX. They claimed the property was surrendered, even though I remain in possession of and continue to pay the loan. 
XX/XX/XXXX : I disputed the accuracy of their reporting and requested that they provide documentation of the XXXX debt and evidence that it the property was surrendered. They are re-aging the account based on the bankruptcy discharge date of XX/XX/XXXX. This is incorrect because the DOFD was XX/XX/XXXX. 
XX/XX/XXXX : Shellpoint issued another response stating that the bankruptcy notation remains for historical reference and that payment data is suppressed. They refused to correct the tradeline or provide documentation proving that the account was XXXX. 
XX/XX/XXXX Escrow Statement : Shellpoints own records show the account was open and current with no delinquencies, which contradicts their reporting to credit bureaus. 

Basis for CFPB Escalation : Shellpoints actions violate the Fair Credit Reporting Act and Regulation X for the following reasons : 1. Continuing to report the account as XXXX through Bankruptcy when the debt was reaffirmed and remains active violates FCRA 623 ( a ) ( 1

) ( A ). 2. Suppressing accurate payment history and reporting a false discharge status constitutes incomplete and misleading reporting under FCRA 623 ( a ) ( 2 ). 3. Failure to perform a reasonable investigation and provide supporting documentation violates 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( e ) ( 1 ).
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:

Issues with Shellpoint's Upload Portal:

No visible upload history or list of previously submitted files is available, preventing independent confirmation of what has been provided over time.
Shellpoint provides no feedback or status update on the reviewed policy (e.g., no confirmation email, dashboard notification, or explanation of deficiencies), which complicates tracking, confuses and misdirects the customer as to what, if anything, was wrong with the proof of insurance upload, and allows Shellpoint to merely continue extorting money through its rigged collection process.
