Regardless of clicking the Submit button or not, this policy was uploaded to the expressinsuranceinfo portal. It should be on the portal for the customer to see. The portal knows of its online existence and should provide status that it is there and needs to be submitted. Although that should not be necessary if the policy is on the portal. The portal should forward this policy on its server to Shellpoint. This is an easy thing to code on the portal, unless it is the intent of this rigged collection to fleece money from the customer.
A lender-placed insurance policy letter dated XXXX disregards the XXXXXXXX upload of XXXX XXXX XXXX  (dated XXXX effective XXXX to XXXX) on the expressinsuranceinfo.com portal. I have definitive proof of this upload with the screenshot in XXXX However, since Shellpoint has never responded to these submissions, I did not send the proof to the designated fax number, XXXX
Pattern of Violations and Non-Compliance:
The Acknowledgment Loop Trap:
The document you uploaded (XXXX) is a standard form letter designed to satisfy 12 CFR  1024.35(d) of Regulation X (RESPA).

The Trap: The law requires them to acknowledge your inquiry within 5 business days (which they did with this letter).

The Violation: The same law requires them to resolve the erroreither by correcting it or explaining why it's not an errorwithin 30 business days (potentially extendable by 15 days).

My Leverage: Since I stated "nothing ever is sent that addresses my inquiries," Shellpoint is likely in violation of 12 CFR  1024.35(e). I should explicitly mention this violation to XXXX XXXXThe Trap for XXXX  - My monthly payment has increased:

My previous payments were XXXXMy new payment due XXXX XXXX XXXX is XXXXn
Warning: If I autopay XXXX for XXXX, it will be considered a "Partial Payment" because it is less than the new required amount. It will sit in the suspense account and not be applied, potentially causing a late fee.

The compliance loop:

They receive my Notice of Error regarding the stolen funds.

They send a template acknowledgment letter stating they are "gathering requested information".

They close the inquiry without ever providing the information, correcting the error, or explaining their determination, as required by federal lawallowing them to continue improperly billing for force-placed insurance through invalid Mortgage Statements, forcing me to comply with these erroneous charges under threats of foreclosure.

This pattern is exemplified by the XXXX delinquency notice, which escalates threats without resolving prior NOEs asserting the invalidity of the underlying charges. Your failure to accept the HOA master policy, as required under the Deed of Trust Section 5 and California Civil Code (Davis-Stirling Act 4775 and 5300), constitutes bad faith, breaching the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. Errors Asserted:

This unwarranted XXXX  ignores proofs and the 72-hour update promise (expired), creating artificial shortages. The XXXX statement (reference: "XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  continues to disregard the XXXX upload and CFPB/certified mail submissions, projecting ongoing FPI charges and increasing the monthly payment to XXXX XXXX XXXX (from previous XXXX  with escrow portion at XXXX due to the artificial shortage. Although my payment oXXXX XXXXXXXX  on XXXX (made under protest to cure the alleged delinquency) was applied to clear the backlog and bring the account current, with current principal balance at XXXX and escrow at XXXX as of XXXX, this application effectively forced me to cover the unauthorized FPI charges through my payment. Total recent unrefunded FPI now XXXX  ($XXXX on XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX), with historical data showing a pattern of disbursements totaling XXXX since XXXX partially offset by refunds of XXXX XXXXesulting in a net consumer cost of XXXX (reference: XXXX XXXX XXXX). These charges violate the loan contract's Section 5 (Loan Charges), which requires refund of any sums collected that exceed permitted limits (reference: enclosed Note in XXXX).
Failure to accept proof of insurance and cancel/refund FPI (1024.35(b)(11), tied to 1024.37(g)): You failed to honor the XXXX within 15 days, refund overlapping premiums, or update my accountviolating timely resolution despite multiple uploads. The XXXX letter (reference: XXXX explicitly adds a lender-placed policy effective XXXX  disregarding the valid upload on XXXX, and fails to comply with the Deed of Trust's Section 5 (Property Insurance), which allows lender-placed insurance only if borrower fails to maintain coverage. This also breaches the Condominium Rider's provisions, which deem the borrower's insurance obligation satisfied by an HOA master or blanket policy, waiving the need for separate coverage and related escrow charges. Furthermore, as servicer for a XXXX XXXXowned loan, you must follow XXXX XXXX guidelines (Selling Guide B7-3-03), which require acceptance of HOA master policies for condominium projects if they meet coverage standards. The policy also complies with National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) Residential Condominium Building Association Policy (RCBAP) standards, recognized by federal law and lenders as sufficient for flood coverage in condominiums. Under California's Davis-Stirling Act (Civ. Code 4775), the HOA is responsible for insuring common areas via the master policy, with annual disclosures required (XXXX), satisfying my individual obligation. Your refusal constitutes bad faith and violates the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. The XXXX  statement confirms ongoing disregard, as it includes an "Important Message" about suspense accounts despite my full payment on XXXX  incorrectly implying insufficient funds. The XXXX notice further compounds this by basing threats on these invalid charges.
Escrow mismanagement (1024.35(b)(7)): This disbursement ignores adequate funds for taxes (XXXX pre-this as of XXXX representing an adequate cushion in the escrow account, with tax disbursement of XXXX  on XXXX  and my disputes, violating 1024.17(k)(2) (proper advances) and creating shortages from your errors. The escrow account history reflects these ongoing lender-placed charges, contributing to a projected shortage and an increase in monthly escrow payments from XXXX to XXXX effective XXXX, plus a $XXXX monthly shortage recovery (reference: XXXX XXXX). The projected escrow activity for XXXX  continues to include monthly lender-placed flood disbursements of XXXX indicating no recognition of the uploaded policy (reference: escrow statement projections). A late charge of XXXX  was assessed on XXXX amid these issues, despite the adequate cushion providing no justification for such a fee, which per the Note's Section 6(A) applies only to overdue payments of principal and interest, not escrow-related shortages. Furthermore, these unauthorized FPI disbursements created an "escrow waterfall" effect, where payments are applied first to escrow items under the Deed of Trust Section 2, causing subsequent payments (e.g., 1XXXX  to appear insufficient and triggering invalid fees, despite timely principal and interest. The XXXX statement's "Important Message" about holding payments in suspense is misleading, as I paid the full billing amount on XXXX, yet it implies otherwise. The XXXX  notice escalates this mismanagement by falsely declaring a delinquency based on these artificial shortages.
Failure to provide accurate information regarding error resolution (1024.35(b)(11)): XXXXXXXX provides no status/feedback, and you ignored the 72-hour promise, misleading on verification timelines. For submitted Notices of Error (NOE), the only responses received are form letters indicating the matter is "under review," with no substantive updates or resolutions provided. The XXXX  notice ignores these pending disputes and provides inaccurate delinquency information.
Recent Unauthorized Escrow Disbursements: Shellpoint has engaged in a pattern of unauthorized escrow withdrawals despite having been provided with proof of a valid HOA Master Policy. The most recent instances of this breach are:
XXXX XXXX deducted for "Insurance Premium Disbursement"XXXX XXXX deducted for "Lender Placed Flood DisbursementXXXX XXXX deducted for "Lender Placed Flood Disbursement".
Total Impact: These three unauthorized transactions alone totaled XXXX This depletion of funds is the direct cause of the perceived escrow shortage and the subsequent invalid XXXX late fee assessed on XXXX These charges represent proximate cause, as the escrow shortage was not due to my failure to pay but Shellpoint's unauthorized withdrawals, violating the Note's Section 5 requiring refunds of excess sums. The XXXX  notice weaponizes these errors to threaten foreclosure.
Improper delinquency notice and foreclosure threat (1024.35(b)(11)): The XXXXXXXX  notice falsely asserts a delinquency and right to foreclose, ignoring pending NOEs and QWRs disputing the charges. This violates 1024.35(e) by failing to resolve errors before escalating, and constitutes dual tracking under 1024.41(f) by advancing foreclosure processes during loss mitigation review (triggered by your notice offering options). As the "delinquency" arises solely from disputed FPI, any negative action, including this abusive notice, breaches RESPA's protections during the 60-day dispute period (1024.35(i)) and California's implied covenant of good faith.
These errors violate RESPA, TILA Regulation Z 1026.36(c) (prompt crediting), FCRA 1681s-2(a)(3) (disputed reporting), and constitute UDAAP (deceptive practices). Demands:

Provide updated escrow analysis (taxes only, adjusting balance to XXXX

Sincerely,XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX This delinquency notice is baseless and harassing, as I've never missed a principal/interest paymentthe "delinquency" is manufactured from your errors. Send via certified mail and portal.'

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX COMPLAINT Regarding : Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Loan # XXXX We have had our mortgage through Shellpoint for XXXX years. On XX/XX/year> we endeavored to make a mortgage payment via phone customer service with Shellpoint of {$3300.00}. My wife gave them the bank account to withdraw the funds, they read it back to her and then gave her the confirmation number XXXX, and told us our mortgage was current. 
Over a week later my wife became concerned because the money for the payment still had not been withdrawn from our account, so she called Shellpoint again. 
On the XX/XX/XXXX call she told them the money had not been withdrawn. They retook the bank account information and gave us confirmation XXXX and told her we were current and everything was fine. 
By XX/XX/XXXX my wife noticed the money still had not been withdrawn. She gave them the bank account number again and they discovered that two of the digits in the previous withdrawal were incorrect. So, they entered the payment for a third time, again telling us we were current, the payments attempts were on file, and everything was fine with the account.

Despite telling us everything was fine and we were current three times, and despite their employee in the Customer Service Department making the error entering the account number, Shellpoint maliciously put derogatory information on our credit report as the length of time it took to resolve their error made our payments over 60 days due. This caused a dramatic drop in our credit scores which dominoed into our being denied credit because of the entry error Shellpoints employee made which we had to rectify without any aid from Shellpoint. 
I wrote Shellpoint and brought their error and subsequently filing derogatory credit information on us to their attention and received an oh, well unconcerned response. They offered no help whatsoever. 
This has left me no alternative but to file complaints to numerous agencies regarding their unfair practices. I would like the derogatory credit information removed, but short of that I would like to put this complaint on their record for malicious and unfair customer service. As I will continue to do to everyone I can find who will listen to me.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

transfer of my loan. 2. All documentation showing how and why Shellpoint converted my FHA loan to Conventional. 3. Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing a complaint regarding Shellpoint Mortgage Servicings handling of my Deed-in-Lieu ( DIL ) request for Loan No. XXXX. Despite my full cooperation and repeated submissions of required documents, Shellpoint has failed to complete the DIL review, has given inconsistent and inaccurate explanations, and has failed to provide the information necessary for me to resolve items they claim are preventing approval.

1. I submitted a complete DIL request beginning in XX/XX/XXXX, and Shellpoint repeatedly confirmed receipt. 
Emails and letters beginning XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, and XX/XX/XXXX show that Shellpoint requested documents, and I consistently provided them, including : Opt-Out form Borrower Assistance Form Hardship letter ServiceLink Authorization Responses to occupancy, condition, and relocation questions IRS form 4506-C Financial worksheet All of these documents were emailed to Shellpoints loss-mitigation address as instructed.

2. Shellpoint identified a single title defect in XX/XX/XXXX, and I provided proof that the lien had been paid and released. 
On XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, Shellpoint notified me that a prior lien from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  appeared on title.

I immediately provided documentation showing the lien had been paid and released. This includes SBA correspondence and lien-release authorization ( dated XX/XX/XXXX ) confirming the loan was fully satisfied and authorizing release of the lien.

Despite receiving this information, Shellpoint never confirmed whether they forwarded it to their title vendor, and they never issued an updated title determination.

3. Shellpoint later claimed my application was incomplete because of title issues, but they never told me what was still unresolved or what actions were required.

After XX/XX/XXXX, Shellpoint stopped communicating regarding the title issue. 
Beginning in XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, Shellpoint again confirmed the DIL process and ordered a title report, but they did not provide any findings or request any additional documents.

At no point did Shellpoint provide a written explanation identifying any outstanding title defect.

4. Shellpoint issued a conditional DIL approval on XX/XX/XXXX, which contradicts their later claim that no complete application existed.

The conditional approval stated that I must provide clear and marketable title, but again, Shellpoint did not specify what issues remained or what was required. 
On XX/XX/XXXX, I submitted the Opt-Out form Shellpoint requested. 
This contradicts Shellpoints XX/XX/XXXX CFPB response claiming the file was incomplete and that no loss-mitigation review was pending.

5. Shellpoint continued foreclosure activity during an active DIL review.

Emails between XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX show Shellpoint actively processing the DIL, collecting documentation, and issuing conditional approvals.

At the same time, Shellpoint continued foreclosure actions.

Shellpoint later claimed dual tracking did not occur, but their own documents clearly show that loss mitigation was ongoing while foreclosure continued.

6. Shellpoint has not provided the documents it claims justify denying or delaying the DIL.

In its response, Shellpoint claimed all supporting documents were included, but the following were not provided : A copy of the title report Shellpoint relied on Any documentation showing unresolved title issues Any written request for additional information after XX/XX/XXXX Any explanation for why the lien-release documents I provided were not accepted 7. Shellpoints repeated references to delinquency conflict with my XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX discharge. 
Shellpoint states the communication is not an attempt to collect a debt but repeatedly states the account is due for payments. I request that Shellpoint clarify that all references are lien-based only and not personal liability, consistent with my bankruptcy discharge.

CRITICAL VIOLATIONS : 1. FDCPA DEBT VALIDATION FAILURE ( 15 U.S.C. 1692g ) I sent comprehensive debt validation demands to Shellpoint on multiple dates challenging : - Amount owed and calculation methodology - Chain of title and assignment documentation - Original creditor and current note holder identity - Shellpoint 's authority to collect/foreclose - Payment history and accounting accuracy Shellpoint FAILED to provide ANY validation within the required 30-day period under FDCPA 1692g ( b ), yet proceeded with foreclosure scheduling. This violates the mandatory cessation requirement - NO collection activity is permitted without proper validation.

2. LACK OF STANDING - SERVICER OVERREACH Shellpoint admits they are merely the servicer, with XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX as Trustee for XXXX XXXX XXXX being the actual beneficiary. Under California law ( Glaski v. Bank of America, Yvanova v. New Century Mortgage ), servicers lack authority to foreclose without proper delegation. No such documentation provided, rendering the entire process void under Civil Code 2924. 

5. PATTERN OF CFPB NON-COMPLIANCE Previous CFPB complaints ( ID : XXXX ) show Shellpoint 's ongoing violations. Their responses demonstrate systematic non-compliance with federal servicing requirements, necessitating immediate regulatory intervention.

IMMEDIATE INVESTIGATION of Shellpoint 's systematic violations 2. EMERGENCY ORDER halting XX/XX/XXXX foreclosure sale 3. MANDATORY COMPLIANCE with debt validation requirements 4. SANCTIONS AND PENALTIES for ongoing federal law violations 5. RESTITUTION for damages, legal costs, and emotional harm 6. REFERRAL to DOJ/FTC for criminal investigation of elder abuse 7. SYSTEMIC REFORMS to prevent future abusive practices This represents a clear pattern of predatory servicing targeting vulnerable homeowners through systematic federal law violations. The XX/XX/XXXX sale date creates an emergency requiring immediate CFPB intervention to prevent irreparable harm.

Consumer complaint narrative:
My mortgage was sold by CMC Funding to New Rez in XX/XX/XXXX. It has been totally mismanaged from day 1. The customer service representatives including managers though for the most part pleasant have been a wealth of misinformation which has caused me financial harm. 
On XX/XX/XXXX, right before the sale I received a letter from CMC Funding showing I had an escrow shortage and my mortgage payment was increasing from {$1400.00} to {$1400.00}. I started receiving statements from New Rez in XXXX, my payment did not increase from XXXX through XXXX remaining at {$1400.00}. XX/XX/XXXX I received a letter from New Rez and a check of {$1600.00} for an escrow excess. I did not cash this check as it made no sense since I was told in XXXX I had a shortage. In XXXX I received my statement and my payment had decreased by {$500.00} to {$900.00} and stayed that way till XX/XX/XXXX. I call about the check I was still holding onto and the decrease in my mortgage on XX/XX/XXXX and was told by the rep it was an escrow excess and I could cash it. This made zero sense to me. I called back on XX/XX/XXXX and spoke with a XXXX who told me to cash the check and pay it back to the escrow from what she could see it looked like a missed tax payment at one point. She would request an escrow analysis and by XXXX and XXXX payments should work themselves out. 
XX/XX/XXXX I spoke with a XXXX who told me the escrow was now short {$2000.00}. I paid back the check for {$160.00} plus an additional {$380.00} to clear the shortage. She was going to reach out to the city to make sure the taxes are being paid correctly. 
XX/XX/XXXX. My mortgage payments are now {$1000.00} after the payments and the new analysis. Why??? They should be around {$1400.00}! Per New Rez rep I spoke with the escrow balance transferred was a surplus form the other company. Payments will stay at this amount until the new escrow analysis in XXXX. 
XX/XX/XXXX New escrow analysis not shows I have an escrow shortage of {$4400.00}. Mortgage payment will increase {$410.00} each month to {$1400.00}. Rep I spoke with said we can do another analysis but this appears correct. I spoke with a manager who said the same thing and was insisting my property taxes increased by $ XXXX.. I explained they absolutely did not and asked for proof before they did redo the analysis. In further discussion they said your taxes are {$7900.00}. I confirmed that as correct. She did a little more digging and said somehow they had y taxes as {$3900.00} which is why my mortgage payments were dropped.The payment was based on incorrect projected taxes, basically half of what I pay in taxes. This was a huge error on their part. She said I could pay all or a portion of the escrow shortage to reduce my payment. 
XX/XX/XXXX Because I was so shocked by all of this I called back and spoke with XXXX who went over everything in detail. She was supposed to email me all the escrow analysises done on my account since summer XXXX but never did. She did confirm from what she was that during the transition New Rez somehow used had the years taxes to project my payments. 
XX/XX/XXXX Spoke with XXXX went over my mismanaged mortgage again and I agreed to pay {$3000.00} toward the escrow shortage as I didn't have the full {$4400.00}. He put in a request for an escrow analysis that will be completed in 5 days. He said this will determine how the additional {$1400.00} shortage will be added to my mortgage. So it was confirmed again that my payments were based on taxes of {$3900.00} and this year taxes are based on {$790000.00}. 
XX/XX/XXXX Spoke with someone about new escrow analysis based on the XXXX I paid. They said it's being done now and to call early next week for your new payment. 
XX/XX/XXXX I called to check on the escrow. The woman I spoke with said your payment is not changing. Unless you pay the full shortage they do not do another escrow analysis.I said then what was the point of me giving you {$3000.00} if nothing is changing.What are you doing with that money? I asked for her to refund me the money since it is better sitting in my bank account than at NewRez. She confirmed that my payment would stay at {$1400.00}. This did not sit well with me so I called back to speak with a different representative in the afternoon who told me yes they do reconfigure your payment if you do a partial payment. I told her I was just told otherwise then the phone was disconnected. I called back and spoke with a different rep, XXXX who told me we do not redo the analysis for a partial payment and confirmed my payment is unchanged and that they are refunding my money. 
XX/XX/XXXX I called again and spoke with a rep who told me it's up to the escrow department when they receive the payment if they choose to redo the analysis. This makes zero sense. 
There is not an opportunity to speak with the escrow department or anyone in charge that has institutional knowledge. The mismanagement of my loan has been horrendous. I feel they owe me at the very least a reevaluation of my escrow with the payment after royally screwing up my payments for a year. The barriers they put up to speak with anyone other than the basic rep are ridiculous. I have asked for emails of our conversation or copies of analysises done and have never received anything. Even the managers I've spoken with are giving incorrect information, that is corrected by the next person you speak with This company is careless and bordering on fraudelent.

Sub-issue: An existing modification, forbearance plan, short sale, or other loss mitigation relief
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to you to request more clarification on the following actions of your company with respects to my loan, following XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX. The following is a timeline of events with my questions for clarification in red. 
( XXXX ) XXXX declared disaster on XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX ) XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX I called to make the payment due XX/XX/XXXX and to ask what my options were for mortgage relief after a disaster. I was told because I was in a XXXX declared disaster zone, I can have 90 days forbearance, with no documentation required. Therefore, I proceeded to NOT make payments for XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, and XX/XX/XXXX due to the disaster forbearance plan that I was told by your representative that I will be placed in. Based on the information given, I was on disaster forbearance and my next payment would be due on XX/XX/XXXX. 
- I called again sometime in XXXX to find out the options after forbearance and the consequences of entering in a disaster forbearance program. I was told that I would need to pay the delinquent amount back in full after the forbearance. The representative was rude, short and dismissive. I was provided with confusing information and told there is no such thing as deferring payments and not paying interest. According to the CFPB, this violates servicing rules by keeping borrowers in the dark about critical information about the process of applying for foreclosure relief. The representatives that I talked to in XXXX were not educated on the current policies for servicing a loan following a disaster. 
( XXXX ) According to Shellpoint documentation, it is confirmed that I called on XX/XX/XXXX to request disaster forbearance but it was indicated by my current point of contact, XXXX XXXX, that I was not actually documented as being in disaster forbearance. This was told to me in XXXX. So my question is when it came time for this initial 90 day forbearance to end, was I documented as just delinquent for no XXXX declared event? Was XXXX XXXX notified that the reason for my delinquency was a disaster? Is it required for XXXX XXXX to be notified that I am in disaster forbearance? How did that affect the fees for property preservation? How did that affect the timeline of foreclosure? Did that affect the manner in which it was communicated to the credit bureaus for the reason of my delinquency? 
( XXXX ) In XX/XX/XXXX, before the initial disaster forbearance ended, I called Shellpoint and was given a loss mitigation point of contact, XXXX XXXX. I explained that I was displaced following the disaster and requested another 90 day extension of disaster forbearance. This representative listened to my hardship concerns caused by the disaster and said she will put me on a disaster forbearance plan for XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX and XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX ( my POC ), who was very empathetic during the conversation, stated that I would not have to make a payment until XX/XX/XXXX because of disaster forbearance! She said that in the most empathetic and understanding way. I am so certain of this that would like you to listen to the recording of the XXXX call. I used the information she provided me to plan and budget for resuming normal payments. And in reality, XX/XX/XXXX was NOT the first day I owed, it was the first day of Foreclosure. She never explained the plan or plans that would result in paying XX/XX/XXXX. I thought I had just received an extension of the first 3 months, resulting in a total of 6 months in disaster forbearance. At this time I was not educated on the possibility of a disaster deferral plan even though I inquired about the consequences of being in a disaster forbearance ( asking how it could affect interest, laid fees, credit reporting, foreclosure? ) I was not explained the XXXX possible solutions on the hierarchy for post forbearance so that I could make plans to choose which is best. 
-After that phone call, I received a letter, dating XX/XX/XXXX, that I was behind on my mortgage by XXXX payments ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) and had been reported to the credit bureaus. Based on my conversation with XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ), I thought this was a normal part of the disaster forbearance process. The letter from XX/XX/XXXX did not mention anything about those months being a disaster related forbearance, but seemed like just a delinquency for a non disaster issue. It was simply to let me know that I was delinquent, which I thought was satisfactory since I was in a XXXX declared disaster area and was assured by XXXX XXXX that I am in disaster forbearance. 
I received a letter dated XX/XX/XXXX, that also appeared in my loss mitigation documents portal. So this is where I assumed that all loss mitigation offers would be sent. It stated that I owed {$0.00} for XXXX, XXXX and XXXX due to a disaster forbearance plan. I was making plans to resume payments on XXXX. XXXX. I made a payment on XX/XX/XXXX, just to be sure that I paid before the end of the 6 months forbearance- which I thought would be the XX/XX/XXXX payment following my forbearance period. Because I did not realize that I was not in disaster forbearance for XXXX, XXXX and XXXX, I thought this was my payment for XX/XX/XXXX. But I believe it was applied to XX/XX/XXXX ( my most delinquent month ). 
More specific correspondence to properly educate me on the options may have been sent by usps, but not through email or the e-mailbox on the platform. All important notifications were either in my e- mailbox or my loss mitigation documents on the portal. Why are some documents mailed while others are sent through regular mail and e- mailbox on the portal? Why was I not educated on the disaster deferral program? This should have been included in the available documents on my loss mitigation portal. I indicated to XXXX XXXX that I was displaced after the storm and to please send notifications and offers to the portal. She agreed. 
XXXX XXXX, I got an email, however no correspondence on my electronic mailbox on the platform, saying that my forbearance is ending. It is time to start planning for end of forbearance options, click this video, that did not work, but I thought I had planned for that and already made that payment that was to be due XXXX. XXXX. I was planning to make another one on XX/XX/XXXX, and be back on track with my regular monthly payment. I was not solicited for a disaster deferral, I knew that I could not repay the default in full, but I was confused on what my options were because the correspondence was really vague and never defined the disaster deferral program or how to enter it. Was I solicited for the disaster deferral program, only through usps? Should it be required that they also send that to the mortgage servicer e-mailbox? How was I solicited for it and educated about the plan? 
According to the servicing XXXX XXXX loans during a disaster, The Servicer must evaluate the Borrower for a proactive offer for a Disaster Payment Deferral in accordance with the eligibility criteria described below. If eligible, the Servicer must send the Borrower a proactive offer for a Disaster Payment Deferral by the XXXX day following expiration of the forbearance plan. You do not have to prove or document anything to Shellpoint to be solicited for a disaster deferral program when you are exiting disaster forbearance. 
The disaster deferral plan should have been solicited to me with the same accessibility as the streamlined modification and BEFORE I was solicited for the streamlined modification, as that causes great confusion. These are deceiving acts to prevent me from choosing the plan that is best for me. 
Before XX/XX/XXXX, I should have been approved and offered a disaster deferral program, the preferred program for my status. On XX/XX/XXXX I received, a solicitation letter, made available on my loss mitigation documents portal and through usps, offering me the streamlined loan modification plan, indicating that I needed to make a modified payment in my trial plan on XX/XX/XXXX. When I was solicited for the streamlined modification plan, I was not sent the solicitation letter that was adapted for post disaster forbearance. 
This offer should have been sent after the disaster deferral agreement ended or if I declined. According to the hierarchy from XXXX XXXX, I should have been solicited for the XXXX XXXX XXXX modification after the disaster deferral offer expired. Why was the streamline load modification solicited to me at this time? 
Was I solicited for the streamlined loan modification plan at that time because at the end of my official disaster forbearance ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX ), I was more than 60 days delinquent due to not being properly documented for disaster forbearance in XXXX XXXX and XXXX To be solicited for disaster deferral you must have been less than 60 days current at the time of the disaster. 
Was I solicited for a disaster deferral plan? Was this mailed to me? Because I am displaced, is it required to have it uploaded on my loss mitigation portal? Why was the streamline loan modification agreement more readily available for me to view on the portal? I have requested a copy of the solicitation/offer for the disaster deferral options but was told by my XXXX XXXX XXXX that I did NOT qualify, based on insufficient information and thus no solicitation was EVER offered for the disaster payment deferral. I would like to confirm that I was proactively solicitated for the disaster deferral program and not just the streamlined modification plan. This should have been done on or before XX/XX/XXXX. Instead on or before XX/XX/XXXX, I was solicited for a streamlined modification by usps and the electronic mailbox. 
I have made the XXXX trial payments for the modified loan and they are currently sending me a loan modification agreement with a total principal balance of a much higher number due to about {$4000.00} interest.

Sub-issue: Changes in loan terms during or after closing
Consumer complaint narrative:
The company that bought our loan after we purchased the home was Shellpoint/New Rez. We financed our home at XXXX. Around XXXX of XXXX my husband was laid off. Forcing us to file for unemployment and food stamps, and needing to enter a loan forbearance program to get by. The forbearance program ended in XXXX and our first payment was due in XXXX. We were originally told to make regular monthly payments while we figured out and decided on what program we would go into once the forbearance was over. Shellpoint would not allow us to make a regular payment, they wanted a single payment of around XXXX and refused to allow us to pay any less than that. It was that or nothing. We first agreed to a repayment plan. The representative was not completing their end of the paperwork, so they would not accept payment from us. I called frequently from XXXX of XXXX checking to see if their paperwork was complete so we could make a payment as we were ready to make a payment and tried to make a payment in XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX. Finally after escalating the issue and demanding to have a different representative on our case, they complied but told us because of their representative not doing their paperwork we now no longer qualified for a repayment plan and we're told we would have to enter a loan modification program, otherwise they would foreclose on our home. We signed as we did not want to lose our home. They accepted payments from us on this new interest rate from XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX while they completed their end of the paperwork. In XXXX of XXXX I was finally able to see details of what our loan looked like. This forced program that we would not have been forced into if it wasn't for one of their employees not completing paperwork in a timely manner added XXXX to our loan; erasing nearly 5 years worth of payments and taking our new principal balance to XXXX. We continued to make payments through XXXX of XXXX, and at closing time they still took a check for XXXX and are currently sending us letters stating we still owe them additional funds. I had called in XXXX of XXXX because the principal balance was not changing as we made payments, also wanting to know where the payments from XXXX of XXXX of XXXX went, and wanting a break down of how this program allowed them to add XXXX to our original loan. They said we signed, so that's just it. We also had no choice but to sign, they would have foreclosed on our home and even threatened to foreclose while accepting monthly payments- their reasoning for the additional threats was that if the paperwork submitted didn't get approved by someone on their team, they would still foreclose anyways. They refused to escalate the issue and allow me to speak to someone else within the company- this information is even stated in the notes from our time with Shellpoint/New Rez. We believe we overpaid by quite a bit. We did some simple math and calculated nearly XXXX in overpayments, we could be wrong as we are not professionals on the matter. 

We would appreciate any help we can receive on trying to recover some if any of our over payment, and we would like to bring light to how Veteran families are being treated by this company.

Sub-issue: Trying to communicate with the company to fix an issue while managing or servicing your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/year>, I submitted a recast request to Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing exactly as their representatives instructed. I mailed : - A {$90000.00} principal reduction check - A {$250.00} recast fee check - A signed recast authorization form - A cover letter making my request clear Shellpoint deposited both checks ( totaling {$90000.00} ) but misapplied the {$250.00} fee to principal rather than recording it as the fee. Because of this error, my recast has not been finalized nearly four months later. 

Since then, I have received contradictory and misleading information : - XX/XX/scrub>XXXX XXXX  : I was told the recast was complete. 
- XX/XX/scrub>XXXX XXXX XXXX  : I was told it was not complete, but that an internal request would be submitted. 
- XX/XX/year> : I was told the same again, with no proof of action. 

To this day, Shellpoint has not provided a written recast confirmation or an updated monthly payment schedule. My funds remain misapplied and my loan is in limbo. 

This issue is part of a larger pattern. Since XX/XX/year>, when I first inquired about a recast, Shellpoint has : - Given me incorrect information on numerous calls, often contradicting earlier statements- Refused to allow escalation beyond frontline reps- Claimed applications or internal requests were submitted when they were not - Failed to document calls in a way visible to me- Ignored written requests unless I involved the CFPB It has now been over seven months since I first asked about a recast, and Shellpoints delays and errors have cost me thousands of dollars in additional interest payments that should have been avoided once the recast was processed. It is not hyperbole to say this has been the worst customer service experience of my life in any industry.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing a complaint against Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing regarding improper lossmitigation handling, dual tracking, and unreasonable demands during my request for a deed in lieu of foreclosure. 

I am the former borrower on a mortgage for the property at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, Washington, DC XXXX. My personal liability on this mortgage was discharged in Chapter 7 bankruptcy on XX/XX/year>. I do not want to keep the property and I submitted a complete loss mitigation package to Shellpoint requesting a deed in lieu of foreclosure. 

Despite submitting all documents requested, Shellpoint continues to move forward with judicial foreclosure at the same time they are processing my deed in lieu request. This appears to be a violation of the federal servicing rules under Regulation X, which prohibit a servicer from moving forward with foreclosure while a complete loss mitigation application is pending.

Shellpoint has now informed me that they need a free and clear deed in order to move forward with the deed in lieu. This requirement is impossible for me to meet because I am not the current titleholder of the property under normal circumstances until the deed in lieu is executed. A deed in lieu is the mechanism that returns title to the lender. I can not produce a free and clear deed before loss mitigation is completed, and Shellpoint knows this. This appears to be an unreasonable and abusive servicing requirement.

Shellpoint is effectively forcing the foreclosure to continue by imposing a condition that a borrower can not meet. This prevents my deed in lieu request from being processed, while foreclosure activity continues in violation of the nodualtracking rule ( 12 C.F.R. 1024.41 ( g ) ).

I want to make clear that I do not want the property and am trying to surrender it. I submitted the requested forms, including Form 710 and additional documentation. Shellpoint has told me the file is incomplete unless I sign a Loss Mitigation OptOut Form, even though I have already requested a deed in lieu. The optout form is typically used to decline loss mitigation, but they are requiring it as a condition of reviewing a deed in lieu. This is confusing, misleading, and appears designed to both move foreclosure forward and avoid offering the deed in lieu option that I am requesting.

I am asking the CFPB to require Shellpoint to : 1. Stop all foreclosure activity immediately while my deed in lieu request is reviewed.

2. Process my deed in lieu without requiring an impossible free and clear deed from me.

3. Confirm in writing whether they will approve or deny the deed in lieu.

4. Stop using forms or requirements that appear to conflict with bankruptcy discharge protections and federal servicing rules.

I am providing copies of communications, my complete loss mitigation application, bankruptcy discharge, and Shellpoints statements regarding the need for a free and clear deed.

Thank you
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am the borrower on a first-lien mortgage loan ( account # XXXX ) secured by my primary residence at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXXXXXX, serviced by NewRez dba Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ( Shellpoint ). Over the past several months, I have filed multiple legitimate complaints with the CFPB regarding Shellpoint 's violations of federal laws, including RESPA ( 12 CFR 1024.41 ), FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692 ), and California 's Homeowner Bill of Rights ( HBOR ), such as dual-tracking, failure to respond to Qualified Written Requests ( QWRs ), improper fee assessments, and denial of loan modification appeals without proper review. 
Shellpoint has consistently responded to these complaints with identical, copy-pasted boilerplate letters that do not address the specific issues raised. For example : In responses to complaints filed on [ list dates, e.g., XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/XXXX, etc. ], Shellpoint reused the same generic language, ignoring my requests for detailed loan history, itemized fees, chain of title, and validation of post-bankruptcy charges. 
These responses often include irrelevant or fabricated details, such as referencing events or dates not related to my loan, and fail to comply with RESPA timelines ( e.g., 5-day acknowledgment, 30-day substantive response ).

Despite this, the CFPB has accepted these non-responsive replies as adequate and closed my cases without further investigation. When I provide feedback or file new complaints highlighting this pattern, the cycle repeats, allowing Shellpoint to evade accountability for their unlawful practices. 
Most recently, on or around XX/XX/XXXX, Shellpoint 's opposing counsel ( from XXXX XXXX ) called my attorney and accused me of " harassing '' Shellpoint through my CFPB complaints. This is an attempt to silence me and deter me from exercising my legal rights to report violations and seek redress. As a consumer, I have the right under federal law ( e.g., RESPA, FDCPA, and CFPB regulations ) to file complaints without fear of retaliation. Shellpoint 's tactics, including this accusation, constitute unfair, deceptive, and abusive acts or practices ( UDAAP ) under 12 U.S.C. 5531, and may violate anti-retaliation provisions.

This patternShellpoint 's copy-paste responses leading to CFPB closures, followed by accusations of harassment when I persistsuggests systemic issues that the CFPB should investigate. It undermines consumer protections and allows servicers like Shellpoint to continue improper foreclosure activities ( e.g., my trustee 's sale is still posted for XX/XX/XXXX, despite ongoing violations ).

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this urgent complaint against Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing for repeated violations of federal and state consumer protection laws, including the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA, 12 U.S.C. 2605 ) and California 's Homeowner Bill of Rights ( HBOR, Cal. Civ. Code 2923.6 et seq. ). Shellpoint 's stonewallingthrough their attorney, XXXX XXXX XXXX of XXXX XXXX prevented me from obtaining basic confirmation of a loan modification package review, while a foreclosure sale on my primary residence is fast approaching on XX/XX/XXXX. This non-responsiveness is beyond the pale, exacerbating my financial distress and risking wrongful foreclosure on a property with over {$2.00} XXXX in equity. I have substantial evidence of these violations, including an extensive email chain attached here, and I request immediate CFPB intervention to halt the sale and enforce compliance.

Detailed Timeline and Violations : Submission of Complete Loan Modification Package : On XX/XX/XXXX, my authorized advocate, XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX, contact : XXXX ), submitted a complete loan modification application on my behalf to Shellpoint. This package included all required financial documentation, as confirmed by XXXX. Under RESPA 1024.41 ( b ) and HBOR 2923.6, Shellpoint must acknowledge receipt within 5 business days and review the application without proceeding to foreclosure ( prohibiting " dual-tracking '' ). Despite this, Shellpoint has failed to confirm receipt or status, triggering automatic protections against the XX/XX/XXXX, sale date. 
Unanswered Qualified Written Requests ( QWRs ) and Inquiries : Since XX/XX/XXXX, I have sent multiple QWRs under RESPA 1024.36 demanding servicing information, including payment history audits, chain of title, Pooling and Servicing Agreement ( PSA ) for the CWMB 2007-HY7 Trust, error corrections for inflated arrears ( ~ {$180000.00} disputed ), and foreclosure authority documents. Shellpoint has not acknowledged or responded substantively within the required timelines ( 5 days for acknowledgment, 30 days for response, extendable to 45 ). This violates RESPA, exposing them to statutory damages of up to {$2000.00} per violation plus actual damages ( 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( f ) ). Attached emails from XX/XX/XXXX, show my detailed QWR demands, which Shellpoint 's attorney dismissed as " improper discovery requests, '' ignoring RESPA 's broad scope ( see CFPB guidance and Poindexter v. Mercedes-Benz Credit Corp. , 792 F.3d 406 ( 4th Cir. 2015 ) ).

SPOC and Communication Failures : HBOR 2923.7 requires a responsive Single Point of Contact ( SPOC ) for foreclosure prevention. On XX/XX/XXXX, I called Shellpoint to speak with a supervisor about the modification package. The supervisor refused to discuss it and referred me to their attorney, XXXX XXXX, claiming they could not assist due to litigation. XXXX XXXX has repeatedly refused to comment or provide updates ( see attached emails dated XX/XX/XXXX, at XXXX XXXX  and XXXX XXXX  ). This referral loop constitutes a SPOC violation, as Shellpoint must provide effective assistance regardless of attorney involvement. Prior interactions with SPOC XXXX XXXX were unprofessional and non-responsive, further violating RESPA 1024.40 and HBOR.

Dual-Tracking and Foreclosure Threats : With an active modification review pending, Shellpoint 's refusal to postpone the XX/XX/XXXX, sale violates HBOR 2923.6 's dual-tracking ban and recent California laws like AB 130 ( effective XX/XX/XXXX, restricting high-equity foreclosures ) and SB 1079 ( updated for bidder rights ). Shellpoint claims prior postponements, but the sale was only delayed once ( from XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX ). Their attorney states " further applications without material change don't trigger HBOR, '' but my XX/XX/XXXX package demonstrates changed circumstances, including updated financials. This risks wrongful foreclosure under Yvanova v. New Century Mortgage Corp. ( 62 Cal. 4th 919, 2016 ), potentially leading to treble damages under Cal. Civ. Code 2924.12.

Ownership and Standing Issues : Shellpoint claims ownership by XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) as trustee for the CWMB 2007-HY7 Trust, but XXXX has denied ownership in writing, directing me to XXXX XXXX XXXX ( which disclaimed involvement since XXXX ). The XXXX assignment appears invalid under the trust 's PSA ( 90-day closing window ), nullifying foreclosure authority. Shellpoint has ignored QWR demands for proof, violating RESPA and raising FDCPA 1692g debt validation issues.

Pattern of Non-Compliance : Shellpoint has responded to prior CFPB/DFPI complaints but ignores new ones. Their attorney labels my lawful inquiries as " harassment '' and demands I cease contact, while including Shellpoint in email chains. This defensive posture suggests underlying compliance issues, as noted in cases like Lucioni v. Bank of America, N.A. ( 3 Cal. App. 5th 150, 2016 ) for HBOR injunctive relief.

Impact on Me : These violations have caused severe emotional distress, financial harm ( e.g., disputed arrears accruing interest ), and the imminent threat of losing my home of over 15 years. Consumer complaint narrative:

Date Range Covered : XX/XX/year> XX/XX/year> XXXX. Summary of the Problem ( XXXX Ledger Manipulation ) Between XX/XX/year> and XX/XX/year>, my mortgage payment history at Shellpoint/NewRez changed without any new payment, disbursement, or legitimate servicing activity. 

On Day XXXX, the payment history PDF showed XXXX version of my XX/XX/year> transactions. 
On Day XXXX, a new PDF for the same loan, same period, same loan number, showed a different ledger : a new transaction line was inserted, transaction order was changed, and balances shifted without any actual payment or escrow activity. 

In other words, the past was edited in XXXX hours. 

This is not a misunderstanding ; it is XXXX contradictory, system-generated ledgers for the same dates, obtained directly from XXXX online XXXX portal on XXXX consecutive days. 



XXXX. Facts : What Changed Between XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX For the period surrounding XX/XX/year>, the XXXX PDFs ( downloaded on consecutive days ) show : Day XXXX ledger ( prior PDF ) : XXXX entries on XX/XX/year> : XXXX unapplied/processing entry XXXX regular payment entry Escrow, unapplied, and principal balances associated with those transactions. 

Day XXXX ledger ( new PDF, next day ) : Now there are XXXX entries on XX/XX/year> : XXXX. An unapplied entry for the full payment XXXX. A separate {$750.00} unapplied payment line that did not exist the prior day XXXX. A regular payment line Escrow balance shifts to a more negative value, even though no taxes or insurance were paid and no escrow analysis is shown. 
The principal balance remains the same, but the path to reach that number ( the sequence and classification of transactions ) is different. 

No new payments were made between the issuance of the XXXX PDFs. No reversals, no NSF, no escrow disbursements, no payoff, no modification. The only thing that changed was the content of XXXX own ledger. 

This is not a simple temporary online view issue. I have : XXXX different official Shellpoint payment-history PDFs, for the same loan, covering the same time period, downloaded on consecutive days, which do not match. 



XXXX. Why This Matters : False Delinquency & Fabricated Numbers At the same time these changes appear : The system shows me Past Due : {$5000.00} While also showing : Last payment received before the due date Payment due XX/XX/year> already covered by that payment Next coupon date advanced as if the payment cycle is current. 

That {$5000.00} past due amount is built from : My regular payment amount ( {$3900.00} ) + late charges ( {$1000.00} ) + other fees ( ~ {$75.00} ) The ledger changes from XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX appear designed to justify that synthetic past-due figure by recoding or fragmenting prior payments ( e.g., creating a {$750.00} partial unapplied entry that didnt exist the prior day ), instead of reflecting reality. 

This is ledger engineering, not accounting. 



XXXX. Legal Violations Implicated a. XXXX  & XXXX XXXX Payment Application & Error Resolution Under 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( k ) and 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( b ) ( 1 ) ( i ) ( ii ), servicers must : correctly apply payments as of the date received, and treat failures in payment application and false information about the loan status as errors requiring investigation and correction. 

By generating XXXX different histories for the same period with conflicting entries and balances, Shellpoint/NewRez are : failing to maintain a consistent, accurate payment history, potentially misapplying or mischaracterizing payments, and creating false delinquency by changing how prior payments are labeled after the fact. 

Regulation XXXX  also requires [ r ] easonable policies and procedures to ensure accurate and timely information, including proper maintenance of documents and data used for servicing. 12 C.F.R. 1024.38 ( b ). A system that produces XXXX ledger XXXX day and a different ledger the next, with no underlying transaction, is evidence of a systemic failure of those policies. 

b. Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) & Mortgage Servicing Rules Under the TILA servicing rules and XXXX mortgage servicing regulations, periodic statements and histories must be accurate and complete. Generating XXXX incompatible versions of my payment history for the same dates is per XXXX inconsistency and undermines any periodic statement relying on that ledger. 

XXXX XXXX Unfair, Deceptive, or Abusive Acts and Practices Creating, through internal changes, a false impression that I am past due when : XXXX version of the ledger shows payments applied, another recasts them as unapplied/partial, and the past-due amount appears to be built out of re-labeled payments and extra fees, is deceptive and unfair within the meaning of the Consumer Financial Protection Act, 12 U.S.C. 5531, 5536. The consumer can not possibly understand or verify their true obligation if the lender itself can not maintain a stable, consistent ledger for even XXXX hours. 

This sort of conduct is similar in nature to practices previously found unlawful in CFPB servicing actions, where servicers misapplied payments, misrepresented the status of loans, or maintained system data that did not accurately reflect borrower performance. 

XXXX VA XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( Context ) This loan is a XXXX mortgage and I am a 100 % permanent & total XXXX veteran. A VA borrower being declared past due based on a ledger that internally contradicts itself carries heightened risk of : wrongful default/foreclosure, improper fees, and improper reporting to credit bureaus. 

It also undermines the integrity of XXXXguaranteed loan performance reporting. 



XXXX. Evidence Pattern : Systemic, Not XXXX This XXXX shift is not happening in a vacuum. It is consistent with a broader pattern on my account : Repeated contradictions in phone calls about what is due and what has been paid Prior admissions by agents that large amounts ( e.g., ~ {$12000.00} ) sat in unapplied status and then disappeared from the portal Negative escrow balances that dont match disbursement history Past-due statuses despite payments made before the due date A separate incident where I was sent another borrowers foreclosure notice with their financial data blended into mine The XX/XX/year> XXXX change is not an isolated glitch ; it is a snapshot of an actively unstable servicing system that can not reliably maintain a single version of the truth. 



XXXX. Harm and Risk Because of this manipulation and data instability, I face : Artificial past due status based on a ledger that has been rewritten. 
Exposure to wrongful foreclosure activity based on corrupted or altered data. 
Potential damage to my credit if this synthetic delinquency is reported. 
XXXX stress and psychological harm, particularly as a XXXX veteran who is supposed to be protected instead of put at risk by systemic accounting failures. 

If my single loan history can be altered between XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX without any real transaction, it is reasonable to suspect other borrowers histories are also changing behind the scenes, especially on this same platform. 



XXXX. Requested Action by CFPB I am requesting : XXXX. XXXX and/or XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, specifically : How multiple versions of a payment history can exist for the same period, generated on different days, with different lines and different balances. 
Whether payment-, escrow-, and fee-posting logic is stable and accurate. 
XXXX. A requirement that Shellpoint/NewRez : Provide a complete, immutable transaction history for my loan from transfer to present, with : all transaction IDs, all system posting dates and effective dates, all reversals, all suspense/unapplied entries, and all internal adjustment codes. 
Explain in writing why my XX/XX/year> transaction set appears differently in XXXX PDFs produced on XXXX consecutive days. 
XXXX. A determination whether : The creation of a {$5000.00} past due figure is based on legitimate missed payments or is the result of post-hoc ledger manipulation and fee stacking. 
There is a pattern-or-practice of generating artificial delinquency and negative escrow through unstable systems. 
XXXX. XXXX from any foreclosure or collection activity while : these inconsistencies exist, and this case is being reviewed by CFPB, VA, and any partnering regulators. 



XXXX. Closing Between XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/year>, my Shellpoint/NewRez payment history changed without a single real-world payment being made. That is not a consumer issue. That is not a misunderstanding. That is a system that can not keep its own story straight for XXXX hours. 

I am asking CFPB to treat this not as a single customer complaint, but as a red-flag indicator of systemic servicing failure, especially given the VA XXXX XXXX the loan and my status as a XXXX veteran.

Consumer complaint narrative:
URGENT : Systemic Servicing Platform Failure at NewRez/Shellpoint Creating Imminent Risk of Wrongful Foreclosures, VA Loan Violations, and Conflicting Credit/BK Reporting ( API Breakdown + Orphan-Loan Indicators ) Primary Consumer : XXXX XXXX Product : VA Mortgage Servicer : NewRez LLC d/b/a Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing XXXX XXXX : XXXX XXXX XXXX ) I. Summary of Immediate Harm NewRezs servicing platform is now failing at a software-architecture level. The system is returning XXXX XXXX and XXXX Unauthorized errors across core mortgage-servicing API calls including : XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX These error codes mean the servicer can not retrieve federally required disclosures ( Reg Z ), can not retrieve loan details ( RESPA ), and can not properly authenticate borrower records ( FCRA/FDCPA ). This is a direct, active risk of wrongful foreclosure and systemic data corruption affecting me and all other borrowers on this platform. 



XXXX. Nature of the Problem I am a XXXX veteran with a XXXX mortgage. My loan is being serviced off a platform that is returning broken authentication, invalid permission states, missing legal disclosures, and loan-detail failures. This means : They can not verify ownership They can not verify balances They can not access legal disclosures They can not apply or retrieve payments They can not retrieve FDCPA communication preferences They can not validate whether foreclosure actions or delinquency statuses are lawful This is not a glitch. 
This is a systemic data-integrity collapse in a federal mortgage-servicing environment. 



III. Evidence of System Collapse As shown in the screenshots : There was an error retrieving the terms and conditions. 
XXXX XXXX Unauthorized on loan details. 
XXXX XXXX Unauthorized on payment status. 
XXXX XXXX An error has occurred on FDCPA-required communication-preference retrieval. 

401 Unauthorized = the system does not recognize the borrower or loan as valid or authorized.

400 Bad Request = the servicers system can not process the loan data or its identifiers.

A mortgage servicer can not lawfully not recognize a borrower in a live servicing relationship. 



IV. Why This Is a Legal Emergency A. RESPA / Regulation X ( 12 C.F.R. 1024.35, 1024.36 ) API failure preventing access to loan details is a direct violation of : 1024.35 ( b ) ( 1 ) failure to correctly apply payments 1024.35 ( b ) ( 2 ) failure to maintain accurate information 1024.35 ( b ) ( 6 ) failure to provide accurate escrow information 1024.35 ( b ) ( 10 ) Any other error relating to the servicing of a borrowers mortgage loan If the system itself is corrupted, every regulatory obligation collapses.

B. TILA / Regulation Z ( 12 C.F.R. 1026.41 ) The system can not retrieve legally required mortgage disclosures.

Failure to retrieve 1026.41 periodic-statement information is a direct violation.

C. FDCPA ( If NewRez is acting as a debt collector ) The 400/401 errors prevent required disclosures, violating : 15 U.S.C. 1692e ( 2 ) false representation of amount or legal status of a debt 15 U.S.C. 1692f ( 1 ) collection of amounts not permitted by law When the system reports delinquency but can not retrieve the loan, it is a per se misleading act.

D. FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ) The same platform that can not authenticate the loan is furnishing credit data to Experian showing : Discharged through Chapter 7 Paid off Closed Never late While ongoing collection efforts present the loan as live, delinquent, and in foreclosure trajectory.

This violates : 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) furnishing info known to be inaccurate 1681s-2 ( b ) failure to reasonably investigate and correct disputes The API errors show the underlying system can not validate anything it is reporting.

E. Bankruptcy Code ( 11 U.S.C. 524 ( i ), 105 ( a ) ) Multiple courts ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, XXXX ) have held that misapplied payments and inflated balances after bankruptcy constitute a discharge-injunction violation. 
A system unable to retrieve loan data is incapable of correctly crediting payments. 



F. Dodd-Frank UDAAP ( 12 U.S.C. 5531, 5536 ) A servicing platform returning 400/401 errors during foreclosure-risk conversations is the definition of : Unfair Deceptive Abusive A servicer can not claim delinquency when its system can not retrieve the loan.

G. VA Servicing Rules ( 38 C.F.R. 36.4350 ) VA loans require heightened accuracy, consistency, and communication.

A system that can not authenticate or display loan data is out of compliance.

V. Pattern & Practice NewRez/Shellpoint/Rithm already appear in federal litigation and state enforcement actions for : Misapplied payments Illegal inspection fees Zombie mortgages Bankruptcy-related balance inflation False credit reporting RESPA violations Data-integrity failures These new API failures suggest a full-platform data governance breakdown.

VI. What I Am Requesting from CFPB I request CFPB immediately : Open an enforcement investigation into NewRez and XXXX XXXX. 
Require NewRez to freeze any foreclosure or collection activity until a full audit is completed.

Require a full system-level data integrity audit, including : database logs servicing-platform API logs access-control logs payment-application records error traces for the 400/401 failures Require NewRez to provide the correct loan balance, escrow balance, and amortization history.

Require correction of contradictory Experian reporting.

Evaluate this as a pattern-and-practice UDAAP violation affecting all borrowers using the platform.

This is no longer a my loan issue.

This is a servicing-platform failure affecting every loan in their system.

VII. Damages ( Requested ) Immediate suspension of all negative credit reporting Removal of all late fees, delinquency coding, and charges Full loan accounting audit Compensation for emotional and psychological harm ( XXXX veteran ) System-wide relief for similarly affected VA borrowers Consideration of civil penalties

XXXX XXXX : My co-op building maintained valid master insurance the entire time. The lender never inquired about this until after placing the policy.

Consumer complaint narrative:
We bought a house in XXXX, XXXX with a XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX giving us a flood zone of XXXX with a different mortgage company. Therefore, we were not required to get flood insurance and chose not to get it. Shellpoint Mortgage bought our loan in XXXX, XXXX. 

In XXXX, we received a letter from Shellpoint Mortgage stating that we were in a designated flood zone and had 45 days to show proof of insurance or they would get lender-placed insurance. The 45 days ended at approximately XX/XX/XXXX. We contacted Shellpoint Mortgage and sent them our Standard Flood Hazard Determination Letter showing that we did not need flood insurance. There was some back and forth between the Flood Service listed on my Letter and Shellpoints letter, but Shellpoint 's company stated their information from XXXX has our house in a Flood zone. ( We are currently working with XXXX because we believe that while the property is on the edge of XXXX zones, the house is high enough not to require insurance. ) Here is where the problem starts. During this time, we believed we were in good faith making our case that we did not require flood insurance. We waited for the determination from Shellpoint because we expected that we had a legitimate XXXX XXXX that would not require us to have flood insurance. After they rejected our letter, we called a land surveyor who did not return our calls. Since it clearly was going to take longer than we thought to file the XXXX with XXXX, we bought flood insurance for $ XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX and sent them the paperwork. It was after the 45 days, because we were going back and forth with them trying to show that we did not need the insurance. 

Later in XXXX, Shellpoint sent us a notice saying Lender-placed Insurance was put on the property. The same policy that we obtained for {$1200.00}, they put a $ XXXX lender policy in place and took {$6000.00} out of our escrow, claiming that we had an insurance lapse since they bought the loan in XXXX. They back-dated the lender-based insurance to a time when, as far as both us and Shellpoint knew, we were not required to have flood insurance. They bought our loan without flood insurance. Shellpoint Mortgage has a flood determination date XX/XX/XXXX which is the earliest anyone knew that flood insurance was required on the property. They claim that we are responsible for notifying them of something we had no knowledge of and had just bought the house in XXXX. I do not know why our SFHDF was different, but they bought the loan that way. We did not ask for them to buy our loan. 

When I noticed that they took {$6000.00} out of our escrow in XXXX, I called Shellpoint Mortgage Insurance Division and spoke with a supervisor, XXXX, who told me they could not rescind the lender-based policy but she would file an appeal on my behalf to change the date from XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX when we were notified that we needed flood insurance. Even though I thought that was not actually a fair compromise given that we were never told that each day we were communicating with them, they were charging us and that they were charging us for a policy XXXX times the cost XXXX sets, I figured it was a starting point. ( Please see the attached letter sent to us on XX/XX/XXXX. The cost mentioned is vague and says that policy will be put in place in 15 days. There is nothing about back-dating the policy to XXXX. Also, there is no acknoledgement of the appeals that we were making. ) However, they even denied this compromise. {$6000.00} is the cost of 5 years of the flood policy that we have. They basically stole {$6000.00} from our Escrow. 

I contacted XXXX in XXXX who advised me on completing the XXXX and recommended that I contact CFPB. Due to travel and a serious illness, I am filing this complaint now.

Consumer complaint narrative:
IMMINENT HARM NewRez LLC d/b/a Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing Attn : General Counsel / Litigation Department XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, SC XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
Attn : General Counsel / Chief Legal Officer Re : Renewed Litigation Hold & Preservation of Evidence Notice Loan No. : XXXX | Property : XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, TN XXXX Borrower : XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX P & T XXXX Veteran, VA Loan ) To Counsel and Compliance : This letter serves as a renewed, expanded, and formal LITIGATION HOLD / PRESERVATION OF EVIDENCE NOTICE. 

It is being issued because you improperly closed a prior RESPA Notice of Error and related disputes as duplicate without providing the investigation, written findings, or corrections required by law, and despite your actual knowledge that the account is in active dispute, that regulatory complaints are pending, and that litigation and enforcement are reasonably anticipated. 

Your decision to treat a lawful error notice and legal hold as duplicate is evidence of willful disregard of your preservation obligations and will be presented as such to courts and regulators. 



I. Background : Prior Legal Hold & RESPA Notice Ignored XXXX. I previously issued a RESPA Notice of Error under 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 and explicitly placed you on notice that : the loan ledger is corrupted ; unapplied funds were used to manufacture delinquency ; a false XX/XX/XXXX default / pre-foreclosure notice was issued ; call recordings contain admissions that only {$750.00} was due while you held {$12000.00} in unapplied ; and a complaint and investigation were pending with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
XXXX. I also made clear that litigation and enforcement were reasonably anticipated and that all relevant evidence must be preserved. 
XXXX. Rather than comply, you : caused at least XXXX RESPA Notice of Error to be closed as duplicate ; failed to provide a compliant written response under 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( e ) ; and continued using corrupted data to threaten foreclosure and assess fees. 

This conduct signals a conscious attempt to dodge legal and regulatory obligations, not a good-faith response to a borrower error notice. 

For avoidance of doubt : this letter renews and broadens the litigation hold. 



XXXX. Duty to Preserve Litigation & Enforcement Are Reasonably Anticipated There is no question that you are on notice of potential litigation and regulatory action. Among other things : Multiple RESPA Notices of Error and RFIs have been submitted. 
Numerous CFPB complaints have been filed, including but not limited to XXXX and related complaint numbers. 
XXXX has opened a complaint and received your XX/XX/XXXX response letter regarding my loan. 
The loan involves a XXXX mortgage to a 100 % permanent & total XXXX veteran facing wrongful foreclosure threats. 
You issued a pre-foreclosure notice while holding substantial funds in unapplied status. 
I have explicitly raised claims under RESPA, Regulation X, FDCPA, FCRA, Dodd-Frank UDAAP , Tennessee consumer-protection law, VA servicing standards, and potential securities/controls issues at the Rithm level. 

Under well-established spoliation doctrine and federal law, including Fed. XXXX XXXX. P. XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX ( XXXX ) and cases such as XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX F.R.D. XXXX ( S.D.N.Y. XXXX ), and XXXX v. XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ), your duty to preserve evidence arises when litigation is reasonably anticipated, not when a complaint is actually filed in court. 

That standard has been met several times over. 



XXXX. Scope of the Litigation Hold What Must Be Preserved Effective immediately, you are directed to suspend all routine and ad hoc destruction, overwriting, or alteration of any materials potentially relevant to : my loan ( Loan No. [ XXXX ] ), your servicing systems and practices, and your responses to regulators and investors. 

This includes, without limitation : XXXX. Loan-Level Records & Ledgers Full payment history for my account from XX/XX/XXXX to present, including every version of the ledger ( before and after any reversals, adjustments, or modifications ). 
All records of unapplied/suspense funds, reversals, and reclassifications. 
All escrow analyses and escrow transaction histories. 
XXXX. Default, Foreclosure, & Collection Activity Copies ( and system templates ) of all default, acceleration, and pre-foreclosure notices, including the XX/XX/XXXX letter. 
Internal notes, workflows, and servicing system entries related to any decision to code my loan as delinquent or refer it to foreclosure. 
All property inspection requests, invoices, and reports ; all entries for inspection fees or property-preservation fees. 
XXXX. Call Recordings, Transcripts, and Internal Notes Audio recordings and/or transcripts of all calls with me and with XXXX XXXX referencing this loan, especially the calls on and around : XX/XX/XXXX XX/XX/XXXX calls quoting conflicting payment amounts XXXX XXXX XXXX calls about unapplied funds and property inspections All internal agent notes, servicing comments, and escalation logs tied to those calls. 
XXXX. Compliance, Risk, Audit, and Complaint Files All internal complaint files, including CFPB, XXXX, and internal case or ticket systems related to my account. 
Any internal audits, QA reviews, risk assessments, or root cause analyses addressing unapplied funds, false delinquency, XXXX servicing, or duplicative/erroneous default notices. 
All documents relating to your decision to mark my RESPA Notice of Error and complaints as duplicate. 
XXXX. Policies, Procedures, & System Documentation Servicing policies/procedures for : unapplied funds, suspense accounts, default/foreclosure initiation, VA-loan handling, property inspections, escrow analysis, and RESPA Notices of Error. 
System documentation or vendor contracts for platforms used to service my loan ( payment processing systems, collections platforms, dialer/phone systems, recording systems, document-generation platforms, etc. ). 
XXXX. Emails & ESI ( Electronically Stored Information ) Emails, chat messages, Teams/Slack messages , and other ESI among employees, managers, compliance staff, and executives concerning : my loan, unapplied funds and payment reversals, my CFPB and XXXX complaints, treatment of my prior legal hold notices, instructions on how to respond to my RESPA notices XXXX and decision-making about closing items as duplicate. 
Communications with any outside counsel or vendors, including but not limited to foreclosure counsel, collection agencies, sub-servicers, and XXXX corporate/legal. 
XXXX. Rithm / NewRez XXXX Shellpoint / Investor-Level Communications Communications between NewRez/Shellpoint and XXXX XXXX XXXX relating to my loan, similar loans, unapplied funds policies, or handling of XXXX accounts. 
Any communications referencing my complaints, my CFPB activity, or my status as a XXXX XXXX P & T XXXX veteran. 

This preservation requirement extends to all locations where such information may be stored, including on-premises servers, cloud systems, laptops, mobile devices, backup tapes, archives, and XXXX-party vendors. 



IV. Closing Prior Matters as Duplicate Does NOT Extinguish Your Legal Hold Obligations Your recent behavior, including : closing prior RESPA Notices of Error as duplicate, issuing non-substantive CFPB responses, and refusing to provide a compliant written RESPA response, does not terminate or diminish your duty to preserve evidence. 

To the contrary, it will be argued as proof of willful noncompliance and bad-faith spoliation risk, including : an attempt to avoid creating a discoverable paper trail of your errors ; a pattern of dodging Regulation X obligations ; and deliberate efforts to minimize documentary exposure while continuing harmful servicing conduct. 

Any destruction or alteration of relevant data after receipt of this letter will be treated as knowing spoliation and cited in support of : adverse inference instructions, evidentiary preclusion, monetary sanctions, and expanded damages claims. 



XXXX Confirmation of Hold & Point of Contact Within 14 days of receipt of this letter, please : XXXX. Confirm in writing that a litigation hold has been implemented, XXXX. Identify the individual ( XXXX ) responsible for coordinating your response and preservation efforts, and XXXX. Confirm that routine deletion, overwriting, and data-retention schedules have been suspended as to all categories identified in XXXX XXXX. 

Failure to confirm will not relieve you of your obligations ; it will only strengthen the argument that any loss of evidence was willful or reckless. 



VI. Reservation of Rights Nothing in this letter waives any rights or remedies I may hold under : RESPA / Regulation X ( 12 U.S.C. 2605 ; 12 C.F.R. pt. 1024 ), FDCPA ( 15 U.S.C. 1692 et seq. ), FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq. ), Dodd-Frank UDAAP ( 12 U.S.C. 5531, 5536 ), VA servicing rules and related regulations, Tennessee state law, or any other applicable federal or state law, including securities-related obligations at the XXXX level. 

All rights are expressly reserved, including seeking sanctions for spoliation if you fail to honor this legal hold.
