Sub-issue: An existing modification, forbearance plan, short sale, or other loss mitigation relief
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, Shellpoint entered into a pretrial mortgage modification with XXXX XXXX. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX received the approved loan modification documents containing numerous errors. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX received her first email from her new point of contact, XXXX XXXX, who reached out to discuss the loan modification documents. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX responded by email, explaining that her attempts to reach someone had been unsuccessful. For the first time, she told XXXX XXXX that her daughters name, XXXX XXXX, had been removed from the title and had no obligation to the loan, and therefore needed to be removed from the loan modification documents. 
Please note ; As instructed in the check agreement page of the loan modification documents. Note, if anyone should not be listed on the mortgage you must include supporting documents such as Quit Claim Deed. 

On the XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX identified herself as XXXX XXXX point of contact and stated that she would be reaching out by telephone. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX responded by email that she had not received a call and was concerned about possible spam blockers, asking XXXX XXXX to please provide a telephone number and extension, as well as a set time to call. Despite XXXX XXXX attempts to reach XXXX XXXX, she was unable to connect with a live person. Instead, each call was met with a prerecorded message stating that the loan modification documents were being processed. 
On XX/XX/XXXX, for the Second Time by email, XXXX XXXX again explained to XXXX XXXX that she had previously contacted XXXX XXXX in XXXX, to whom she had forwarded a Quit Claim Deed and requested the removal of her daughter 's name from the loan modification documents. Furthermore, she was still waiting for the corrected documents. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX completely ignored XXXX XXXX request for the corrected loan modification documents ONLY to say in an email ; XXXX XXXX, I see that the modification agreement was delivered to your residence on XX/XX/XXXX, at XXXX through XXXX. These documents havent been returned to date. If you would like to discuss this further, please feel free to contact me. 

On XX/XX/XXXX for the Third Time by email XXXX XXXX, had to completely explain to XXXX XXXX of the situation with the loan modification document. 

Where XXXX XXXX responded ; I have reviewed the documents mentioned in your email, and have made the requested for the revised modification. Once this is completed it will be sent. I do apologize for the delay in getting this addressed. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX received a default letter. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, by email, XXXX XXXX contacted XXXX XXXX about the default letter, asking what was taking place with the corrections to her modification. 

On XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX responded see below by email ; The time expired to complete the modification, and per fulfilment department there was not a reason given to have other party removed from the deed. To workout will have to reset and start anew. When the cycle was closed, the loan was reassigned to a new point of contact that will be contacting you. My honest apology that the plan did not complete. 

XXXX XXXX did contact XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX, prior to the deadline of XX/XX/XXXX, required to return the loan modification documents. 
Throughout XXXX, XXXX XXXX called to follow up on the status of the loan modification agreement, but encountered the same difficulties, she was unable to reach a live person and was instead met with a prerecorded message stating that the loan modification documents were being processed. 
On XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX received foreclosure papers. Distressed by this development, she made multiple attempts to reach Shellpoint by phone and was eventually able to speak with a live representative. 
On XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX XXXX again had difficulty reaching a live person and requested a supervisor. XXXX XXXX was assigned as the supervisor for XXXX XXXX, and at that time, she was given a new point of contact, XXXX XXXX. 
On XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX received a letter of confirmation from Shellpoints Compliance Department. 
This letter is in response to the correspondence received by Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ( " Shellpoint '' ) on XX/XX/XXXX, regarding the above-referenced property. Please know that we take our customer service and consumer protection obligations seriously and have dedicated staff to identify and resolve your concerns. We understand your concern is regarding request for revised Loan Modification Documents, removal of XXXX XXXX XXXX. We apologize for the delayed response to your inquiry. 

On XX/XX/XXXX and XXXX, XXXX, The Quit Claim Deed was resubmitted to Shellpoints XXXX. 

I am requesting that Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing fulfill our loan modification agreement by expediting the issuance of new loan modification documents that remove her daughter from the loan and further correct the city in the property address. 
Once again, due to Shellpoints failure to promptly make the necessary corrections as outlined in the loan agreement documents, Shellpoint is responsible for the loan modification agreement not being completed. Furthermore, XXXX XXXX should not be penalized with foreclosure proceedings as a result of Shellpoints negligence.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute the additional charges that Shellpoint assessed on my mortgage payoff, specifically the late fee of {$650.00} and the additional per diem interest of {$380.00}, which appeared on the revised payoff statement dated XX/XX/XXXX. 

My closing and payoff were completed using the official payoff statement Shellpoint issued dated XX/XX/XXXX, which clearly stated that the payoff amount was valid through XX/XX/XXXX. The title company XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) sent the full payoff amount according to those instructions, and Shellpoint confirmed receipt of those funds on XX/XX/XXXX, which was within the valid date range. 

Despite that, the following XXXX XXXX, XXXX issued a revised payoff statement adding a late fee and additional per diem interest. These charges are improper and must be removed for the following reasons : Shellpoint provided a written payoff quote valid through XX/XX/XXXX, and the payment was sent and received on that date. 

A borrower and title company are entitled to rely on the written payoff statement issued by the servicer. Servicers are required to honor their stated payoff terms during the validity period. 

Any additional fees or interest added after the payoff funds were already remitted and received contradicts the payoff terms Shellpoint itself provided. 

XXXX XXXX paid the unexpected shortage only to prevent further improper interest accrual. This should not shift liability to me or the title company when the discrepancy originated from Shellpoints error. 

I am requesting the following : Immediate removal of the late fee ( {$650.00} ) and additional per diem interest ( {$380.00} ). 

Reimbursement or credit for the {$1000.00} paid by XXXX XXXX, as these funds were only paid due to Shellpoints failure to honor the original payoff quote. 

Updated documentation confirming the correct payoff application and that the loan is paid in full with no outstanding balance. 

Please respond in writing within XXXX business days confirming that these charges have been reversed and that the account is fully satisfied without delinquency, derogatory reporting, or additional fees. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to a resolution.

Consumer complaint narrative:
My mortgage servicer, Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing, mishandled my homeowners insurance, escrow account, and payment history, resulting in improper charges, inflated payment demands, and the initiation of pre-foreclosure activity despite my maintaining insurance and making payments. 

For many years, my homeowners insurance was paid directly by me ( not through escrow ), and Shellpoints own escrow analysis in XX/XX/XXXX reflected this correctly. 

Insurance and force-placed insurance errors : XX/XX/XXXX, Shellpoint sent XXXX requesting proof of insurance renewal, even though my policy was active and premiums were being paid through automatic payments. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, Shellpoint stated my insurance had expired, which was incorrect. The policy had renews in XXXX, and coverage was continuous. 

On XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, Shellpoint escalated to final and unable to confirm insurance notices, even though there was no lapse in coverage. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, Shellpoint placed force-placed insurance on the account. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, Shellpoint paid approximately {$7000.00} to my actual insurance XXXX, confirming coverage existed and was active. 

Despite this confirmation, Shellpoint did not cancel the force-placed insurance to my knowledge as I have not been informed otherwise. 

Misapplication of funds : After the insurer refunded the {$7000.00} to Shellpoint because my account was current as well as I was listed as the responsible party, Shellpoint misapplied the funds by posting them to future monthly payments and principal instead of correcting the escrow error. 

These misapplications were only corrected after I contacted Shellpoint in XX/XX/XXXX. 

Escrow and payment issues : Shellpoint later added homeowners insurance into escrow without proper notice, creating an artificial escrow shortage and increasing my monthly payment. 

My regular monthly payment prior to these errors was approximately {$610.00}, but XXXX system began showing conflicting and significantly higher amounts. The payments are now {$1300.00} with a new amount issued as I am writing this complaint. 

Fees such as late fees and NSF fees were assessed even though payments were made and, in some cases, cleared the following day. 

Borrower record and bankruptcy errors : Shellpoint repeatedly referenced a former co-borrower who signed a quit claim deed years ago and is not involved in servicing. 

Shellpoint also implied that bankruptcy applied to the loan, which is incorrect. I have never filed bankruptcy, and the mortgage has never included in any bankruptcy proceeding. 

Pre-foreclosure action : On XX/XX/XXXX, Shellpoint issued a pre-foreclosure notice even though any alleged delinquency was caused by its own unresolved servicing errors and disputed charges. 

Impact : These errors caused financial hardship, emotional distress, and fear of losing my home. I repeatedly contacted Shellpoint to correct the issues, but the problems persisted, and corrective action was delayed or refused unless I pursued options like refinancing or loan assumption, which did not address the underlying errors. 

I am asking for CFPB assistance to ensure the servicer corrects the insurance and escrow errors, fixes the payment history, removes improper fees and delinquency coding, stops foreclosure activity, and accurately reflects that no bankruptcy applies to this loan.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

This refusal is evidence of : concealment obstruction platform corruption inability to explain their own system fear of creating discoverable statements servicing misconduct 2. FEDERAL LAW VIOLATIONS ( RESPA, TILA, FDCPA, UDAAP, VA SERVICING ) All original citations remain applicable and included : RESPA 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( e ) RESPA 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 TILA 15 U.S.C. 1639f FDCPA 15 U.S.C. 1692e and 1692f UDAAP 12 U.S.C. 5531 ( a ) VA servicing regulations under 38 C.F.R. 36.4350 CFPB XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) CFPB XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) CFPB XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX oversight standards 3. XXXX XXXX ( THE CORE STRUCTURAL FAILURE ) In multiple CFPB filings, NewRez/Shellpoint have stated : We have nothing to do with XXXX. 
We are not affiliated with XXXX. 
XXXX is not our parent. 
We have no relationship with XXXX. 

These are federal-record statements. 
They carry legal consequences. 

XXXX XXXX is the publicly disclosed owner of NewRez and Shellpoint. 

If NewRez denies any affiliation with XXXX, then under federal regulatory classifications : NewRez is operating as an XXXX  entity. 

And an XXXX  entity : can not service loans can not legally enforce mortgages can not collect payments can not claim authority over VA loans can not maintain standing can not issue balances can not initiate or threaten foreclosure can not report to credit bureaus can not determine escrow can not contact consumers for payment This legally voids the loans enforceability. 



* * 4. NEW SECTION ( YOUR REQUEST ) : WHY IS NEWREZ CONTACTING ME ABOUT A LOAN THEY HAVE NO LEGAL AUTHORITY TO TOUCH? * * This is the new nuclear logic : If NewRez states on a federal record that they have nothing to do with XXXX and XXXX is the disclosed owner of NewRez, then NewRez has no lawful parent, no lawful authority, no lawful servicing rights, and no lawful right to contact me at all. 

Therefore, when NewRez calls me : to demand money to discuss payments to demand verification to refuse to explain missing funds to threaten delinquency to maintain an account balance to classify me as behind to contact me for anything They are : operating without authority attempting to collect without ownership attempting to enforce a void loan acting as an unlicensed XXXX  XXXX  engaging in unlawful collection activity exerting financial pressure without standing extorting payments under false authority This constitutes : FDCPA 1692e false representation of authority FDCPA 1692f unfair/unauthorized collection activity UDAAP abusive and deceptive practice RESPA failure to provide ownership evidence VA Servicing Violations unauthorized contact with VA borrower This is extortion under the definition of : demanding payment without legal right or authority. 

By contacting me about a loan they admit they do not legally service or own, NewRez is : misrepresenting their capacity exerting pressure on a VA borrower attempting to collect payments they are not entitled to concealing the absence of standing engaging in deceptive servicing If NewRez is not owned by XXXX, NewRez can not enforce my mortgage. 
If NewRez can not enforce my mortgage, every contact they make is unauthorized. 
If every contact is unauthorized, the attempt to collect is extortion.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint as a follow-up to my previous CFPB complaint filed on XX/XX/year>, regarding general servicing and foreclosure issues with Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing XXXX This new complaint focuses on distinct, additional violations involving a backdated letter, delayed delivery, and conflicting communications from my Single Point of Contact ( SPOC ), which have caused further confusion and hardship. 
On XX/XX/year>, I received a letter from Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing dated XX/XX/year>, stating that my complete loan modification application is under review and that no foreclosure activity will proceed during this evaluation. However, my assigned SPOC has provided contradictory verbal information, stating a different status for the review, which directly conflicts with the written letter. This inconsistency is creating extreme confusion, especially as I am a XXXX XXXX  homeowner facing an imminent foreclosure sale on XX/XX/year>. 
Additionally, the 9-day delay between the letter 's date ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and its receipt ( XX/XX/XXXX ) appears to be an unfair practice that deprived me of timely notice and the opportunity to respond effectively. As a result, I am uncertain about the true status of my application and whether foreclosure activities are truly paused. 
These actions violate federal mortgage servicing rules under Regulation X ( 12 C.F.R. 1024.40 ), which requires servicers to assign a SPOC who provides accurate, consistent, and clear information about loss mitigation options. The conflicting statements between the letter and SPOC communications breach this requirement. Furthermore, the backdated and delayed notice may constitute unfair or deceptive acts under the Consumer Financial Protection Act ( CFPA ), as it misleads consumers about the timeline of their review process. 
If foreclosure advances while my application is supposedly under review, this would also violate dual-tracking prohibitions under Regulation X ( 12 C.F.R. 1024.41 ). As a XXXX XXXX in California, these practices are causing severe emotional distress and putting my primary residence at risk. 
I have ongoing litigation against Shellpoint in XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( Case No. XXXX ) for related HBOR violations, and this new inconsistency will be documented as evidence.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing a complaint regarding my mortgage loan servicing with NewRez ( also known as Shellpoint/XXXX  ). My mortgage account has been mishandled multiple times, resulting in repeated errors, escrow mismanagement, and improper payment increases. 
Most recently, I discovered that my home owners insurance had not been paid for which resulted in no coverage for a year, even though escrow funds were collected for that purpose and I received email confirmation saying the payment was made. The company tried to give me insurance and I had to call to set back up my previous home insurance plan. This was the servicers error, not mine. 

In addition to the insurance issue, there have been repeated problems with how my property taxes are handled. My escrow payment due keeps raising which the lack of payment in insurance should have kept it down. The servicer has made errors in the amounts collected and paid out of escrow, which has contributed to ongoing miscalculations. Because of these combined mistakes, my monthly mortgage payment has been repeatedly increased, most recently by more than {$100.00} per month. These increases are not the result of my actions but of the servicers failure to manage escrow properly. 
I have requested explanations from the servicer, but I have not received a clear or accurate escrow analysis that justifies these increases. I believe my escrow account has been mishandled in violation of RESPA. This situation has caused me financial hardship and stress, as I am being charged higher payments due to the servicers own errors. Additionally, the company keeps sending me a XXXX check. I have already cashed the check but received it several other times and received a call from the company notifying me they are going to send it out again and I need to cash it. 

My escrow going up XXXX times for taxes when my state does tax analysis once yearly ( my taxes went down ), the repetitious sending of the same check, the year without homeowners insurance, and the most recent payment increase lead me to believe my loan is completely mishandled. 

I am requesting a full and accurate escrow history and analysis for the past XXXX years, a correction of any errors in my escrow account, removal of any payment increases that resulted from the servicers mistakes in failing to pay my insurance and mishandling my property tax payments, and written confirmation that this will be handled properly from the company going forward.

Consumer complaint narrative: Im XXXX XXXX  XXXX and therefore am tax exempt in XXXX XXXX where I live! In XXXX I went to the controller and filed to have my taxes deferred and to get my homestead exemption which I got. I then filed the paperwork with Caliber mortgage the lender at that time which then became NewRez which is who they are now! They said that they would file the paperwork and that I could call back in one week and that I would then be in their system and would be tax exempt and would not be charged taxes. I called back after one week and they stated I was setup in their system and was not going to be charged taxes. Later that year I was indeed charged taxes anyway. When I found out I was charged taxes I called them and asked what was going on. They said I was not setup as tax exempt. I said I called in and setup myself up and was in their system. They looked it up and figured it out that I was setup and then said that I was setup and that they would return the money to the county in 5 days. They took 4 months to return the money all the time charging me {$3700.00}!! After they returned the money they then did and analysis on the house and decided that they would raise my mortgage to a higher amount since my house was worth more money now!! The next year came around and they said to call in and let them know that I was tax exempt and they would not charge me taxes. So I called them early in the year but they charged me taxes anyway!! They then said they would return the money but took 3 months to return the money the whole time charging me over {$3000.00} a month!! After they returned the money they then did another analysis on my house and raised the mortgage again! This started to become a pattern! Every year they would charge me taxes when they were not supposed to while claiming that I was not tax exempt even though I am in their system as tax exempt!! I keep calling them every year early to tell them not to charge me taxes yet they do it anyways. Then when they say that they are going to send the money back to XXXX XXXX they take 4 months to send the money back!! After they send the money back they do an analysis on my house and raise my mortgage. They are driving me out of my house by raising the mortgage!!! This is not right!!! They claim that the county is sending them a bill but I had the county remove them from my account so there is no way they can get a bill from the county unless they ask for a bill from the county!! They keep saying the county is sending them a bill though which is a lie!!! I have verified this with the comptroller of the county!!! As of XX/XX/XXXX they still have money that they have to return from this year that they took from me as taxes which they were not supposed to have charged me which they were supposed to return 4 months ago!!!! They need to return that money NOW!! Please help me ASAP!!!

To Whom It May Concern, I am submitting this complaint regarding Shellpoint Mortgage Servicings refusal or failure to postpone a scheduled foreclosure sale, despite clear evidence that the property securing the loan is actively listed for sale and will result in a full payoff of the mortgage debt. 
Loan Number : XXXX Property Address : XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, CA XXXX Scheduled Sale Date : XX/XX/year> The property is currently actively listed on the CRMLS at a competitive market price and was recently reduced to encourage an expedited sale. Based on current market conditions and buyer activity, a successful sale and full payoff are reasonably imminent. Documentation supporting the active listing and price reduction has been provided to the servicer. 
Proceeding with a foreclosure sale under these circumstances is unnecessary, avoidable, and harmful, particularly when the servicer is positioned to be paid in full through an arms-length market transaction. Allowing the sale to proceed would create irreparable harm to the borrower while providing no financial benefit to the investor beyond what is already assured. 
I am the listing real estate broker and authorized third party, and I have formally requested that Shellpoint postpone the sale date to allow sufficient time for the transaction to close escrow. This request is reasonable, time-limited, and aligned with loss-mitigation principles and the CFPBs servicing standards, including the obligation to avoid unnecessary foreclosure where alternatives exist. 
Shellpoints failure to pause the sale under these conditions raises serious concerns regarding : Failure to exercise reasonable loss-mitigation discretion Unnecessary advancement of foreclosure despite a pending full payoff Potential unfair servicing practices causing avoidable consumer harm This complaint seeks CFPB intervention XXXX require Shellpoint to postpone the XX/XX/year> foreclosure sale and allow the open-market transaction to proceed to closing, resulting in full satisfaction of the mortgage debt. 
If additional information is required, I am available immediately. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX Real Estate Broker | XXXX XXXX # XXXX Authorized Third Party Phone : XXXX Email : XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
CFPB COMPLAINT SYSTEMIC SERVICING FAILURE, DATA CORRUPTION, WRONGFUL FORECLOSURE RISK, AND MULTI-BORROWER HARM Consumer : XXXX XXXX Servicer : NewRez LLC d/b/a Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing Parent Company : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
Product : VA Mortgage Issue : Systemic misapplication of payments, data corruption, false delinquency, contradictory federal representations, imminent harm to borrowers I. Summary of Complaint I am filing this complaint to report system-wide data corruption, misapplied funds, false delinquency reporting, contradictory corporate representations, and imminent harm to consumers, including myself as a XXXX veteran with a VA-backed loan . 

My account has been corrupted since XXXX. 
Payments disappear, reappear, shift between months, or get placed into suspense. 
I have received another borrowers foreclosure letter, and I am now receiving correspondence from a Florida address that does not match Shellpoints declared headquarters, consistent with multi-system contamination. 

At the same time, the parent company, XXXX XXXX XXXX, is telling the CFPB that complaints naming XXXX are directed to the wrong company, while filing SEC disclosures that state the exact opposite : that XXXX owns, consolidates, controls, and profits from NewRez/Shellpoint .

These contradictions create a high-risk, multi-borrower crisis requiring urgent CFPB action.

II. Findings 1. My loan servicing data is corrupted Payments are not credited when received. 
Unapplied funds have accumulated for years. 
Conflicting ledgers produce different balances depending on the portal or department. 
Escrow values change without explanation. 
A {$3900.00} payment was moved to XX/XX/XXXX, then removed from the ledger entirely. 
Funds placed in suspense contradict the servicers own call recordings. 

2. I received a foreclosure notice belonging to another borrower This is not a clerical error.

This proves that borrower data and foreclosure processing streams are contaminated.

3. My mail is now being routed through XXXX XXXX, Florida a location that does not match Shellpoints declared headquarters Shellpoints operations are based in South Carolina.

NewRezs operations are in Pennsylvania. 
Yet I received official correspondence from : Shellpoint XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, FL XXXX This is consistent with : legacy routing tables, corrupted system identifiers, and cross-database contamination. 

This is a hallmark indicator of platform-wide data instability. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX is denying ownership of NewRez to regulators while affirming ownership to the SEC In at least XXXX CFPB responses, XXXX stated the complaint does not belong to us. 
But in its SEC filings ( Form XXXX, Form XXXX, Form XXXX, Form XXXX, and insider transactions ), XXXX : consolidates NewRez revenue and assets, describes NewRez as a wholly-owned subsidiary, grants executive compensation based on servicing-platform earnings, and states it ultimately owns a number of subsidiaries, including the entities involved in my servicing. 

These contradictory statements create what I call the Orphan Company Paradox : XXXX is enriched by NewRezs servicing income while disowning NewRez to avoid regulatory accountability for servicing failures. 



III. Evidence A. Ledger corruption and payment manipulation Multiple ledgers showing different balances.

Suspense funds acknowledged on recorded calls.

The servicer claims error, but errors of this magnitude indicate systemic failure. 

XXXX XXXX foreclosure letter I received foreclosure documents for an entirely different consumer. 
This demonstrates : cross-borrower contamination, privacy breaches, wrongful foreclosure risk. 

C. Contradictory addresses ( SC XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX print routing ) This indicates a fragmented and corrupted data environment. 

D. Public borrower reports showing the same failures I submitted XXXX screenshots documenting years of identical harm to other consumers, including reports that parents and seniors are experiencing the same failures. 

E. SEC contradictions XXXX executives sell stock based on subsidiary earnings ( Forms XXXX and XXXX ). 
XXXX asserts ownership in every securities filing. 
Yet XXXX denies association to the CFPB. 

This is a cross-jurisdiction contradiction with consumer harm implications. 



IV. Legal Interpretation XXXX. RESPA Regulation X Violations ( XXXX C.F.R. XXXX, XXXX ) Failure to correct errors. 
Failure to apply payments when received. 
Failure to respond properly to Notices of Error.

Failure to investigate borrower disputes.

Sending another borrowers foreclosure documents.

2. TILA / Regulation Z Violations ( 12 C.F.R. 1026.36 ( c ) ( 1 ) ) Misapplication of payments and inaccurate statements constitute direct violations.

3. UDAP / UDAAP Violations ( 12 U.S.C. 5531, 5536 ) It is deceptive to : consolidate and profit from servicing operations in SEC filings, while denying ownership and responsibility in the CFPB portal to avoid accountability for servicing abuses.

4. Federal foreclosure-process violations Wrong-borrower foreclosure notices implicate wrongful-foreclosure doctrines across all jurisdictions. 

XXXX. VA XXXX Protections As a XXXX veteran, mishandling of a VA loan constitutes heightened federal concern, particularly when : data is corrupted, payments vanish, foreclosure risk is created. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX / XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) XXXX XXXX has : XXXX knowledge of its ownership of NewRez, CFPB-facing denials of that ownership, and an operational platform inflicting widespread consumer harm.

This is a classic breach of oversight duty under Delaware law.

V. Risk Impact Imminent, escalating, multi-borrower harm. 
The system is : corrupting ledgers, misrouting data, mixing borrower files, generating false foreclosure risk, violating federal mortgage-servicing law, and endangering veterans, seniors, and families. 

This is no longer a dispute. 
It is a platform failure with national risk. 



VI. Requested CFPB Action 1. Immediate supervisory investigation of NewRez LLC and Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing, including full data-governance review.

2. Referral to the SEC for cross-jurisdiction contradictions involving XXXX ownership claims in securities filings vs wrong company claims in CFPB responses. 
3. Order a forensic audit of my loan, including : full reconstruction of my ledger, correction of unapplied funds, reversal of false delinquency reports, verification of escrow accounting.

4. Immediate stop of any foreclosure activity due to platform instability.

5. Mandate a system-wide audit across all borrowers due to multi-year, multi-consumer evidence of identical harm.

6. Order monetary relief for damages sustained and escalating daily due to continued non-correction : {>= $1,000,000} in damages, and payoff of my mortgage, consistent with federal consumer-protection statutes, RESPA remedies, UDAAP penalties, data-governance failures, and case law involving systemic servicing misconduct.

VII. Harm to Other Borrowers ( Systemic and Widespread ) The servicing failures documented in my account are not isolated.

I have reviewed hundreds of public borrower reports, including historical data going back to XXXX, and the same patterns appear repeatedly across consumers in multiple states : Misapplied payments Suspense account dumping Conflicting ledgers False delinquency Manufactured foreclosure risk Missing payments Escrow miscalculations Inability to obtain accurate account histories Borrowers receiving one anothers documents Veterans and seniors being placed into delinquency despite making full payments These borrowers include : Elderly individuals on fixed incomes, XXXX veterans like myself, Families with children at risk of wrongful foreclosure, Parents reporting the same errors I am experiencing, Borrowers whose accounts show unexplained increases, Borrowers whose ledgers do not match their statements or portals, Borrowers who have lost homes or nearly lost them due to misapplied funds. 

I submitted screenshots demonstrating these patterns spanning multiple years and multiple servicing platforms within NewRez/Shellpoint. These are not customer-service lapses. They represent a structural failure of the underlying data environment, affecting thousands of consumers. 

Because the same errors repeat across states, loan types, and consumer profiles, this constitutes : System-wide risk to every borrower serviced by NewRez and Shellpoint. 

These patterns are identical to those observed in past federal enforcement actions against large servicers for : systemic misapplication of funds, incorrect delinquency reporting, wrongful foreclosure practices, and UDAAP violations under 12 U.S.C. 5531, 5536.

This is not an individual mistake. It is a replicated servicing defect affecting consumers nationally. 

As a XXXX veteran, my own risk is severe. But the harm is not limited to me. 
Borrowers across the country are being placed in danger through : corrupted records, inaccurate balances, loss of payment history integrity, and cross-account contamination that results in people receiving other borrowers documents, including foreclosure notices. 

This creates foreseeable and imminent harm that rises to the level of systemic consumer-risk under CFPB supervisory standards.

VIII. Requested Action for All Affected Borrowers Along with the corrective and monetary relief for my own loan, I request the CFPB initiate a platform-wide enforcement action requiring : 1. Full-servicer forensic audit A top-to-bottom examination of : payment application logic, suspense-account methodology, ledger integrity, servicing data governance, foreclosure processing, cross-borrower data contamination, and all system interfaces used by NewRez and Shellpoint. 

2. Mandatory remediation for every borrower Including : correction of misapplied funds, reconstruction of corrupted ledgers, reimbursement of wrongfully assessed fees, reversal of manufactured delinquencies, and full review of foreclosure activity to identify cases triggered by corrupted or inaccurate data.

3. Protection for veterans, seniors, and vulnerable borrowers Many veterans report suffering from identical errors involving unapplied payments and escalation to foreclosure. 
Given my own XXXX loan, I request the CFPB prioritize an immediate review of : all VA loan XXXX handled by NewRez/Shellpoint, all delinquency coding involving VA borrowers, and any foreclosure activity involving VA loans since XXXX XXXX 

4. Federal coordination with the SEC, FTC, VA, and state regulators Because the servicing failures overlap with : SEC-reporting contradictions ( Rithms ownership vs wrong company claims ), data-governance breakdowns, cross-account contamination, and multi-borrower harm across state lines, I request interagency coordination consistent with Dodd-Frank 112 and supervisory protocols for systemic consumer-finance risk.

5. Enforcement orders preventing continued use of the wrong company defense Because these contradictions contribute directly to delayed remediation and consumer harm, the CFPB should require XXXX/NewRez/Shellpoint to cease using false corporate disassociation statements.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX - Cell XXXX XX/XX/XXXX Consumer Financial Protection Bureau XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX Washington, DC XXXX Via Email to CFPB portal Dear Sir/Madam : This is a follow up complaint to my response dated XX/XX/XXXX Regarding Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing, ( a/k/a New Rez LLC. ). My original complaint was Complaint # XXXX If you will read the emails following between myself and XXXX XXXX of Shellpoint, you can see that I was ultimately proven correct in that I was entitled to interest rate reduction under the CARES ACT according to XXXX XXXX guidelines . However, that is not what happened. 

The emails will show that Shellpoint engaged in a deceitful and deceptive practice by dual tracking my account, acknowledging my rights to the modification, while at the same time, 22 days later, violated federal law by electronically filing a foreclosure action against me in XXXX XXXX, XXXX. The first page of the action is included, and from the header at the top left of the page you can see that it was filed on XX/XX/XXXX as File # XXXX, E-FILED, XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX  This is a clear violation of CFPB Regulation X, a violation under the Consumer Protection Financial Act of 2010, of the Dodd-Frank Act.

Section 12 C.F.R. 1024.41 ( g ) covers issues regarding what is referred to as dual tracking. Shellpoint began actively pursuing foreclosure while simultaneously assuring me that I would be accepted for loss mitigation pursuant to the CARES ACT.

( See Gresham v. Wells Fargo Bank, N.A., 642 F. Appx 355 ( 5th Cir. 2016 ) ; see also Herrera v. Bank of Am., N.A., No. 15-CV-62156, 2016 WL 4542105, at * 8 ( S.D. Fla. Aug. 31, 2016 ). Section 1024.41 ( g ) provides the prohibition on dual tracking, 12 C.F.R. 1024.41 ( a ) expressly provides consumers such as myself, a right of action in the event the servicer ignores that prohibition. Gresham v. Wells Fargo Bank, N.A., 642 F. Appx 355, 359 ( 5th Cir. 2016 ). 

My mortgage was originated through XXXX XXXX XXXX, who retained the servicing of the mortgage as the loan was sold to the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX ( XXXX XXXX ). In XX/XX/XXXX servicing was transferred to Shellpoint and that is when the violations of law began. 

SHELLPOINT SENT A CHECK BACK TO ME IN THE AMOUNT OF {$4500.00}, THAT I PREVIOUSLY PAID TO THEM PER THEIR DEMAND. 

I HAVE BEEN UNABLE TO CASH THIS CHECK AS BANK WOULD NOT CLEAR IT. SO I HAVE PAID SHELLPOINT, ( INCLUDING THE CHECK ABOVE ), TOTAL OF {$17000.00} SINCE FIRST TRIAL MOD STARTED ON XX/XX/XXXX, WHICH WORKS OUT TO XXXX XXXX THROUGH XXXX XXXX, 13 MONTHS, AVERAGE OF {$1300.00} A MONTH. 

COMPARE TO THE ORIGINAL XXXX XXXX OF {$900.00}, TIMES 13 MONTHS = {$11000.00}. 

SO THROUGH ALL THE SHELLPOINT TRIAL MODS I PAID SHELLPOINT {$5800.00} MORE THAN THE ORIGINAL PAYMENT RATE. 

You can see by examining the documents contained herein my rights have been violated by the deceptive and manipulative practices of Shellpoint. I am therefore requesting that you investigate the facts as I have provided as to the conduct of Shellpoint. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX EMAILS FOLLOW BELOW : XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX Good Afternoon, After review of the file we are going to honor the loan modification but in order to proceed with the modification. To accept it we need for you to make the payments that would have been due as of today the amount is {$4500.00} along with the full divorce decree. Thanks in advance Best Regards XXXX XXXX Loss Mitigation Specialist Hours of Operation : Monday thru Friday XXXX. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX Toll Free XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX to XXXX me Good afternoon. 

Based on the most recent trial modification package I made a payment for XXXX in the amount of {$810.00}. When I tried to make the XXXX payment I was prevented from doing so, both on line and in telephone conversations with Shellpoint employees. I was not willing to take a chance on this sudden change of terms, so I actually used my XXXX  XXXX XXXX account to issue a payment to Shellpoint in the same amount, {$810.00}, which shows it cleared my account on XX/XX/XXXX, meaning that two of the three required payments have been made pursuant to the most recent trial mod package. So, if the trial mod document is to continue governing our relationship, the only payment I would be due for would be the XXXX payment of the same amount. Did these payments get credited to my account or were they put in a suspense account? 

So, I am not sure how you came up with the amount due as {$4500.00}. Can you explain that to me? 

Keep in mind that I have been trying for over two years to get the modification corrected to follow the federal CARES ACT with no success. Regardless, I have continued to make the payments at the amounts requested by Shellpoint knowing that they are overcharged based on the incorrect interest rate, feeling confident that eventually Shellpoint will correct the modification and my " overpayments '' will be correctly amortized and the excess could either be refunded to me or credited to the mortgage balance. 

I will gather the information you requested regarding my divorce and send it off to you via email. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX to me Good Afternoon, We have reviewed the file and are going to honor the first modification approved with the COVID interest rate that would have had the first payment starting on XX/XX/XXXX. To accept this you will need to make the payments that would have been due as of today with that start date. We will take into consideration what has been paid in the meantime. Total amount is {$12000.00}. The difference of this and what has been received ( {$8100.00} ) is {$4500.00}. Hopefully this will help better understand. 

Thanks XXXX XXXX Loss Mitigation XXXX Hours of Operation : Monday thru Friday XXXX. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX Toll Free XXXX XXXX XXXX  From : XXXX XXXX XXXX Sent : Wednesday, XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX  To : XXXX XXXX XXXX ; XXXX XXXX XXXX Subject : [ EXTERNAL ] Re : XXXX External Email. Please use caution before clicking on links or opening attachments. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX to XXXX, me Good afternoon. Thank you for your note. 

Unfortunately your company has either missed XXXX XXXX or chooses to ignore all of my correspondence over the past two years. Further, you are not giving me proper credit for the payments I have made, for example posting my most recent two payments of {$810.00} as {$670.00} to the account. 

Shellpoint is not calculating the proper interest rate per the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Reference Guide, XX/XX/XXXX edition, wherein the proper interest rate should be 2.875 %. I am again attaching a PDF copy of the Guide and I draw your attention to page # XXXX, where modification interest rates are shown. For the period in question the rate is clearly shown to be 2.875 %, not the 6 % as offered all along by Shellpoint. Regardless, I have made every payment at the higher rate thinking that at some point the correction will be made and the excess interest paid will be credited to the outstanding loan balance or refunded. This needs to be corrected and I will be happy to run the spreadsheet breaking down the payment overage that is due to be credited to me if someone internally does not know how to do it. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX attachment Scanned by XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX to lossmitigation, XXXX, me Re my loan # XXXX Good afternoon. 

I have a letter from Shellpoint acknowledging the servicing was incorrectly calculated when the servicing was transferred from XXXX to Shellpoint. Further, it confirms that the interest rate should have adjusted to the rate in the XXXX XXXX guidelines at 2.875 %, rather than the six percent employed by Shellpoint.

In my review of almost two years of payment to Shellpoint, history obtained from Shellpoint shows the payments were applied with no consistency and frequently shorted in their allocation, with funds being shown as " unapplied payment. '' In fact my most recent payment of {$810.00} to Shellpoint this month was likewise improperly credited. 

This situation has to be corrected for the entire time Shellpoint has been servicing my account. 

This is what needs to be done : 1. Since all of my payments to Shellpoint have been under the CARES Act since the servicing was outsourced to your company, starting with the initial offering of a modification, the payment amounts requested have to be recalculated. Whatever the amount was set as during the first three month trial period, you must subtract from that amount the funds set aside which were to be allocated to escrow for taxes and insurance. The remaining amount would be representative of principal and interest, and based on the erroneous documents sent to me that was calculated at six percent.

2. Run an amortization schedule based on the correct interest rate of 2.875 %, calculated on the mortgage balance. That will give the correct principal and interest to be charged based on 2.875 % XXXX XXXX stipulated rate for all of the payments I made to Shellpoint.. 

3. The amount determined as the principal and interest rate at 2.875 % is then subtracted from the principal and interest amount incorrectly calculated at the 6 percent rate.

4. The difference between the two amounts is payment overage that should be credited to the loan balance, thereby reducing the mortgage balance.

5. This needs to be calculated for every payment made to Shellpoint so that my account reflects the correct balance going forward. 

6. Prepare the final modification papers for my signature showing the corrected outstanding mortgage balance, the correct interest rate, and the remaining term for my signature.

I will run the above math myself this evening and forward it to you. I believe that when the account is corrected, there will be no additional {$4500.00} necessary as you have requested in your most recent email. 

Feel free to contact me should you have any questions. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX * * END * *

I hold legal title to the property, and I have submitted recorded title documentation on XXXX separate occasions, each time demonstrating clear ownership. 
Despite these submissions, Shellpoint has : Failed to identify any specific title defect ; Failed to cite any recorded document creating an alleged defect; Refused to provide access to anyone in their legal or title review department ; Provided only a generic complaint email address with no substantive response. 


Shellpoint has never explained whether this determination is based on servicer discretion or investor guidelines, nor has it identified whether it believes I do not hold fee simple title or that the title is unmarketable or uninsurable. 
I have acted in good faith throughout the loss-mitigation process and have complied with all documentation requests. Shellpoints vague and unsupported assertion that title is unclear is preventing completion of loss-mitigation review and exposes me to imminent foreclosure. 
Foreclosure proceedings are active. The mortgage is in my name, and delay caused by Shellpoints failure to properly review title documentation creates a risk of irreparable harm, including loss of the home and equity. 
This appears to be a failure of internal escalation to legal review and a breakdown in loss-mitigation compliance.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint regarding Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing and their mishandling of a short-sale file for the above-referenced property. This file has now been in process for several months with long periods of complete inactivity, no communication, and unexplained delays that are jeopardizing the sale and harming the estate.

We originally had a short-sale approval earlier this year and were scheduled to close. A minor fee discrepancy arose, which was quickly corrected and removed. Following that correction, the file fell into a complete standstill again with no movement and no updates provided despite repeated outreach by multiple parties, including myself as the authorized representative working on behalf of the estate.

For months, we have attempted to obtain status updates from Shellpoint. Emails go unanswered, escalation attempts receive no response, and the assigned representatives have not provided any meaningful information. Even a manager who has assisted us successfully in the past has not responded.

In early XXXX, after months of no communication, we were abruptly told the file was in review for a repurchase, with no explanation, no timeline, and no notice that this change was occurring. This was the first time we were informed of any such issue, leaving everyone blindsided and without clarity. The buyer has been waiting for months and is now at risk of walking away due to Shellpoints unexplained delays.

This behavior violates the servicers duty under RESPA 1024.41 to : Timely review and respond to loss-mitigation submissions Provide reasonable status updates Avoid dual tracking and unnecessary delays Communicate clearly and promptly with borrowers or authorized representatives Shellpoints repeated non-responsiveness and constant stalling have caused significant financial harm to the estate of XXXX and risk the collapse of a legitimate, arms-length purchase contract. We have complied with every request and provided all documentation immediately. There is no reasonable justification for these prolonged delays.

Issue: Applying for a mortgage or refinancing an existing mortgage
Sub-issue: Changes in loan terms during the application process
Consumer complaint narrative:
From the outset of my loan process with XXXX XXXX XXXX that started on XXXX XX/XX/year>, the experience has been deceptive and misleading. After a full week of discussions regarding the loan terms, including a specific agreed-upon XXXX, I was shocked to discover that the final terms which closed on XXXX XX/XX/year>, did not match what was actually funded. Once the loan was funded on XXXX XX/XX/year>, the interest rate had already inexplicably increased to an outrageous 13.16 % a significant and unjustified increase from what was promised at closing. 

Throughout the process, I was assured that funds would be deposited directly into my bank account, allowing me to manage my own debt. However, XXXX instead sent checks directly to creditors without my authorization a clear breach of our agreement. To make matters worse, I later learned that my loan had been transferred to a third-party company, Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing , also known as Newrez LLC a company I was never informed would be involved. Discovering that this company functions as a mortgage debt collector with a one-star rating on XXXX and an overwhelming 97 % negative review rate was both disturbing and unacceptable. No responsible consumer would knowingly enter into a financial agreement with a company that holds such a dismal reputation. This lack of transparency is both unethical and predatory. 

Customer service for both XXXX and Shellpoint/Newrez LLC has been virtually non-existent. Attempts to resolve these issues have led nowhere, further reinforcing the perception of intentional avoidance and lack of accountability.

The unauthorized changes to my loan terms including the interest rate and the handling of payments without proper notice or explanation, are not only misleading but may border on fraudulent. To include during the initial discussions, I would not proceed unless the contract mentioned a non-penalty clause for early repayment of the loan. XXXX failed to include this verbiage in the final terms. 

This entire experience reflects gross negligence, misrepresentation, and a disturbing lack of transparency from both companies involved. Given these serious concerns including the unauthorized rate increase, misapplication of funds, failure to include the prepayment penalty verbiage in the contract and the overall concealment of key information I am formally requesting the immediate cancellation of this loan and rescission of any related obligations or transfers. I entered into this agreement in good faith, relying on representations made by your organization, which have proven to be inaccurate and misleading. I expect an urgent review of this matter and written confirmation that the loan has been cancelled, along with all necessary steps taken to resolve the issue. Failing this, I will escalate my complaint to the XXXX XXXX XXXX, state legislators, and all applicable consumer protection agencies.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Notice of Error Improper Property Inspection Fee, Overdue Payment, Misapplication of Payments, and Refusal to Accept Principal and Interest Payments Dear Newrez LLC dba Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing I am submitting this Notice of Error pursuant to 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 regarding multiple servicing errors and improper charges applied to my mortgage loan. 

Since XX/XX/year>, your company has added a recurring {$30.00} overdue payment to my account. My loan is not in default, and I have remained current on all required payments. I also do not maintain an escrow account on this loan and pay all property taxes and homeowners insurance directly. 

Despite my loan being current, you have : Refused to accept full principal and interest payments, including those with additional principal applied ; Carried forward and demanded payment of an unauthorized {$30.00} " overdue payment '' and property inspection fee, which you have declined to substantiate ; Failed to provide documentation showing why or how the overdue payment occurred, how, when, why, or by whom any property inspection was performed. 

Under HUD guidelines, Regulation X ( 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 and 1024.38 ), and RESPA servicing standards, overdue payments and property inspection fees may be assessed only when a borrower is delinquent or when a default situation justifies them. As I am current and no such delinquency exists, the fee appears improperly applied and any resulting rejection of payments constitutes a servicing violation. 

Requested Actions Please provide the following within the time required by law ( acknowledgment within 5 business days and full response within 30 business days ) : A complete account history from origination to present showing all fees, charges, and payments applied, including corporate advances, overdue payments, property inspection fees, and any reversals or offsets ; Documentation and authorization for each overdue payment and property inspection fee charged since XX/XX/year>, including the date of the inspection, the address inspected, the purpose of the inspection, and proof of the servicers right to charge such fees under the terms of my loan ; Confirmation that my loan is not in default and that payments have been properly credited to principal and interest as required by 12 C.F.R. 1024.38 ( b ) ( 5 ) ; Immediate removal or reversal of any improperly assessed overdue payment or property inspection fees ; Written assurance that all future payments, including those designating additional principal, will be accepted and correctly applied. 

Please treat this as a formal Notice of Error and Request for Information under 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 and 1024.36. 

Sincerely,

Consumer complaint narrative:
My mortgage loan has been transferred between servicers multiple times. Since the beginning of the loan and for all prior years, I have always paid property taxes directly, while the escrow account has been used only for insurance.

After the servicing transfer to Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing, the company reported an incorrect escrow shortage and demanded {$9100.00}, despite the fact that my actual escrow-related payments total approximately {$4900.00}. This shortage was created due to Shellpoints failure to properly review the loans prior servicing history and account for taxes I paid directly. 
On XX/XX/year>, I contacted Shellpoint and was instructed to submit proof of my property tax payments. On XX/XX/year>, I provided complete documentation showing that I paid property taxes directly. Despite this, Shellpoint failed to correct the escrow balance. 
On XXXX XXXX XXXX, I received an updated billing statement again demanding {$9100.00}, with no correction applied. On XX/XX/year>, I contacted Shellpoint again and was instructed to resend all documentation by email, which I did. 
Since then, I have contacted Shellpoint at least four additional times, including speaking with supervisors. Shellpoint has stated that they allegedly paid the property taxes themselves and are now waiting for a refund from XXXX XXXX. This explanation has been repeated for over one month, yet no refund has been received, no escrow correction has been made, and no overpayment has been returned to me.

Regardless of any refund Shellpoint claims to be waiting for, property taxes were never intended to be paid through escrow, and any duplicate or mistaken tax payment made by the servicer is the result of their own error. Shellpoint continues to retain more than {$4000.00} of my funds, has placed my escrow account into a negative balance due to their mistake, and continues to demand inflated and incorrect escrow payments.

Despite repeated notice and full documentation, Shellpoint has failed to provide a proper escrow analysis, failed to reconcile the duplicate tax payment issue, and failed to refund the overcharged funds. This constitutes improper escrow accounting, failure to correct a known servicing error, and unlawful retention of borrower funds.

As of the most recent billing update, Shellpoint has changed the demanded escrow amount to {$6400.00}, which remains incorrect and unsupported by any valid escrow analysis. Despite this change, my escrow account continues to show a negative balance of {$15000.00} as of today. No explanation has been provided
for these changing figures, and the underlying escrow error has still not been corrected.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/year> - Submitted a request on NewRez web portal to remove escrow/close my escrow account XX/XX/year> - Called for a status update on my request. I was told my request was denied because my loan-to-value ratio was above 80 %. The customer service representative verbally confirmed that this information is NOT CORRECT and my XXXX at the time was below 60 %. He acknowledged that because I do not have PMI on my mortgage, that it MUST be below 80 %. He called his escalation team and confirmed with them that there must be an error. The representative and the escalation team verbally confirmed there were no disqualifying reasons to deny my request for escrow removal. He opened my request back up and sent it to the escalation team. 

XX/XX/year> - Called to check on my re-opened case. I was told by a new customer service rep once again that my request was denied because my XXXX was too high, above 80 %. The representative confirmed once again that my XXXX was, in fact, below 80 % and acknowledged that this is evident because I do not have PMI on my mortgage. She stated, however, that NewRez uses two different calculation to calculate XXXX. For PMI removal they will use latest appraised value. For escrow removal, they will use ORIGINAL LOAN AMOUNT. I asked her to clarify that she did not mean ORIGINAL APPRAISED VALUE and she verbally confirmed. I explained that, hypothetically, if someone made a 50 % down payment on a house, that using ORIGINAL LOAN AMOUNT to calculate XXXX would result in a 100 % XXXX on day one of that mortgage, despite the person having 50 % equity in the house. She confirmed this is how they calculate XXXX. 

XX/XX/year> - Sent formal complaint letter via NewRez web portal requesting written escrow removal policy and XXXX calculation clarifications. 

XX/XX/year> - Received letter in mail from NewRez requesting more time to respond in a thorough and accurate manner. 

XX/XX/year> - Received an email from NewRez with a generic response denying my request to remove escrow because my XXXX is above 80 %. They attached my XXXX XXXX XXXX that simply showed my payment and balances since the loans origination. They did not attach any written policies, any calculation clarification, nor did they even provide my current XXXX ( simply " above 80 % '' ). 

I believe Newrez is applying contradictory internal policies and denying escrow removal without proper basis. This refusal to provide documentation or apply consistent standards appears to violate the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA, 12 U.S.C. 2605 ) and constitutes unfair servicing practices.

What Happened I am filing this complaint because my entire mortgage account has collapsed, and the servicing platform used by XXXX XXXX XXXX, NewRez LLC, and Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing is producing contradictory, corrupted, and unrecoverable loan data in real time. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  I documented the following failures across both NewRez and Shellpoint portals, which share the same core database : My due date changes repeatedly between : XX/XX/XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/XXXX ( Next Coupon Date ) XX/XX/XXXX ( earlier XXXX  date ) My past due amount changes between : {$0.00} {$3900.00} {$5000.00} My late fees appear and disappear, including a {$1000.00} Late Charge even though I paid before the due date.

The NewRez portal and Shellpoint portal display simultaneous but conflicting data about my : due date payment status late fees escrow delinquency coupon date unapplied balance past-due history This shows that the entire servicing engine is malfunctioning, with modules overwriting each other and generating synthetic due dates that do not exist in my contract. 



XXXX. Why This Is Illegal These failures violate multiple federal laws, including : RESPA ( 12 U.S.C. 2605 ) Regulation X ( 12 C.F.R. 1024.35, 1024.38 ) UDAAP ( 12 U.S.C. 5531 ) VA Mortgage Servicing Rules ( 38 C.F.R. 36.4315 ) Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ) CFPB Mortgage Servicing Rules ( 2014 Final Rule ) Prohibition on unearned fees ( CFPB Bulletin 2013-07 ) Under these laws, servicers must : maintain accurate, retrievable loan records correctly apply payments maintain accurate escrow accounting ensure accurate delinquency reporting refrain from assessing unearned late fees provide consistent data across platforms avoid false representation of debt avoid dual-portal contradictions maintain systems that do not produce synthetic due dates The violations documented today show that none of these obligations are being met. 



XXXX. Why This Is Catastrophic The evidence now shows : My loan data is corrupted beyond repair. 
The platforms records contradict themselves. 
The servicer can no longer calculate my true payment or delinquency.

This is a full platform collapse.

XXXX. What I Want I am requesting : {>= $1,000,000} in individual damages Reflecting : financial harm emotional and XXXX  harm XXXX-veteran harm multiplier XXXX years of ongoing errors imminent wrongful foreclosure risk permanent data corruption VA-loan-specific statutory violations systemic reckless servicing practices {>= $1,000,000} in national restitution This platform is failing across thousands of borrowers.

Consumer complaint narrative:
CFPB Complaint and Demand for Document Production Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing This filing supplements and replaces prior submissions regarding Shellpoint Mortgage Servicings ongoing violations of federal law. Shellpoint has failed to provide a substantive response to my Qualified Written Request ( QWR ) dated June 17, 2025, in violation of 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( e ) of the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA ). The servicer continues to rely on fraudulent and incomplete documents to justify servicing a loan it does not own. 

The QWR requested full documentation of ownership, assignments ( recorded and unrecorded ), and proof of servicing authority for the loan associated with my property at XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, GA XXXX ( Loan No. XXXX ). Shellpoint failed to produce any of these materials, instead recycling the same unsupported statement that XXXX XXXX, XXXX, as successor trustee to XXXX, XXXX, as trustee for XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX is the investor. Shellpoint continues to rely solely on a XXXX Assignment of Mortgage executed by XXXX XXXX as Vice President of MERS, even though the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX was terminated in XXXX according to SEC filings XXXX 

The Note and Allonge produced by Shellpoint confirm that the note was never lawfully transferred. The Allonge to Note is blankit contains no endorsement, no transferee, and only the signature of XXXX XXXX, Vice President of XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX A blank allonge means that the original lender did not endorse or transfer the note to any other entity. Under the Uniform Commercial Code ( XXXX XXXX and XXXX ), a note without a specific endorsement can not be legally negotiated or enforced by another party. Because the allonge is blank, there is no proof that XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, or Shellpoint ever became the lawful holder of the note or obtained rights to collect payments. 

Despite this, Shellpoint continues to collect payments, send letters, and make collection-related communications. This conduct constitutes ongoing violations of RESPA and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), including misrepresentation of debt and failure to validate ownership. 

Shellpoint has ignored specific document requests, including : - All recorded and unrecorded assignments of the Security Deed and Note ; - Proof that XXXX XXXX is an active entity with lawful trustee authority ; - Verification of Shellpoints servicing contract and custodial authorization ; - Complete servicing transfer history identifying each prior servicer and effective dates ; - Custodial or investor agreements authorizing Shellpoint to collect payments ; - Escrow and payment application history since origination. 

Because Shellpoint has refused to comply with federal law and continues to rely on fraudulent filings, I was forced to file a Quiet Title Action, Discovery and Lis Pendens in XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( Case No. XXXX ) to protect my property rights and establish clear title.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint against Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ( Shellpoint ) regarding severe issues with the servicing of my mortgage loan, account number XXXX, for the property at XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. Shellpoints actions have violated federal laws, including the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA ), the Consumer Financial Protection Act, and Californias Homeowner Bill of Rights ( HBOR ), jeopardizing my home despite significant equity and a documented hardship. Below, I detail the events, the companys misconduct, and my requested resolution. 
What Happened I lost my job in XX/XX/XXXX, creating a new financial hardship that prevents me from meeting my mortgage payments. I submitted multiple complete loan modification applications, with Shellpoint acknowledging them as complete on XX/XX/XXXX ( effective XX/XX/XXXX ), XX/XX/XXXX ( effective XX/XX/XXXX ), and most recently XX/XX/XXXX. Each acknowledgment promised a 30-day review period and foreclosure protection, yet Shellpoint denied my applications on XX/XX/XXXX, and XX/XX/XXXX, with reasons including the approaching foreclosure sale, maximum modifications reached ( three prior mods ), insufficient hardship verification, failed Net Present Value ( NPV ) test, excessive delinquency, and programmatic ineligibilitywithout requesting additional documents. 
For months, Shellpoint has ignored my emails and calls, with customer service deflecting me to their legal department. Attorney XXXX XXXX XXXX, representing Shellpoint, insists all communication go through him, rejected my {$500000.00} short payoff offer on XX/XX/XXXX, and refused to postpone the XX/XX/XXXX, foreclosure sale, citing the prior modifications as a permanent bar. This contradicts the active review protections and my new hardship. My home, valued at least {$4.00} XXXX ( per an independent appraisal ), faces a disputed balance of {$1.00} XXXX from an original {$1.00} XXXX loan in XXXX, with Shellpoints Broker Price Opinion ( BPO ) at {$3.00} XXXX, a {$700000.00} discrepancy. Ive filed a lawsuit in XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ) on XX/XX/XXXX, alleging dual-tracking, HBOR violations XXXX and emotional distress, and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, indicating investor concern. 
What the Company Did Wrong Violation of Loss Mitigation Rules : Federal regulations ( 12 CFR 1024.41 ) and HBOR ( 2923.6 ) require evaluation of complete applications based on new hardships, like my job loss. Denying review due to prior modifications, without substantiating this limit for a conventional loan, is arbitrary and non-compliant. 
XXXX : The XX/XX/XXXX, acknowledgment grants protection until XXXX, yet the XX/XX/XXXX sale proceeds, violating 12 CFR 1024.41 ( g ) and HBOR 2924.11 .

Failure to Respond : RESPA ( 12 U.S.C. 2605 ) mandates timely responses to inquiries, which Shellpoint has ignored, funneling me to an unresponsive attorney.

Unfair Practices : Rushed denials, inconsistent valuations, and refusal to consider my equity or settlement offer suggest deceptive tactics to force foreclosure, breaching Unfair, Deceptive, or Abusive Acts or Practices ( UDAAP ) standards.

Valuation Discrepancy : The {$700000.00} gap between Shellpoints BPO and my appraisal hints at manipulation to justify foreclosure, a potential RESPA violation.

This statement directly contradicts : XXXX XXXXcertified ownership disclosures XXXX filings XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX filings XXXX  materials XXXX  public statement of subsidiary structure Every XXXX and XXXX submitted under penalty of federal law By disavowing its parent, NewRez implicitly destroys the legitimacy of XXXX its own governance chain, its legal authority to service mortgage accounts, its compliance responsibility hierarchy, its supervisory oversight structure, and its XXXX  certification lineage. 

A servicer with no parent, no controller, and no lawful governance is not a servicer at all it is a free-floating, unanchored financial entity operating outside the required structure mandated by federal mortgage servicing law. 

This is a systemic, platform-level failure. 



1. NewRezs Own Statement Legally Orphaned the Company NewRez told regulators : XXXX is not associated with NewRez/Shellpoint. 

This disclaims : ownership, agency, governance, control, authority to consolidate, accountability structure, oversight committees, risk management lineage. 

Under federal definitions, this creates an orphan entity, because the designated parent in SEC filings has been rejected. 

A servicer can not legally operate without : a controlling parent ( 12 U.S.C. 2605 ) an established governance chain XXXX oversight an accountable board a validated consolidator a lawful reporting hierarchy NewRez now has none. 



2. SEC-Regulated Entities Can not Disavow Ownership Without Collapsing Their Structure XXXX SEC filings certify : 100 % ownership consolidation of income, liabilities, and MSRs consolidation of goodwill integration of legal, risk, and compliance control over internal audit oversight authority If NewRez claims the opposite, then the company is : unaffiliated ungoverned unanchored structurally illegitimate unable to rely on parent filings unable to certify any compliance This is the definition of a regulatory orphan. 



3. A Mortgage Servicer Can not Operate Without a Parent or Controller Federal law requires a servicer to have : a designated controller ( XXXX XXXX ) a parent with financial responsibility for errors a corporate governance chain clear audit authority ( XXXX ) compliance oversight ( CFPB Supervision Manual ) an accountable board internal controls validated by the parent If the parent disclaims ownership : the servicer is operating illegally. 

There is no legal pathway to operate a mortgage servicing platform without : a parent board, XXXX certifiers, a consolidator, an accountable owner. 

NewRez now meets the definition of : an unparented servicer engaging in high-risk, unregulated operations. 



4. NewRezs Existence Depends on XXXX  Governance Which They Just Rejected Every NewRez action depends on : XXXX board approvals XXXX  risk committee XXXX  capital allocations XXXX XXXX valuations XXXX  regulatory compliance audit XXXX  XXXX signing officers XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX investor XXXX If NewRez claims it is not associated with XXXX  : Then every one of the following becomes invalid : all XXXX  certifications all internal control attestations all consolidated MSR valuations all amortization schedules all XXXX  audit opinions all financial consolidations all risk disclosures all XXXX  qualification filings NewRezs entire existence collapses because it depends on Rithms filings.

5. Operating as an Orphan Servicer Violates Federal Servicing Law NewRez is required by law to be : governed supervised controlled audited overseen financially anchored Disavowing its parent violates : RESPA ( 12 U.S.C. 2605 ) Reg X ( 12 C.F.R. 1024 ) CFPB UDAAP prohibitions ( 12 U.S.C. 5531 ) SEC Rule 12b-20 SOX 302, 404 REIT qualification rules Servicer governance requirements ( CFPB Supervision Manual, Part 1 ) Interagency Internal Controls Guidelines This is not a clerical mistake it is a nuclear breach of federal financial structure. 



XXXX. The Resulting Entity Is Illegitimate and High-Risk Under supervisory classification, NewRez is now : A free-floating regulated entity no validated parent no lawful controller no governance lineage no certified reporting structure no XXXX XXXX no validated internal controls no risk oversight In other words : An unlicensed ship pretending to fly a flag it no longer recognizes. 

Such an entity can not legally service mortgages in the United States. 



7. Requested Enforcement Actions I request that federal regulators : 1. Investigate NewRez for operating without a lawful parent.

2. Review all contradictory statements made to CFPB, TNDFI, and SEC XXXX 
3. Examine XXXX  certification breakdown. 
4. Assess whether NewRezs governance structure still meets federal standards.

5. Determine whether NewRez is operating as an unregistered, unsupervised servicer.

6. Evaluate all MSR valuations, escrow accounting, and ledger operations tied to an orphaned servicer.

7. Refer structural contradictions to SEC Enforcement for securities fraud implications.

NewRez can not claim to be independent while relying on XXXX filings to operate. 
A servicer can not exist without a parent. 
A parent can not disavow a subsidiary without collapsing the entire structure. 

NewRez is now an entity without a lawful foundation. 



Closing Statement By rejecting its parent, NewRez has invalidated its own governance, its own legality, and its own operational existence.

A mortgage servicer can not exist as an orphaned entity, and NewRez has now placed every borrower including XXXX veterans at risk under a collapsed oversight structure. 

This is an existential regulatory failure requiring immediate investigation.

Sub-issue: Applying for or obtaining a modification, forbearance plan, short sale, or deed-in-lieu
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am submitting this complaint regarding Shellpoint Mortgage Servicings refusal to consider me for mortgage assistance despite documented financial hardship.

My gross monthly income is approximately {$2500.00}. My documented monthly expenses total roughly {$3700.00}, resulting in a consistent monthly deficit of over {$1100.00}. I submitted a complete mortgage assistance application and an appeal, along with supporting documentation. 
Shellpoint denied my request and appeal, stating that I have sufficient income or resources and that I must be at least 60 days delinquent before they will consider loss mitigation options. I was verbally informed of this policy by a Shellpoint representative after confirming receipt of my appeal. 
Requiring a borrower to become delinquent to be reviewed for affordability assistance intentionally creates unnecessary risk of default and contradicts responsible mortgage servicing practices. My request is for an interest-rate modification to prevent future default, not payment forbearance. 
I am requesting that Shellpoint be required to conduct a good-faith loss mitigation review based on my documented income, expenses, and affordability hardship, without requiring delinquency as a prerequisite.

Sub-issue: Trying to communicate with the company to fix an issue while managing or servicing your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am the homeowner of a property in KXXXX XXXXXXXX, Missouri with a HELOC serviced by Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing. Without notifying me, Shellpoint initiated a lender-placed insurance ( LPI ) wind claim on my property using their force-placed policy. I was never informed that a claim had been filed, never provided any claim documents, and was never given the opportunity to participate in the claim, review the damages, or dispute the findings. 

Shellpoint failed to send required notices, failed to inform me of claim activity, and withheld all claim information. This appears to violate Missouri Revised Statute 375.1007, the Missouri Merchandising Practices Act ( MMPA ), RESPA/Regulation X, and federal rules governing force-placed insurance disclosures.

I am requesting an investigation into Shellpoints conduct and assistance compelling Shellpoint to release the full claim file, including all photos, reports, estimates, communications, and payments associated with this unauthorized claim.

This situation may involve deceptive mortgage-servicing practices, misrepresentation in an insurance transaction, and failure to comply with federal force-placed insurance regulations.

Consumer complaint narrative:
NewRez LLC ( servicer of my mortgage ) has repeatedly failed to implement my lawful request to convert my monthly mortgage into true bi-weekly payments ( 26 half-payments per year, applied upon receipt ). Despite written notices, ACH enrollment, and follow-up correspondence, NewRez continues to denied by weekly payment right and issue the same non-responsive letters. 

Violations : 1. Regulation Z ( Truth in Lending Act, 12 CFR 1026.36 ( c ) ( 1 ) ( i ) - ( ii ) ) : Servicers must credit payments as of the date received. If partial payments are placed in suspense, once they equal a full periodic payment, the servicer must apply them retroactively to the original dates of receipt. NewRez instead holds first bi-weekly installments and only credits as of the second draft, stripping me of lawful interest savings.

2. TILA 129G ( a ), 15 U.S.C. 1639g : Requires timely application of partial payments unless a contrary arrangement was disclosed. My Note and Deed of Trust contain no waiver of this protection.

3. RESPA Servicing Rules ( 12 CFR 1024.35 ) : I submitted a formal Notice of Error on XX/XX/year>. RESPA requires acknowledgment within 5 business days and resolution within 30. NewRez requested more time without providing a new deadline, then repeated the same form letter.

4XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ) prohibit servicers from withholding the interest-saving effect of early payments. 
Harm : Each delay denies me the benefit of accelerated principal reduction and reduces the financial advantage of bi-weekly amortization. It also exposes me to confusion over suspense account handling and possible misapplication of additional principal drafts.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
