Consumer complaint narrative:
NOTICE OF ERROR ESCROW OVERCOLLECTION AND SURPLUS MISAPPLICATION Date : XX/XX/XXXX Borrower : XXXX XXXX XXXX Loan Number : XXXX Property Address : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Servicer : Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing Servicer Contact : XXXX CFPB Complaint References : # XXXX and # XXXX Subject : Formal Notice of Error Pursuant to 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( RESPA ) Dear Shellpoint Compliance Department, I am submitting this Final Notice of Error regarding the mishandling of my escrow account, misapplication of surplus funds, and continuing overcharges following the transfer of my loan from XXXX XXXX to Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing.

1. Escrow Overcollection and Surplus Misapplication Your most recent Escrow Analysis ( dated XX/XX/XXXX ) acknowledges a {$3600.00} surplus in my escrow account. Despite this, Shellpoint continues to collect escrow payments at inflated rates ( {$1000.00} monthly ) rather than the adjusted amount of {$850.00}, as reflected in your own analysis.

While I understand that my account is currently five months past due, that delinquency resulted primarily from ongoing escrow overcharges and Shellpoints failure to correct the inherited miscalculations from XXXX XXXX. Under 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( b ) ( 5 ), the servicers failure to properly apply escrow funds or adjust payments based on accurate tax obligations constitutes a servicing error.

2. Improper Escrow Disbursement Practices Shellpoint has continued to project inflated tax disbursements of {$10000.00} annually, even though actual property tax obligations have been substantially lower. As a result, my escrow account balance has been artificially reduced, masking the true surplus and creating the appearance of delinquency where none should exist.

This pattern directly violates 12 C.F.R. 1024.17 ( f ), which limits escrow collection to amounts sufficient to cover anticipated disbursements plus one-sixth of the annual total. The consistent collection of excess funds, without timely refund or application to principal or arrears, is non-compliant with federal servicing requirements.

3. Request for Immediate Corrective Action I am requesting the following : A full, written correction of my escrow account to reflect the true tax obligations and the accurate monthly escrow amount of {$850.00}.

Immediate application of the {$3600.00} escrow surplus toward my past-due principal and interest balance.

A written explanation of how and when the surplus will be applied or refunded.

A temporary halt on any further payment increases or account adjustments until this matter is corrected and I receive a written response under 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( e ) ( 3 ) ( i ) ( C ).

4. Supporting Documentation Enclosed are copies of : Shellpoints Escrow Analysis ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Escrow Transaction History showing consistent overcollection XXXX XXXX  rate adjustment notice ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Prior correspondence and CFPB complaint summaries 5. Notice and Compliance Request This letter constitutes a qualified written request and notice of error under Regulation X ( 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ). You are required to acknowledge receipt within five ( 5 ) business days and provide a written resolution or correction within thirty ( 30 ) business days.

I request that all collection activity, account adjustments, or payment increases be suspended during your investigation of this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Sub-issue: An existing modification, forbearance plan, short sale, or other loss mitigation relief
Consumer complaint narrative:
I respectfully submit this complaint against Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing regarding the mishandling, excessive delays, and inconsistent communication in the processing of my FHA short sale application. My experience demonstrates multiple servicing deficiencies, including potential violations of Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA ) provisions, CFPB Mortgage Servicing Rules under Regulation X ( 12 C.F.R. 1024.41 ), and FHA short sale guidelines. 

Despite my cooperation, timely responses, and the existence of a strong {$520000.00} all-cash offer from a qualified buyer, Shellpoint has failed to close my short sale after more than four months from the date of offer acceptance. I allege that Shellpoints conduct has caused : In XX/XX/XXXX, facing financial hardship, I initiated an FHA short sale request with Shellpoint by submitting a completed hardship application. Consumer complaint narrative:
IMMINENT HARM CFPB COMPLAINT WILLFUL REFUSAL TO COOPERATE WITH STATE AG & CONTINUING HARM Company : NewRez LLC ( d/b/a Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ), owned by XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
Product : Mortgage ( VA-backed home loan ) Issue : Trouble during payment process / improper servicing / refusal to correct errors / obstruction of state-AG mediation 1. What happened I filed a detailed consumer complaint with the Pennsylvania Office of Attorney General, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) against NewRez LLC d/b/a Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing concerning corrupted loan data, misapplied / unapplied payments, negative escrow, and foreclosure risk on my VA-backed mortgage. 
On [ email date ], I received the attached email from XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, Pennsylvania OAG XXXX, regarding Complaint No. XXXX. 
The email states that the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : attempted to resolve your complaint against NewRez LLC ( d/b/a Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ) through a voluntary mediation process, but we have not been able to resolve this matter to your satisfaction and have reached an impasse between you and NewRez LLC ( d/b/a Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing ), and we will take no further action on your complaint at this time.

The email also confirms : A copy of your complaint will remain on file for future reference and for possible use in an investigation or enforcement action we may bring to protect the public interest of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.

In plain terms : a state Attorney Generals consumer-protection office tried to mediate my dispute with NewRez / Shellpoint . The company refused to resolve it, and the AG is now keeping my complaint for possible enforcement use. 

This is not a situation where I refused mediation ; it is a situation where NewRez / Shellpoint declined to take the off-ramp that would have repaired their servicing errors and protected a 100 % permanently and totally XXXX veteran from further harm. 



2. Why this is willful & deliberate obstruction Federal law requires mortgage servicers to investigate and correct account errors and to respond to written Notices of Error : 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( e ) : Servicers must respond to borrower inquiries and error notices.

12 U.S.C. 2605 ( k ) ( 1 ) ( C ) : Servicers may not fail to take timely action to respond to a borrowers requests to correct errors.

12 C.F.R. 1024.35 : Servicers must acknowledge a Notice of Error within 5 business days and then either correct the error or provide a detailed written explanation within required timeframes.

12 C.F.R. 1024.38 : Servicers must maintain policies and procedures to accurately credit payments, maintain records, and respond to borrower complaints.

In my case : I have already sent multiple RESPA Notices of Error and legal-hold letters to NewRez / Shellpoint about misapplied funds, inaccurate delinquency status, and corrupted escrow.

Instead of providing the required written corrections or a consistent accounting, the company has closed XXXX as duplicates, refused to explain contradictory ledgers, and continued to change key figures ( unapplied funds, escrow balances, past due amounts ) while foreclosure pressure continued. 
The Pennsylvania OAG XXXX email now shows that even when a state AGs office intervened, NewRez / Shellpoint still would not resolve the matter, causing an impasse and forcing the AG to suspend mediation and reserve the complaint for possible enforcement. 

A servicer that 1 ) ignores or duplicate-closes XXXX  and 2 ) refuses to cooperate with a state Attorney Generals mediation process is not simply confused. It is obstructing the statutory error-correction framework that RESPA, Regulation X, and state consumer-protection laws are built on.

3. Ongoing harm Because NewRez / Shellpoint refused to resolve this in the AGs mediation : My VA loan account remains corrupted, with conflicting ledgers and negative escrow despite significant payments. 
I remain under continuing foreclosure risk based on data that the servicer and now a state AGs office know is disputed and potentially unreliable. 
As a 100 % permanently and totally XXXX veteran, this prolonged uncertainty and threat of losing my home causes severe emotional and psychological harm on top of the financial harm. 
Other borrowers who complain to the Pennsylvania OAG may face the same impasse, meaning this pattern is not just about me ; it raises a systemic risk that NewRez / Shellpoint / XXXX will stonewall state-level mediation while continuing harmful servicing practices. 



4. Damages requested For CFPB purposes, I am asking that this complaint be treated as both an individual harm case and an indicator of a broader pattern and practice : Individual relief requested {>= $1,000,000} in compensatory, statutory, and punitive damages for : financial harm from corrupted servicing, threats of foreclosure, and fees ; severe emotional and psychological distress aggravated by my status as a 100 % permanently and totally XXXX veteran ; time, cost, and effort spent pursuing corrections through multiple regulators and now the Pennsylvania OAG.

Full payoff and release of my VA-backed mortgage so that my home is secured free and clear. 
Full correction of all tradelines and credit reports to remove any delinquencies, late fees, or negative remarks that stem from the corrupted data and unresolved errors. 

Systemic / public-interest relief requested Creation of a {>= $1,000,000} restitution and remediation fund for other borrowers serviced by NewRez / Shellpoint XXXX XXXX whose accounts have been impacted by similar data corruption, misapplied payments, or refusal to correct errors, with priority for VA loans XXXX FHA loans XXXX and loans to active-duty military and XXXX veterans. 
A comprehensive servicing-platform audit ( data integrity, escrow handling, payment application, XXXX response procedures ) supervised by CFPB and state regulators ( including Pennsylvania OAG and Tennessee  XXXX XXXX. 
Appropriate civil money penalties for pattern-and-practice violations of RESPA, Regulation X, and unfair / deceptive acts or practices under the Consumer Financial Protection Act and applicable state UDAP laws. 



5. What I am asking CFPB to do Given the Pennsylvania OAG email, I respectfully request that CFPB : Treat this as evidence that NewRez / Shellpoint are refusing to participate in good-faith resolution with a state Attorney General, despite active servicing errors. 
Open ( or expand ) a supervisory or enforcement investigation into NewRez LLC, Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing, and XXXX XXXX XXXX for violations of 12 U.S.C. 2605, 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 & 1024.38, and unfair / deceptive acts or practices. 
Coordinate with the Pennsylvania OAG XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX to use my complaint file ( XXXX ) as part of any joint or parallel enforcement action. 
Require the company to correct my account, pay damages, and implement systemic fixes so that other consumers are not forced into the same situation. 

Attached is the full email from XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, Pennsylvania Office of Attorney General, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, which documents the failed mediation and confirms that my complaint is being retained for possible enforcement use.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Systemic Compliance Collapse NewRez LLC d/b/a Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing / XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 

Complainant : XXXX XXXX Loan Number : XXXX Property : XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX  XXXX Narrative Between XXXX XXXX XXXX, I submitted a Qualified Written Request ( QWR ) and Notice of Error ( NOE ) under RESPA ( 12 C.F.R. 1024.3536 ), supported by metadata, payment ledgers, and call transcripts proving misapplied mortgage payments and ledger manipulation. 
Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing acknowledged receipt three timesissuing letters dated XX/XX/XXXX, and XXXX, XXXXeach unsigned, auto-generated, and issued by the Customer Care Team rather than the Compliance or Legal Department . 

Despite direct notice to the Chief Legal Officer of Shellpoint and the President of XXXX XXXX, the matter remains trapped at the customer-service level. This demonstrates a collapse of Shellpoints compliance-management system and a pattern of reckless disregard for federal servicing obligations. 



1. Procedural and Legal Violations Shellpoints actions violate 12 C.F.R. 1024.35 ( c ) ( 1 ) and 1024.36 ( d ) ( 2 ) by failing to route borrower error allegations to trained personnel and to provide a substantive written response within thirty business days.

Each acknowledgment letter constitutes constructive receipt under Marais v. Chase Home Finance LLC, 736 F.3d 711 ( 6th Cir. 2013 ), where acknowledgment without investigation was deemed reckless noncompliance.

Multiple court decisions reinforce that automated responses do not satisfy RESPA : Catalan v. RBC Mortgage Co., 2008 WL 2741159 ( N.D. Ill. 2008 ) form letters without review prove pattern or practice.

McLean v. GMAC Mortgage Corp., 398 F. Appx 467 ( 11th Cir. 2010 ) failure to act after acknowledgment constitutes willful violation.

Ploog v. HomeSide Lending Inc., 209 F. Supp. 2d 863 ( N.D. Ill. 2002 ) repeated template responses show systemic disregard.

2. Metadata and Digital Evidence The evidence packet included timestamped PDFs, author and version data, and ledger-file creation logs proving manipulation of unapplied payments and escrow accounting.

This metadata qualifies as electronically stored information ( ESI ) under Lorraine v. Markel American Ins. Co., 241 F.R.D. 534 ( D. Md. 2007 ) and must be preserved once notice is received ( Zubulake v. UBS Warburg LLC, 220 F.R.D. 212 ( S.D.N.Y. 2003 ) ).

Shellpoints failure to review or escalate these records is not accidentalit is intentional avoidance of regulatory obligations.

3. Evidence of Systemic Collapse All three acknowledgment letters were unsigned and auto-generated, confirming that Shellpoints platform issues federal acknowledgments through automation rather than compliance oversight.

This breakdown in routing, coupled with duplicate dates and no escalation to Legal, reveals that internal compliance architecture has failed.

Regulators view such behavior as a control-environment failurethe servicer can not identify, route, or remediate borrower notices. 
Because the XXXX and XXXX President were directly notified, corporate knowledge is established under agency law. Continuing to operate through automation after executive-level notice constitutes reckless disregard and pattern-level noncompliance under 12 U.S.C. 2605 ( f ) ( 1 ) ( B ). 



XXXX. Damages and Enforcement Demand I claim actual and statutory damages of no less than {$100000.00}, and seek compensatory relief of no less than {$150000.00} for unapplied payments, credit injury, and ongoing emotional and financial harm. 

I further request : XXXX. A full audit across all servicing platforms for escrow accounting and unapplied balances, including metadata validation and ledger cross-checks. 
XXXX. Immediate enforcement action by CFPB, coordinated with DOJ, SEC, and state attorneys general, to protect both myself and all other impacted borrowers. 
XXXX. An order requiring XXXX XXXX and NewRez to certify their compliance-management systems under 12 C.F.R. 1024.38 ( c ) ( 2 ). 



XXXX. Broader Pattern and Precedents NewRez LLC and Shellpoint have a documented history of litigation and enforcement exposure, including : Hodges v. NewRez LLC d/b/a Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing and Bank of New York Mellon ( Class Action , N.D. Cal., 2024 ) alleging deceptive zombie second-mortgage servicing.

Apodaca v. NewRez LLC ( E.D. Mich., 2023 ) alleging mishandled payment application and communication failures.

Ortiz v. NewRez LLC ( D. Mass., 2022 ) alleging repeated QWR/NOE violations . 

The CFPBs own public complaint database contains thousands of consumer reports describing nearly identical patterns : unapplied funds, contradictory statements, and unresponsive Customer-Care automation. This reflects an enterprise-level compliance failure that now extends to governance oversight under XXXX XXXX. 



6. Requested Regulatory Actions Open a CFPB enforcement and supervisory investigation into NewRez/Shellpoints correspondence-routing and metadata-handling practices. 
Coordinate with the DOJ Civil Division, SEC, and State Attorneys General to examine whether misrepresentation or spoliation occurred in violation of 18 U.S.C. 1519 and 15 U.S.C. 1692e ( 10 ).

Compel restitution for unapplied payments, removal of false delinquency notations, and permanent prohibition against foreclosure or adverse credit reporting during the review.

Respectfully submitted, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX is the parent company and controlling entity of NewRez LLC d/b/a Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing, exercising direct oversight of its servicing, compliance, and financial reporting operations. NewRez functions as a wholly owned subsidiary within XXXX mortgage-servicing portfolio, and its compliance failures therefore extend to XXXX governance obligations under federal law. XXXX executives receive and certify subsidiary performance data in public SEC filings, meaning that any systemic misrouting, metadata suppression, or RESPA violations at XXXX represent not only a servicing failure but a material governance breach attributable to XXXX itself under 15 U.S.C. 78j ( b ) and Regulation FD.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Mortgage Servicing Complaint Loan Holder- Newrez LLC XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, PA XXXX XXXX NMLS # XXXX Mortgage Serviced by- Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, SC XXXX Main Office NMLS ID # XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX Summary- Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing claims my mortgage has been in arrear since XXXX, XXXX, despite regular monthly payments. Shellpoint has charged me numerous fees during that time, in excess of {$1000.00} total, for late fees, property inspection fees, etc. Communication with Shellpoint on this issue over the last month has been, for the most part, unsatisfactory. 

During a chat conversation at the end of XXXX, I was told the problem was due to my mailing the payments and not allowing Shellpoint to directly debit my accounts despite my explaining to the rep during the chat that my payments are sent electronically from my bank. When I asked for a manager the chat was ended saying I was idle too long while I was replying to the latest message.This failed chat prompted a call which was connected to Shellpoint customer service representative, XXXX XXXX. XXXX was the only helpful person I have talked to at Shellpoint. With XXXX assistance we were able to identify that there were payments made electronically every month, with none missed but we were unable to come to a conclusion as to why the account fell into arrears. XXXX then opened complaint # XXXX in reference to the problem. 

Since this discussion I have been contacted by Shellpoint Customer Service by phone at least twice plus numerous texts which keep saying my payment has not been received. During one such call I informed the customer service rep there was a pending complaint about improper application of payments. This rep then opened a second complaint referencing the first complaint. In a subsequent call on XX/XX/XXXX, I again told the customer service rep that there was an unresolved complaint that needed to be answered and, at that time, since nothing had been done in regard to the complaint, I said if I need to open a complaint with my state AG and the CFPB. At this point I was asked to hold for a manager. 

At this time I was transferred to Shellpoint Customer Service Manager, XXXX. I asked again about the status of the complaint and was told the complaint was resolved on XX/XX/XXXX, or XXXX, while I was on the phone with a Shellpoint Customer Service representative. I believe this is the date referenced above when a second complaint was supposed to be opened. I communicated this and was again told. The complaint is closed. To date, no additional information on the complaint has been shared with me. 

The Customer Service Manager ( XXXX ) then reviewed something and told me our mortgage has been in arrears since XXXX, XXXX, due to a shortfall in payments caused by an interest rate increase of 2 % starting with the XXXX, XXXX payment. I do have an adjustable rate mortgage so an interest rate increase is possible. XXXX XXXX, the payment increased {$240.00} creating a shortfall and the account falling into arrears. 

I informed the Customer Service Manager that I had not received a notification of an increase. Per the Customer Service Manager, a notification of the rate increase was mailed to me on XX/XX/XXXX. I do not recall receiving the indicated notification from Shellpoint. Additionally, I have elected to receive electronic communication from Shellpoint and could not locate any rate notification in my email and, to the best of my knowledge, did not receive a printed/mailed notification. 

When I pressed the Customer Service Manager on the Unapplied Payments, Principal Only Payments and Late Charge Payments listed in the account history the call was abruptly cut off without warning. There was no return call from the customer service manager to continue the discussion and, as I had been provided no contact information for the manager, I had no way to resume the conversation. 

I have tried to understand what Shellpoint was doing with the payments but due to the complicated and confusing entries shown in the online payment history it has been impossible for me to do a proper analysis to understand what is going on. What I can identify is my payments recognized by Shellpoint as Regular Payment up to XX/XX/XXXX, and applied to my account as a Regular Payment and a Principal Only Payment for the payment due on XX/XX/XXXX. Beginning with the payment for XX/XX/XXXX, delivered on XX/XX/XXXX, the payment is identified as a Principal Only Payment After this date the entries become very confusing with entries for XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, Late Charge Assess, Unapplied Payments, back-dated Regular Payment, Property Inspection XXXX XXXX 

From a payment perspective, I can identify, via my bank records, a payment was delivered electronically from our bank 3 to 5 days before the payment due date so all payments were made on-time. 

Additionally, we decided to increase our payment amount in XXXX, XXXX, to pay down the mortgage faster. At that time we increased our payment by an additional {$400.00} per month from ( {$1700.00} to {$2100.00} ) and with that decision, an additional payment was sent by our bank on XX/XX/XXXX. This increased payment amount is still in effect today. 

My last point would be that it appears our ARM was adjusted again in XXXX, XXXX, and as with the previous adjustment, there was no notification either electronically or via printed mail. This was a rate decrease of XXXX percent.
